description: Top-Down-Shooter, without guns. You are one of the last survivors of the apocalypse and you just came out of the Thrift store and in to your car. Kill as many zombies as possible while stopping to save the survivors.
author: Pixel_Phased
title: Zombie Street
comments: It's realy slow - I mean it's slower than a slide show - on my Core2Quad with 1GB DD3...
I like the idea tough. This could be something really entertainig if expanded a little. But seriuosly you could find better sfx. :)

I had lots of problems understanding what I was doing and what was happening (besides squishing everything) at first. After playing it a while, I was like... is this everything? So I looked back on this page and was like: oh, there's people. I think a quick info screen--[img of car] "you", [img of zombie] "squish", and [img of human] "save"--would have gone a long way. On the same note, I couldn't tell if I was getting damaged (or could be). I didn't quite figure out what the three numbers on the top left were... (lack of formatting symbols like X:XX, HP, $). Better yet, revamp the UI (maybe health bar on top of car, money/time at top/bot center of screen). And a "ahhghg" scream for the human. And the lag. Lots of small details.
Don't get me wrong, I liked it. That's why I took the time to comment on everything. With a bit of polish, I can see this being a really fun game. :)

i have thought about these, should have put the image tutorial in, that would have helped and i probably had the time too. this was my first LD48 and i guess i panicked once there was under an hour left, the improved Gui would have been implemented if i had more time, thanks for the review, i think it will help me out for the next LD48.

Not too bad - like other people, I found it slow, but the basic mechanic was fun. I'd suggest that hitting zombies slow you down and that zombies don't turn as quickly. Also, if there were humans there I'm not sure I could tell them apart - maybe they should have had hats?

description:
Hey, so this is my entry.
It was made in about 20-25 hours,
This was made using unity3D.
I wanted to focus on the "Alone against many" rather than being alone..well Alone, without any people, Hope that does make sense :)
Please tell me if you find any bugs, or have any trouble getting the game,
Thanks !
author: Strkl
title: You're Alone.
comments: I really enjoyed this game.  I managed to get myself stuck in some geometry, but was able to beat the 4 starter enemies.
And then the whole circle started attacking.  It was pretty epic.
I could see this being the foundation of a very fun game.
One of the best games i have played in the LD22!
Little confusing at first, but definitly a great good. Love the connection to the theme
Thanks a lot for the feedback, that really means a lot :D

Really cool game. It took me some time to realize there was an offensive element to the game and when I did it really changed things up! I think this is one of the strongest games I've played in terms of the theme so far. Good work!
I enjoyed it. I wish there was some indicator that let me know when I could use my shield again.
Beaten in second attempt! Yeah! A pity it ended in an unfortunate way for the character, anyway. Great game.
Nice concept. I Like how the game just works, without any long explanation or intro.

It was confusing at first seeing how I couldn't do anything but wait.  Then, once I saw that the shield bounced the bullets back I understood what to do, but couldn't see any life label anywhere and the bullets didn't kill me.  When everyone started shooting at me then I died.  In my opinion, the interface lack some way to tell the player the remaining health and when the shield would be ready again (and even when it will fade off, because of the glowing it is very hard to know when to dodge the bullets.)

description:
The Grey Waste is a quick adventure of a madman in a bad place.
You'll need the XNA framework redist and .net framework 4 redist located:
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=17718
Also this game uses the hidef profile, so it needs a DX10 capable card.  That rules out netbooks and the like.
For tools I used quake army knife for the levels, my own build tools I posted before the jam based on genesis/q2, paint.net for the 2D stuff, sfxr for sounds, and raw hand typed in values for the moving 3D stuff.
Hope you enjoy it!  I barely got it done in time. :)
author: Kharza
title: The Grey Waste
comments: can i play this without a control pad?
Yes it works fine with a keyboard and mouse.  If you plug in a controller it assumes you'll use it though.

Nice! Very dark and moody. Kind of expected a light behind a fan somewhere... Also, I used up all of my spells before seeing any enemies, not knowing I had limited ammo. I just ran away from em though.
Haha seems like everyone does that :)  I wish I had more time.  I had 6 levels planned, but had to chop and rewrite the story (or lack thereof)
Super cool aesthetic! I love the creepy dark look and sounds :) I too ran out of ammo before encountering enemies.

I had some nive time trying this game, nice it is in 3D and ambince was great at start. Had graphic bug during next levels(several walls that did not appeared, XNA blue instead, but collisions worked). Could go throudh the whole game, not very original but nice effort for the overall rendering (sounds + ambiance + gameplay).
I'll not install anything to play a game...

I liked the visual style and the general atmosphere. It fits the theme very well. But the controls without a gamepad were quite unusual. I had to hold down the right mouse button to look around (?) Also, I had some bugs with collision that did not let me walk across some edges, but I could get across by jumping. Overall, nicely done!
rawbits:  Understandable!  I did an xna game last ludum dare as well, and it seemed so many more people were willing to play web games.  So much easier to just hit a link and play.
Lythom your bug sounds very scary haha.  My poor codebase is already so buggy but haven't seen that one.

Elusive, I had a small mouse I drew for the control screen but I'm not sure my little round circle over the button came across.  The button is "mmo style", and helps make windowed mode work a bit more smoothly.  I'll bet that caught out a lot of people, should have mentioned it in the post.
Hopefully for next time I'll have a better control library that will let people customize things.
I noticed that collision bug with the small ramp.  I'm going to be digging into that when I get vis working again.  It looks like it's hitting the extra axial leaf side.

description:
Click trees to chop them down. Once you've chopped enough trees, you can begin building wooden drones to do the work for you.
My original intent was to have wooden drones mine stone to build stone drones, and stone drones mine iron to help you build a ship to get off the island you were deserted on, but it didn't work out how I expected. Next time I'll know what to expect!
author: jordizzle
title: Untitled Tree Game
comments: Hehehe, its a weird kind of lil game, but the visuals are charming, and its fun to see your little robots doing their thing. They get stuck pretty easily though, dont they?
Haha, love the sprites!  I love these sorts of resource-feedback-loop style games...pity the stone/iron stuff didn't work out, but nice work on what's here!
Also...I do believe I will develop carpal tunnel from too much tree clicking now.  xD
Not sure how it relates to the theme but I liked the concept and it was fun even though the pathfinding is a little off. Graphics were pretty cool and I like the overall feel of the game!
The original story was gonna be you got stranded on an island, and you have to use your engineering knowledge to build drones to get you materials to build a ship to get back home :P

Despite the incomplete nature of the game, it's one of the ones I've njoyed the most. very nice graphics and sounds and the systems that are present are basically fun. I'd love to see this expanded further.

Problems with the game as is: Trees seem to often end up outside the viewable/clickable area, and tree planeters seem to often get stuck trying to plant a tree in the 'cave'. Also if you don't build a tree planter at first you can get yourself stuck without wood, which is a little annoying.
doesn't fully run under WINE, so I can't give it a proper rating (controls are iffy and sound does not work)

description:
A mighty obstacle obstructs your path, and you cannot possibly surpass it alone. Unfortunately, you can remain alone even when surrounded by others. With your newfound power to objectify, people may as well be stepping stones to you.
Use arrow keys for movement.
Pick up small red blocks by running into them.
Drop a held block by pressing 'down'
When things change, objectify by holding 'down' to charge ( when not holding a block). The beam will fire when fully charged.
This is my first Ludum Dare! How'd I do?
author: KevinZuhn
title: You Only Help Yourself
comments: I was stuck when I found the big red block....  Also the controls weren't the best, I hate that you can't just hold the direction you want to go and jump, when you hit something you stop and have to press the direction again.
After you find the big red block, turn around and go back. Things will be different, and you can shoot a beam by holding the down arrow. Sorry about the controls.
Yes, the jumping controls are annoying, but the rest is well done.  Unfortunately, I got a GameMaker error trying to "blockify" the left-most person from the left and I couldn't continue.

Gave up after I got a game maker error, when "blockifying" one of the starting characters. I think I triggered it because a few particles from the end of a beam hit one of the characters, then I hit him with a new beam while he was transforming.
Neat concept, very cute for your first LD. The controls are a pain though : /

Apart from the jump control problem, the game is a solid entry, I like the ambience of the intro, and the second part of the game is a good take on the theme. An ending sequence would have been nice, but maybe  I missed it ? I was expecting that the blocks I was  gaining by killing the citizens will let me reach a secret place near the entrance

Sorry about that gamemaker error. If you're interested in finishing or just poking around, you can hit 'z' to shift everybody to red without visiting the giant red block first. For some reason, I don't get the error when I use this method.
The ultimate goal is to build a way over the giant red block, and that's where the game ends.
I think with a bit of polish this would be a really sweet little game.

description:
Hello! I am 13 and this is my first venture into Ludum Dare. I went through a bunch of ideas and made like 2 half-finished games out of them before I finally focused in on one idea, giving me about a day and a half to work on it. I love the graphics but the rest of it isn't that great and I would like to some time to develop these ideas in the future. Anyways, to make the game I used Stencylworks for the programming, CFXR for the SFX and GIMP for the graphics. Here are the controls:
left, right, up, down=movement
z=jump
x=take
So, enjoy the game!
author: zorrtwice
title: The Sanctuary
comments: Woah! 13? You made a better game than many of the entries I saw. If I can give you some suggestions: the solid objects tend to get confused with the background and when I picked up the big head I went right and then disappeared. Nice job!
There's a certain sly humor in the "You made a friend" thing that I liked. Good pixel art, too- things were very distinguishable.

Thanks for the responses! Yah the walk off the right side is a glitch a lot of people found and I found it at like 901 so I couldn't edit it. To finish the game u have to go backwards anyways, so yeah. @jeck I was kinda going for that, like one of those badly translated NES games. I was going to put "(literally" after it but I ran out of room on the screen.

Not bad. Somewhat short but amusing. The engine seems to have some bugs, especially with the jumping, (and the running off the edge when you find the head thing) but everything looks pretty and I like how he "made a friend". That is worth at least a few extra points for humor.
The font you used was fairly difficult to read, due to its kerning; the letters were touching each other.
I was quite impressed with the attention to detail in the backgrounds, since it looks good and is quite substantial.
Not even one blog entry? No timelapse and all? Sad me :/
Nice little game. Though at the time when you had to jump up, I had a lot of problems even seeing the platform.
Controls were kinda quirky. He moved while jumping, but falling down was straight down. Weird.

description:
Being immortal is hard, people are always around making noise, living short meaningless lives.
You've had enough, kill everyone so you finally be alone.
You start out weak with few allies. You can pick up new special attacks the more you fight.
-Controls-
Arrow keys - Select attack/ Select mob
Space - Attack
author: Alone

downloads.Source: http://media.zensoftware.org/LD22/to be or not to be - alone.zip

title: To be or not to be
comments: Way too hard... Took me 12 tries, and i was only spamming the strongest special. Graphics are nice, but nothing is animated.
Too hard, failed many times before I won. Didn't progress enough to unlock other specials.
The 1d6+4 stats are a little heavy. I've played D&D so I get  where it's coming from, but something simpler to read or visualize would be nice.
Just a tad too difficult, otherwise very nice! :)
Agree with the above that it needs some balancing.
I give up! I can't win.

description:
To start the game double-click the .jar file.
You woke up, all alone in a deserted city...
...or maybe you're not alone after all...
ZOMG!! Zombies!!!!
My submission for my first Ludum Dare.
Satisfied with the result because this is my first Java project since 5 years, and pretty much my first serious java game ever.
Developed on osX so pretty sure it works for osX users.
Did little testing on windows and it did seem to work there as well.
Linux is untested. But hey, its Java, it should work right?
Controls:
Walk: Arrows
Shoot/Use: Space
Pickup: X
Menu/Cancel: ESC
(if you happen to have a working Logitech RumblePad or XBox360 Controller, those _should_ work as well...)
Well.
Thanks for this great event, I will definitely join the next one :D
(I sure hope GitHub is a good place to host the download & code?)

description:
Here is my first entry on the Ludum Dare
Zombie city is a small game where you must reach the exit of a quarantine city, your only goal is to reach the exit door but there are a lot of zombies to kill and dodge.
have fun!

Jump - Space

author: omarchapa
title: Zombie City
comments: Hahaha, I love them' breakdancing zombies. One of them was doing the worm!!

Yeah I have to say this game is very (maybe unintentionally) funny, with the zombies falling all over themselves. I couldn't really find where to go and I also couldn't figure out how to look around. I've had a similar issue with other Unity games though (on Mac in Firefox).
Those lego-zombies are cute, at least it's not another shoot-the-zombie game.

description: You just became a new TheCity resident. But why nobody else is there ? Discover TheCity hidden truth.
author: ncannasse
title: Welcome to TheCity
comments: My actual journal (default link seems broken)
- in case you get lost and want to reset the game, use "K"
very nice didnt fin but i like

I don't know how long I spent playing this.  I will be blunt: it was fairly boring after a few minutes.  But the snippets were enough to keep me going.  I beat the game.  Good job.  Very impressive considering the timeframe.  A few things that would have made the experience more enjoyable: mouse-controlled camera (looking off edges is cool, but not as cool as being able to get a better grasp of my surroundings), textures.  Of course, textures would have taken too much time I'm sure.

Really like this. The graphics are simple but really cool. The city is so vast and interesting. At first I feel a lit bit odd there's no mouse controlling camera. But then I found that you really did a great job to control the camera to look at the right direction.
Really cool, I'll try to finish this.

I just read your post and found that you wrote the engine by yourself. This is really cool. I'm always thinking about learning 3D and computer graphics but find it hard to start. Any suggestions for books and tutorials?
Some collisions/graphics bugs, and a little bit boring but I like the Idea ... and good job for the engine ! :O

This game truly is something, I wish I had more time to play and finish it, but alas, I only got as far as the second terminal, but I am definitley interested to play more.  The controls are a bit wonky, but the atmosphere really shines through, and the visual style is delightfully surreal and bleak.  Also, props on developing your own 3d engine, colour me impressed.
Very good and mood-y game :-). The collision is a bit flaky, but overall it feels good. It was a bit boring after a while, but i wanted to find more story parts :-P.
The 3D was very slow on my iMac though. I had to resize the window to something like 400x300 to make it playable :-/
Sadly, my computer hated this game. Couldn't play due to lag.
Very immersive game, but I'm afraid of not having enough courage nor time to restart from the beginnings and find "may"... Yes, because I found the definitive "exit" before. -_-;
Pretty good idea, good presentation and fits the theme well.
The only real problem is that it didn't keep me interested enough to stick with it after being told to find more terminals/stars.
Looks fascinating, but it runs at about 5fps on my laptop even when shrunk to postage stamp size, and warns me it needs 3D acceleration even though I have it enabled already :(

description:
you play the purple guy who is so deathly afraid of other people's company that it physically pains him. To stay alive he must make them leave. But he doesn't want to talk to them or touch them so he just throws stuff.
Keep the yellow guys out of your circle.
Throw items at boxes to break them.
controls:
Arrow Keys to move
Spacebar to pickup and throw items
author: intmain
title: Step Off
comments: Neat game, very funny, The aiming is rather difficult, but very cool game anyway
This game is interesting, well done! I like the connection between the LD's theme and your gameplay, very innovative.
Love the styling on this one. Surprised how tricky it was to get the aim right, not a flaw though.
Love it, the visuals are sooo cute and really polished. I agree with strkl in that the aiming is difficult, takes so long to spin into place! But other than that an amazing little game!
Fun game. cool atmosphere. Loving it despite the aforementioned difficulty in aiming.

Very good, i liked the comments that the yellow guys make :-). Aiming is a bit hard because i always expected the thing to be thrown *from* the arrow. I suppose putting the arrow behind the player would have been a better idea. Beyond that, the graphics are cute and the idea fits the theme nicely :-)

Really awesome game. I didn't have any problem with the aiming mechanic. I was able to WHOMP EM pretty good. Great use of theme as well. Rad art style, unique game mechanic, hilarious title, etc. THANKS FOR MAKING THIS!

Haha, if you want to see how your game would have looked if you were graphically unskilled with approximative mechanics you should check mine. That was a compliment, don't check mine. Your game is really cool, plenty of stars \o/
great little game, i love the controls
The game is very funny, graphics are cute, I hated the controls though
The collision detection seemed inaccurate at times.
I love it! Polished to shining, with a sound core concept that fits with the theme, topped off with cute and fitting graphics. Very well done.
Hahah I love this. Thought the aiming was great in my opinion, something different anyway!
Pretty interesting little shoot feature. I love the simplicity, though it did take me a few to figure out what was going on.
A good all-rounder for me, I had fun playing this one!
Really fun, great balance of all the categories, especially for the time-frame :) Clever idea overall!
i found it pretty difficult to aim, so ended up taking the items right up to the "enemies" to fire them off. very polished and a nice art style though.
I keep coming back to this. I just can't get over how polished it is for a 48-hour game- it's how any Ludum Dare game should be: a core of fun gameplay polished until it shines.
cool quick short game, interesting mechanic, a little bit hard to tell where the object is going to shoot out of you though because the arrow is beside you

Loved this game. The movement feels great, the text is funny and the gameplay mechanics are pretty simple. My only problems with it is the lack of a catchy tune and the feeling that the arrow is still moving even after pressing the throw button. Congrats!
Great idea for game mechanics but also quiet difficult. Maybe only spawning outside the circle would help.
Great little game. Wish it didn't take so long to get all 40 items though.
i like this one a lot

Cool game, the mechanics could use some work.  It really takes too long for the arrow to circle back around.  If that was faster then it would give more of a reflex element and less of a timing element which I think would fit this game better.
Great game. Cure graphics. Had a lot of fun with it.

Aiming was a little awkward at first, and it took some getting used to. For whatever reasons I think I keep expecting the projectiles to originate from the arrow rather than the character, so I instinctively use the arrow to judge throwing arcs. Maybe if you had a little arrow orbit around the character, rather than rotating beside him.
I really liked the item variety, good humour there. Throwing 'Australia' at someone got a laugh out of me.

I really like this take on the "Alone" theme.
I almost think it would be better if there wasn't an ending, and you were just doomed to sit there waiting forever...
Pretty good for something that was obviously just thrown together quickly.  Good job!

I have to agree. At first glance, this looks like it's one of the "oh god please don't make me play this" games, but... it does have it's own strange charm. After trying it out, I have to say it's certainly not bad.

This isn't what I'd call a finished game by any stretch of the imagination, but still... I did it :D
Plus, I learnt webgl and pixel art along the way, so can't complain.

description:
You wake up, not knowing where or who you are. You appear to be some kind of robot. It's apparent that you're in some kind of research facility. It's also apparent that all the researchers are dead, lying on the ground. But why?
I'd say "platformer/shooter" is the most fitting description of this game. Remember when playing, it's best to read all the notes, logs, and boards, as most of them either contain information about what happened, or real-world references.

description:
EDIT
some clarifications:
- You can (and probably should) walljump
- The little red things are mines. Destroying them will grant you some points. Beware the explosion
- No healthbar : The more red your square is, the more in trouble you are
Soooo this is my first LD48 attempt, but also my very first game! I wanted to make some games for a long time, but I have always been too lazy to do so. Until now. Also, I decided to try a new language for the occasion. You might notice that the title of the window is "hello world" :)
I used Flixel as a game engine,  bfxr.net for sounds assets, and http://videogamena.me/ to find a name.
My original design was :
- a survival game, based on scoring and combo
- PLENTY of ennemies
- melee fighting
- grabbing and juggling with enemies
- "wall jump" on knocked-up enemies
I quickly came with mouvements controls that I found really cool. I had enemies moving around (wall jumping and climbing) shortly after.
The I tried to implements combat mechanics. I intended to use the mouse for jungling with enemies and dashing toward them, but I forgot that you couldn't right clic with flash. And that mac users also cannot.
So I spend almost the entire first day trying to come with keyboard controls that felt right, but I couldn't. Shortly after midnight I gave up and changed my design to make it a shooting game. I had it working by the time I went to bed.
I spend the second day adding different type of enemies,  levels, scoring mechanism, sounds, a few visual effects (mostly to give feedback to the player), and a proper debug mode. I spend some time tweaking difficulty, and ended up with far less enemies than before (max is 5/6 right now)
I felt the game was finished almost 5 hours before the deadline, and even though I could have easily add sprites, a level editor and maybe an enemy editor, I was just too lazy to do so :)
For those of you who want to play with the debug mode, you can enable it by pressing SHIFT in the instruction screen. When debug mode is active, you can choose wich level you want to play by pressing 1-5 from this screen.
Enemies won't automaticly spawn in debug mode.
As it is my first game ever, I would love to get feedbacks from you guys. Also, don't forget to post your score!
author: PapyGaragos
title: Deadly Robot Spree
comments: First of all congratulations on your first LD48 attempt.  It was my first attempt as well.  I wrote down some first impressions as I played your game and I'm just going to give them verbatim.

It's good that enemies wall jump to show the player that they can do that as well.  I think introducing this earlier, or forcing the player to do it in order to complete some obstacle could have worked even better.  Teaching with gameplay is always better.
I like that when you die you still get to try the other levels.  Especially for a competition like this where we want to see as much of your content but may not have time to play the entire game.
I think it could benefit from dynamic difficulty, if you are finding it very easy, increase their health,
their fire rate, their spawn time.  And if its getting too hard modulate it a bit.  If one enemy seems to always beat the player, control how often they spawn.
Also let the enemies spawn from less predictable positions.
I always knew where they were coming from so there was little strategy involved.
Oh and the little red things, I thought they were mines, I still dont know whether to shoot them or collect them.
All in all a fine job, especially for a first attempt, I played the entire game and I look forward to playing your future Ludum Dare entries.  Possibly with sprites.
That said Alphaland is a pretty great game and it uses similar graphics.

description:
I made this game to go along with my Nether Six collection, so it's an arcade game that only uses the AXML keys, and has a simplistic graphic style. It's an HTML5 game made using a slightly modified version of my library CanvasLord (http://canvaslord.co.cc/).
Hold the key that corresponds to the location on screen that you want the crowd to move to. Try to avoid the gray circle as long as you can. It must remain alone. Pass through the outlined zones (circles) to get points quickly.
* How it relates to the theme: The gray circle is forever alone.
author: WITS
title: ALONE
comments: I love it. The controls are extreamly challenging and fun at the same time!
I really like it, but how does it answer to the theme?
The theme is alone, but that doesn't mean the player has to be the one who is alone. Your goal is to keep the gray circle alone as long as possible.
And thank you for the nice feedback everyone! :D
I don't see how this really fits with alone, but i LOVE the gameplay! It's just so new! I suck at it though...
@nate427 the little grey circle is forever alone :(
I like the style of controls. Nice idea.
This is great :) I feel really sad for the grey circle though...

The game itself is not bad, but I really do think that a lot more could be added, whether it's the graphical style or gameplay. I played it and got a half decent score, but I didn't have any fun. It's a really nice concept though, and could be expanded a lot more to make something good - the whole idea of trying to leave an object alone hasn't really occurred to anyone.

I agree with Nik, as there's somehow no real 'goal' except for getting points. Which gets hard quick because your group gets larger, and three lives are very unforgiving (it would be better making it dependent on the number of your circles). Also, better graphics like e.g. sheep and a wolf (+blood splatter) would have been nice

The graphics style is simply to keep it similar to the other Nether Six games (and to avoid showing my lack of spriting skills), and your group only gets larger if you don't fluently change direction. If you stop pressing any keys and then press another one, it counts as a freeze, because when you press another key the gray circle delays a little bit before following, and every five freezes another circle is added to your group. Otherwise, you could simply keep freezing, and the game wouldn't be challenging at all. So you can keep your group's size to four if you don't pause in between pressing keys. Considering that it's an arcade game, shouldn't the main goal simply be to get points? I suppose I could make a non-arcade version as a sequel or something...

I only died when I messed up and hit a key out of order. I don't think the graphics need to change, but I would like more of a progression, have it get harder as you go along, you know?
A very interesting idea, but connection to the theme... well, it would fit last LD's theme much, much better.

description:
My entry's about a Gravekeeper who enters a crypt one night after hearing stories about a treasure inside.
I worked on this for probably about 8-10 hours overall, and a good portion of that was swapping between ideas. I focused on the art first, then worked on the game itself. It's unfortunate that I couldn't have done much more in terms of gameplay, but at least it looks like I imagined! Unfortunately, there's no sound and it's rather short, but it was still a lot of fun making it. I didn't really have enough time, between sleep, going out for dinner, my Mom's birthday party, and Christmas shopping.
It's WAY too short, with not much gameplay, but whatever, 8 hours of work from the engine up, so, yeah.
Programmed in C++ using SFML2, all assets done in Paint.NET and I think I might've used GIMP at one point. The levels were made in Tiled to save time.
Source is available here: http://deljam.net/projects/grave_src.zip
..but I'm begging you not to look at it.

Slick platforming, nice graphics, but the lack of music/sound brought it down a bit and I didn't really feel very alone while playing it.

Yeah, unfortunately I had way less time than I thought I was going to have with this. It was originally supposed to be a puzzle-based platformer with a moody feel, with the lighting setup and all. It ended up being a quickly thrown together "game" with the only progression being the treasure and lackluster/very short escape sequence.

The movement is also very fun, just walking and jumping feels very right :)

Unfortunately, the gameplay doesn't hold up.  The lighthouse moves around, and I can make it go left or right, but nothing it does looks at all like "falling" or "bouncing."

I gotta give you high marks anyway, because I'm so impressed with the general feel of the thing.

description:
MazeExplorers is a maze game with a few twists. Your goal is to find the exit of the maze before your food runs out.
My goal regarding the theme was to use "alone" in the mechanic of the game, not necessarily in the "dressing" of the game. There are other explorers in the maze - each of them will give you some ability, but they will also eat your food (do you will have less time to complete the maze), and they will block your way (possibly taking you to dead ends).
So, is it better to try to solve the maze alone, or ask for their help? This is a crucial decision.
There are 5 mazes in the LD48 version of the game. Even if you beat a maze, you can still try to find the minimal path.
Also, there is a secret kitten mode ;-) Let me know if you find it.
This was my first entry to Ludum Dare, and it was quite fun!
Code is Java/Slick. Sound is sfxr and espeak. Sprites based on the openPixel project.
Make sure to check the time-lapse of the game being made: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0tpQZ1pjQKM
author: caranha
title: Maze Explorers
comments: I liked it, but not a whole lot to do with the theme!
Nice little game! At first I didn't think it was more than a simple maze solver, but the characters and their abilities really add a lot.

Awennor: Yeah, the idea was to have the theme link up with the decision, each maze, of having the characters join you or going alone. If I had time to write more levels, I would have explored this further.

Great little game and I loved your ideas for different types of help you can get from the various other people in the maze (although you're not exactly 'alone' when your game specifically involves teaming up with other people ;)). It was a bit of a annoyance that if I walked into a dead-end with a helper behind me I was stuck and couldn't walk back because they blocked the path so we had to both stand there and starve - I felt that's too stubborn on their part! Still, very good work overall.
cakemonitor: Well, I wanted to use "alone" more as a gameplay element, a choice, than as the central theme of the game. But I see your point. Thanks for the comment!

The "blocking your path" thing was a decision I made, that is why I added a key to quit the maze. But maybe it is indeed a bit too harsh, a lot of people are complaining about it. Maybe I should make the game auto-detect that you are stuck and game over you there.
D: That sucks... are you using OpenJDK? I couldn't get it to run with OpenJDK on my linux system, so I had to use Sun's Java. I'll look into it tomorrow and get back to you!
One question though: Is it normal for the white wizard to get you stuck in alleys?

I liked the basic idea for this one, but the "stuck" mechanic seems a bit unfair at times, as it doesn't really allow you to explore the maze freely.  It seems like you have to explore on your own for as far as you can until you die so that you can have a mental map of the maze.  This isn't necessarily bad, but at the same time I feel like it's a bit too unforgiving right now.
Simple, perhaps too simple... but, try the escape is fun...
The flame gays block me... it's normal...?

dr_soda, sempai, kiwi: Thanks for the comments. Yes, the "assistants" blocking your way was a design decision, and part of their balance. I see that I didn't manage to get this part very clear to most players. Oh well :-(
I like that the companions eat your food and block your path, makes being alone preferable so I think it is on theme. Also, good job balancing the difficulty, I like failing occasionally :)

I like this a lot. The helpers mechanic is a really great idea. I like the conflict that they introduce (they can help you, but they can also hurt you by blocking you in). It is a little too harsh to have to start over though.
Maybe you could choose to kill/abandon them if they get you stuck. You'd lose their special ability, but you could continue on with the game...
nice job! i like the idea of alone or with help+consequences. never played a maze like that before. the simple graphics/sounds fit well too. great first dare!
Although I have completed the 5 levels I couln't find the cat easter egg.

I got mixed feelings concerning the sound, in one hand the omnomnom sound helped with the humor, but the step sound was so annoying that made me turn the sound off, but anyway good job ^-^, and congratulations for your first participation =).

description:
PLEASE READ README BEFORE PLAYING
About
=====
LDKittenRL
Your friend has ventured into a cave without you and is lost and alone! It is
up to you to save him! Battle through hordes of 90s boy band members, people
who work in predatory industries, and other horrors of the deep!
Don't read any of the source files if you care about spoilers. This includes
the ./game file that runs the game.
Requirements
============
You'll need Ruby 1.9.3 and a terminal that supports colors.
Playing
=======
Navigate to the directory in your terminal and run
` ruby ./game `
without quotes. If you're a seasoned Ruby user, you may have a different
command for running Ruby files. Also, Linux/OS X users may simply
` chmod +x ./game `
` ./game `
This will give the file permission to be run, and the second command runs the
file.
Controls
========
y	-	Northwest
u	-	Northeast
h	-	West
j	-	North
k	-	South
l	-	East
b	-	Southwest
n	-	Southeast
>	-	Down stairs
<	-	Up stairs
U 	-	Use item, follow up with the key in your inventory
g	- 	Pick up item
.	-	Wait a turn
Tips
====
When you level up your unarmed damage and health go up. Try to avoid insurance
salesmen at early levels. They're pretty mean.
Good luck!

description:
The original idea behind the game is that it was supposed to look extremely generic - but have an extremely original concept. knowing that I'm among a lot of creative people in this jam, this probably has been done before. but Sense I didn't have the time or energy to flesh out the concept (and a lack of understanding of rapid prototyping) I just made the first level.
Even though this isn't my first game jam entry, its my first one that I've made in 3 days. I'm really excited that I got to do this and I'm glad that I had the encouragement.
You'll see that this game isn't well planned out and mainly focuses more on the aesthetic than actual game play (well it really depends on how you look at it.)
I hope you enjoy playing what little game there is to play :-).
The Music is a loop I made called "Loneliness" I made it specifically for this jam.

description:
Use the newgrounds link. Press UP next to beds and doors to go to the next level! Collect pills to not die. musical Notes are optional.
TIMELAPSE: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rAZlTgyMqYQ&feature=youtu.be
Take the role as Duke (or you???). You're a super fan of Davement, the famous '90s rock band! You've traveled back in time to 1990, but are now stuck and alone! Help Duke fight his anxiety disorder through many meds! Also help duke (OR YOURSELF?!??) take over Davement and become the new frontman, by writing their album ahead of time and beating up the members (via respectively collecting body-sized notes, and breaking into their houses!)
Hi, I'm Sean (seagaia) - this is my first Ludum Dare Entry, and actually my first game I've ever come sort of close to completing. For more, read the journal! All source is at my github. You can download the standalone .swfs from there - included are the .ptcop (pxtone notation files) for the songs if you're interested at all (though these, of course, are quite rushed :) ).
Enjoy!
author: seagaia
title: Enslaving Davement
comments: The time pressure and shaking screen made it a little too hard for my liking, but it's a solid little game.

Haha, love the story. I don't know if it made sense, but it made me grin. Well-behaved controls, challenging but not impossible, endearing low-fi graphics. My only complaint was the Q, Y, X, and P keys you mapped were far enough apart that I was constantly shifting my hand positions at the end of each level. I would tighten up the keys into a smaller cluster in the future. But good work otherwise!

Pretty cool. I liked the music and the art was pretty good, was well as all the shaking and particle effects. I admit I couldn't beat the first level though - is it actually possible to get to the top without death by anxiety?

@kato9: Yeah, all the levels should be possible to beat completely. I'll admit the game is a bit difficult and takes a bit to get used to, as some have pointed out - if I were to expand on this idea I'd have a tutorial or something so people knew the elements better (in contrast to the rambling instructions I give in the beginning). That or lighten up on the time constraints.
I dig the music... but the anxiety thing happens way too quick to be able to explore and get the notes. AND LOL AT THE CRAZY ASS STORYLINE!

cool music, game made not much sense. You shouldn't use a different key for every action. It was really annoying to have to press Y after dying to restart because it makes you reposition your hands on the keyboard every time. Put more time into planning, so things turn out better next time, congrats on finishing!
I agree with SonnyBone but the game seems very solid despite that.
Good job! Hope you keep participating in the upcoming challenges :P!
That was a very solid game for the time limit. The timer (and time rechargers) could certainly be a bit more spaced away.

While there's a little too much going on graphically this is a very complete game. My only advice would be to find an art style you like and stick with it until the end. Everything else is damn near perfect.
Solid mechanics and level design, oddly suiting music and sounds. The effects actually make me feel anxious and relieved at appropriate times without sacrificing the fun of the game as a whole.
cool but as with most couldnt get past level 1 :D
I hate this game so much.

Embracing my completionist side, I decided to collect every note in the game. I struggled against strict time limits and difficult jumps, avoiding the easy path that could be taken by ignoring notes. By the end I was yelling at my computer. After I finally finished I was rewarded with this: "You got 20/80 notes" FUUUUUUU...

Seriously though, this is a neat game. Both the graphics and audio are nice, especially the anxiety effects. The game is extremely challenging, but still fun, though I think the difficulty could be toned down a bit. And that ending notes glitch should be fixed.

x____x yeah I thought I uploaded a ending-fixed version a few weeks ago. Guess not. Updated it to add correctly and show the ending, which (IMO) isn't worth playing again for unless you're sadistic! (REally, it's not!!)

I'm working on a full version of the game. Rehaul some stuff - solidify the graphics style to be consistently crappy :P, fix the jumping glitch (betcha wished yall found that out earlier! You don't have to be on the ground to jump..ha!). Remapping keys. And of course expanding stages, making the story not confusing as hell, etc.

Difficulty in platformers needs to be handled in well-thought out ways (see VVVVVV, IWBTG), and I think that was your main weakness here.  Ignoring that, though, the graphics look pretty decent for an LD entry, and that background chip track is lovely.

description:
About
-------
Dead World is an adventure game with a twist - you play in a world made up of a mixture of the worlds of many other players. Every new area you explore is 'loaned' from the server, and when you die they are returned to the server with any changes you make.
How to Play
-----------
WASD or Arrow Keys: Move
E: Pickup/Putdown
SPACE: Attack
For more help see: http://tombstone.gnomelogic.com:42000/help.html
IMPORTANT: Buildings _must_ be constructed in one of the 4 corners of the map!
Credits
-------
Code: Finn Stokes, Saxon Douglass
Graphics: Rory Stokes
Sound: Jaime von Schwarzburgg, Joshua Douglass-Molloy
author: Saxon Douglass
title: Dead World
comments: Strong start! I was immediately impressed by the overall looks. The server architecture sounds impressive, though I couldn't verify whether it worked. Neat environments, and endearing art style for characters/creatures. The two tracks were fun to listen to, but then it was just silent.
I wasn't able to do anything besides explore, even after trying to arrange items according to the help file. (Did I use the wrong items, I wonder?) The game has promise!

@dcfedor: I've just realised now we never say that you must put buildings in one of the four corners of the map. I have added that to the How to Play section, thanks for playing and giving great feedback!

Yeah, that was a bit of an oversight on our part. We could have done a much better job with the documentation. The music not continuing after the second track is a known bug that we were unable to fix. It also affects some of the sound effects.
To be clear, that's in the 5x5 square of the corner, so there'll be a gap down the side of thinner buildings
Man, the sound was the best part of the game...
I like this game, I just can't figure out how or what I can make with the buildings. Is confusing.
Very clever idea with the server syncing. The two music tracks were hilarious! Well done!
When i try to play the game I have nothing bu a black screen, anything I should know?
I was giggling at the music while I was trying to figure out what I could do.
I couldn't attack or pick up anything. Neat concept though- it reminded me a bit of Zelda.
@bobboy555: My first suspicion is that your web browser isn't supported. The other option is that the resources aren't being loaded but I can't imagine why that would only happen to some people.

@easlern: Pickup/putdown is E and attack (no attack animation but does kill monsters) is SPACE. To pick something up you must be standing on it, and the attack range is quite short so you need to be almost touching for it to hit the enemy.
I only see a black screen and a "HELP" on the top right corner. There seems to be audio, nothing else though.

description:
[Oh wow, I just discovered that the sounds hurt with headphones.  Take them off or something.  (They're replaced in the post-competition version.)]
So, you're cursed or something, so that everyone who comes near you dies (and turns to stone or something).
It should be fairly obvious that when one of the other person-things moves inside the big red circle around the character you control, they end up as a solid immoveable block.  By being careful about where this happens, you can reach other areas.
Controls:
arrow keys, WASD: move.
R: reset the level.
enter, space: advance text.
[in post-competition version] escape, backspace: pause/unpause.
WASD works for other keyboard layouts too: QWERTZ, AZERTY, Dvorak, Colemak.
To quit, close the window.
Website: http://ikn.org.uk/Can%27t_Even_Apologise
author: J
title: Can't Even Apologise
comments: I couldn't get passed the second room. I tried jumping that thing but without succes.
The second one?  Really?  You just go near the whatever-it-is to freeze it, then jump on it and then onto the next ledge, and repeat for the next one.
The jumping sounds make my laptop speakers sound like they're popping and scratching, had to stop after the third screen.
I really liked this one. I liked the music, but the rest of the sound kinda made my ears bleed. But aside from that, really good job.
Heh, thanks.  I guess I should've tested the sounds on non-cheap speakers at some point...  I'll find something to replace them with in the updated version.

I played the compo and post-compo version. I couldn't get through the first cave (that is, 4th screen?). I also had to adjust my laptop brightness as at the beginning of this level I didn't see anything :). Nice concept, overall. Good work!

Yeah, it gets pretty hard from then on - I didn't really have enough ideas for level mechanics, so I ended up with some easy levels and some hard ones, and none in the middle.  I might put up a video with solutions at some point for anyone interested.
That was a lot of fun.  Liked the art style and sound work.  Neat little concept that was very new to me and very enjoyable.
Why are Python developers so against creating binaries? I do not have pygame installed.
The Windows one is a binary; if you're not using Windows, you probably have a package manager with Pygame in it, making installation really easy.

description:
Little space exploration game. Click around to travel with your spaceship and find out if we are alone in the universe!
I didn't manage to put a game over screen in, if you find yourself stranded then you need to restart the game!

title: Are We Alone?
comments: It was interesting until I realized that my screen res was too small to play it :(
I haven't finished this game yet but I'm really enjoying it :)

exploration + ressource-gathering is fun, and the "this guy died of dyssentry"-vibe is fun. Reminds me positively of  "Infinite Adventures" / "Flotilla" / what do you call this genre" - games.

description:
Concept:
"You're in a box, which you escape from by destroying the walls. Completing a level creates a copy of yourself with your current stats, a Shadow Link, that follows you to all future levels. Unfortunately, he dislikes how you smell and wants you to go away. Being unable to speak, his only way of expressing his feelings is to shoot you in the face."
Controls:
WASD - Movement.
Mouse - Aim and shoot.
E - Swap through weapons.
R - Deletes your local save file (to start a new game).
Tools:
AS3/Flash/Flixel @ FlashDevelop (code).
Paint.NET (art).
Musagi (music).
Rant:
2nd Ludum Dare finished. Woot. ^__^ Yay for Flixel. After spending the last 3 hours of the Dare attempting to compose music, I was reminded how terrible I am with it and ended up keeping the music from my first day build--parts of which are drum samples from DrPetter, if it sounds a bit familiar. All in all, this LD was another ridiculously awesome, fun, and enlightening experience.
Attached background mp3 to go with the screen shots: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/43348544/bgbeat.mp3
Hope you guys enjoy the final product as much as I enjoyed making it. Cheers! :D
edit: The updated post compo version is not meant to be judged! It was worked on for ~a week after the Dare finished as I continued developing the game for funsies and uses music from my actually musically talented friends. Posted in case you enjoyed the original and wanted to see what happens if you leave a kid with lots of awesome feedback.
author: Aaron
title: Alone With Myself in a Box
comments: Nice game, but it became extremely difficult after level 2, because I was always almost dead before I could figure out which of the 4 sprites was me.
That's something I didn't notice after hours of playing it until just so use to the starting positions/subtle color differences. Thanks for the feedback, Wiering! :)
I had a lot of fun playing this but past level three I wasn't able to even kill one of my past selves before dying.
The graphics and musc were great, but it would help a lot of there was some marker indicating which of the sprites you're controlling (just the bullet color isn't enough)

qrunchmonkey, I'm glad you liked it! To my knowledge, the all time high level score isn't much better, lol. In restrospect, I definitely agree with you that a marker (perhaps different/more bold outline color) would have really helped.
The game is really cool (one of the funniest I've played), but I think it doesn't suit the theme very well. Great job btw!
I like the basic idea, but why do you get money for destroying a wall?

tcstyle, thanks :) I wanted to reward players for interacting with everything, so I added that incentive to promote destroying stuff. It's not very obvious, but taking out walls while there are still clones shooting at you also rewards more score and money.
Great work; High marks across the board.
It gets pretty tough pretty quickly (level 4 was crazy), but it is action RPG progression based gameplay at its purest.
It is a great example of why Ludum Dare is so awesome, filled with enjoyable yet minimalist gameplay, loaded with brilliant industry related humor, and some rockin' tunes.
Definitely one of the better games I've stumbled across so far; Give yourself a cookie.
Good little game - if you just made char's sprite little different :/ I gave up in fourth or so level, because I was usually dead before I found out which sprite is me...
nice music and graphics. It would add fun if you could hide behind obstacles, it would also make the game easier ! More fx on shot, hit and impact would be great !
Thanks for the feedback, guys! I really appreciate it. I'm continuing to fix the game up on the side, and all the feedback's helping tons. :)
Yes,  after level 3 or so the games becomes completely unplayable due to difficulty.
This one of the best games I've seen thus far!
I loved the fact that there was even a tutorial level.
The whole scene + sounds created a very agreeable mood. Congratulations. Hope you get a good final score!
PS- We also used flixel in our entry game but we had a lot of trouble with it. Glad to see that it worked for you!

I like the upgrade system and the idea is pretty unique, try to defeat yourself - although it's pretty difficult to tell which player apart. The gfx and bgm are nice. If I can suggest, adjust the difficulty down a bit because it's very hard - like others said. Great game. :)

description:
Alone in the war is an unfinished game developed for LD22 Jam. It is a strategy game where your decisions will increase your economy or decrease your worker's happiness.
We cannot finish the game and it's still in development. There aren't enemies and loose condition it's difficult to reach. It's a kind of sandbox for our micro-engine developed for this compo.
"Enjoy" it if you can and thanks for reviewing it.
Post-mortem post: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/12/22/post-mortem-alone-in-the-war/
Executable: http://dl.dropbox.com/u/2427705/ld22.zip
Source code: https://github.com/ultrayoshi/ld22
Game developed by @ultrayoshi and @ReikVal
Special thanks to Sory and Rul.
author: ReikVal
title: Alone in the War
comments: The postmorten tomorrow in ultrayoshi's journal.

Thank you for testing the game :). We didn't have enough time for including a in-game tutorial or some tips, I apologize for that. We write a post-mortem (http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/12/22/post-mortem-alone-in-the-war/) explaining our experience.
This is our first LD, we need more experience. Thanks for your comment!
Cool game, but as Iforce said: Tutorial on how to play?
Needs instructions, could have used a lot more work.
I don't know what I'm supposed to do. Instructions please :)

It seems you guys created a nice engine of features, but unfortunately spent too much time working on building an engine from scratch. The game shows lots of promise though, and I definitely would like to see what it could be if you guys continued working on it (if just to add instructions, as others have mentioned).

description:
We had a game concept, was never able to implement it, and simply ran out of time. Barely got to working on the actual levels. So, enjoy walking, running, jumping, and moving onto another game.
Controls
A = Left
D = Right
Ctrl + Direction = Run
Space Bar = Jump
author: Goodlookinguy
title: Alone In The Office
comments: Well don't get discouraged, just give things another go. What you have here really is a nice start though. Out of curiosity, what was your game concept?

THIS IS SO UNINTENTIONALLY HILARIOUS! The poster... the non functional title screen... the one room walk-a-thon... and then BOOM. Sucks that you didn't get to finish but this really brightened up my night. Thanks!
Good thing you delivered anyway! Good  sign of perserverance, and you get points for humor.
I would love to see this game finished :D

description:
Help Time Kitten save the universe!  A cute-em-up that you control with the mouse.
This is my first jam game for Ludum Dare.  It was kind of nice, having more time, but unfortunately that was offset by my inability to devote completely all of my time towards LD.
So it kinda balanced out.  However, I think Stitch is perhaps my most polished LD entry as of yet in terms of gameplay.
But that came at the cost of content.  Level one is complete but that's it.  However, don't fear, I will working on the other three levels in a post-compo edition -- including the animated intro/ending that I had to cut.
Note there are two bugs:
* "Fishbones collected" stat is not properly keeping track of the number of fish bones you acquire in a level.
* The game plays a bit too fast -- I tuned everything when I was in a debug SWF inside the debug Flash player.  So level 1 is a bit harder than I intended it to be.
author: ChainedLupine
title: A Stitch in Time
comments: It looks nicely polished and music is very good, but... man, the difficulty is really on the level almost unplayable... I somehow finished the level on my first attempt with 1 life remaining and F result. Since no new levels opened, I thought I need to have better result and give it several other tries... never made it to the last boss :)

With the exception of insane dificulty nice entry, but connection to the theme is non existent :) "Alone" is here even less then in other games i've tried (including mine, which too has kittens.... zombie brain eating ones, but cute ;)

Yeah, I was amazed at the difference between the debug version and the release;  At least a good %20 speed difference, which was enough to make some of the enemies incredibly difficult.  (Especially the ones that fire the little red bullets!)
The other levels BTW, are perma-locked, as I didn't finish them in time.  But I am working on a post-compo edition that'll put them in and address the difficulty issues.
Very impressive; It's a shame that the game is so damned hard, but seeing as there is only one level anyway it doesn't matter.
As far as shooters go, there wasn't much out of the ordinary here, but what was here was well polished, charming, and very well done. (fantastic chip tunes btw)

In future, you may want to regulate your movement with a timing multiplier to prevent this speed up. (multiply every movement calculation by a float that is initially set to 1f, that way if this happens you can just set the multiplier to 0.8f or whatever to get the desired result)
Well done; I gave it fairly high marks across the board.

description: A Lone Kitty, created using Ethanon Engine and Angelscript. Possibly some of the sloppy-est code I've ever written. The game quits automatically after entering the portal at the end game. This is not a crash or a bug, but a call to an Exit function. Source is included in the Dropbox download.
author: Thomas
title: A Lone Kitty
comments: The graphics were good and I liked the lighting effect, it adds a lot to the mood. My only complaint is that the gameplay got slightly dull after a while.
Love the graphics. Not too exciting gameplay, though.
The lighting is great, but the gameplay does get a bit stale. Also... my i7 works like CRAZY while running this game for some reason.
Palyed to the end. Very nice. I found that the glasses of milk increased the light radius, but the increase was so tiny that in the end I didn't bother to take them. Good work!
Played to the end. Very nice. I found that the glasses of milk increased the light radius, but the increase was so tiny that in the end I didn't bother to take them. Good work!

I agree with others: the graphics are great, but the gameplay gets dull after a short while.  If there was some kind of music or sound effects, I think the mood would be vastly improved in this game.  Nice work.

Thanks for all the comments, I aimed for something simple. Maybe, on reflection, far too simple. But thanks to the comments I've got a few ideas on how to improve things, if the game ever makes a full release.

description:
You like to be alone, but this bodyguard won't let you breathe... Escape and enjoy your quiet moments.
(Still a few bugs to kill and an alternate end to code, but here you go, the release version)
title: /follow
comments: Really well done! The art was terrific, the music was great and it was a lot of fun to play.
Wooohoo! Great game :) It was fun to see you working near us this weekend! We will have to gather again for next LD ^^
Really really liked the artwork and the music. The characters look superb, and the animations are really nice. It's got a fairly brutal darkness to it that I like stylistically.

In terms of fun, it wasn't really my kind of thing. I found myself just clicking on things until something happened, and I felt it took a while for everything to respond, especially given that you have to wait for the woman to walk up to an object before she'll interact with it.
Not my cup of tea in terms of gameplay, but the audio and visuals are a treat :)
Wow, this was really great. The artwork was great!

Very nicely done! The graphics were phenomenal, and I found the puzzles and other gameplay to be pretty engaging. The story went from being kind of light-hearted to being really dark by the end - which felt a bit strange, but overall this is probably the best entry I've played yet. Great job!
The art and music are really fantastic, some of the best I've seen so far.
The gameplay and plot seem pretty redundant after a couple levels, it could have used a bit more depth and variation.
I had some fun playing this game, well done !
Just a question, not about the game, but... Why 109 ?
I'm browsing the game list and i'm very happy to found this gem, great execution, graphics and music!! a very solid entry!!
Enjoyed it greatly, but was surprised that my expectations were subverted. I expected a more grim ending for our protagonist. Regardless, good job!
Huge thanks to all of you who played it! :)
Currently finishing an "enhanced" version with the alternate ending and a few corrections.
@LeReveur: 109 = m in the ASCII table. Why m? Secret ;)
Congratulations! I have nothing else to add. For me it's perfect.
That game is sooo nice and the music is great ! Fits the theme perfectly and the game mechanics are good, congrats!
Thanks everyone! I just added the enhanced version with the alternate ending, the credits and a few tweaks.
Ok. This is just the greatest game I've played so far. Congratulations to all of you, it's amazing!
This game is so polished, I liked the  scrolling 'boss battle' mechanic, mixed with the point and click adventure style.  I really enjoyed it.  Nice work!
This is lovely. Graphics are cool, and the music works very well. I love it.
isn't there an app game with the same style?
@Noud: I guess you're talking about Sword & Sorcery EP, by Superbrothers. Yes it was the main inspiration for the art :)
S&S:EP and Skyrim theft hack. Companion cube and Scarface.
Very well-executed point-and-clicker, a real nice modern throwback to the halcyon days gone by.
Wonderful characters, very charming. Had this been a compo entry it would have cleaned up for sure.
noone finds the Cloud's sword from FF7 ? There is also 2 matÃ©rias :p
Not a fan of this type of gameplay, but both the graphics and the score were gorgeous. Bon boulot les gars :)
And it fits in a header, totally reusable on a web site :D
Reminds me a bit of mcpixel, but with a bodyguard instead of bombs. Not at all bad.
A little more situational variety/plot development would have been nice.
Agreed! we get totally noobed by the time limit, we'll do better next time :) I promise :p
Lovely graphics, albeit a bit heavy on the superbrothers inspiration! Sticking non letter characters at the front of your game name to get to the front of the listing?! ;)
For sure SuperBrother was my main inspiration (i am really fan) and it is very fast to produce.
You can also find another inspirations like Skyrim, final fantasy, Portal in this compo.
And no, we did not name this game like that to get first of the list (it change every day), at the begining we were at the end :)
The truth about "/follow" : this name is a reference to the main MMORPG command to follow another character.
Nice, the art style is great, Reminds a lot of Sword and sworcery ^^
At some point I just started to click everywhere like a crazy... But I managed to finish the game.
Excellent in almost all cathegories (short and simple gameplay, but otherwise... excellent I say :)
Very well done! I found it very fun to play, and it was a very nice take on the theme.
MIND BLOWING. Great use of theme and the music fits the mood so well. Graphics make me jealous, which means AWESOME!

description:
"Journey to Polygonia" is the story of a lone triangle, Geometri, whom, when stranded in Dodecaen territory, must bravely journey home to his friends, Spheri and Quadra.  During his journey home, he must avoid the dangerous minions of the tyrant King Dodeca,  the Vertizez.  Along the way, Geometri must steal the dimensional shadow crystals to sap Dodeca of his power, end the tyrant's reign, and restore Quadra, the true heir, to the throne.
Note: Didn't finish building any levels beyond the Hexagian Caves.
AUDIO STOPS AFTER 10 MINUTES DUE TO HTML5 LIMITATIONS. Sorry.
author: sythe
title: .Journey to Polygonia
comments: Wave after wave of the same, with glitchy physics and sporadic music.

+props for not flash or unity in web. A few points of disinterest for me were the physics, they feel really floatey and slidey. Maybe it was the 2 or 3 days of super meat boy, I dunno. The enemies also feel rather shallow, like the whole level is just goombas. The last point is getting killed had almost no distinction from bouncing off of an enemy.
I do like the artwork, simple as it may be. The font is awesome, and the level gives off a vibe of "where am I?"
This was a really neat, relaxing play. Very Zen as an experience. I liked the music a lot.
I felt like I had the most fun when I just barreled through levels without stopping or looking when I was going.

Sometimes the collision detection near the edges of floors seemed a little glitchy. Like if I stomped down on one of the "falling" floors I'd sometimes drop through it briefly, and more than once the "exiting level" animation had me sliding through a floor or through a wall. Also when I reached what I think was the end of the game, the entire game area just disappeared and all I could see was the page background as if the game weren't being displayed at all. The audio continued. Is this correct or a bug?
This is a really great use of HTML5. I love the "maps" in the source code.

The engine is indeed quite glitchy, and the presentation doesn't quite grasp the theme. I really like that you can stomp enemies while dying, it's a neat touch! Also what is there is mostly quite solid.
Physics bugged me, but it certainly seemed lonesome.
Quite fun, I kinda like it but the controls feel a little awkward and the sound is annoying. I can't get very far because I keep sliding off the edge of platforms :/
This was fun, the scrolling was silky smooth and the hit detection was spot on.
If only the physics... blah blah blah... because I was enjoying it until I had to rage quit in just the 3rd level...
Still, I gave this fairly high marks as it is very well made and a lot of fun when you get on a streak of not dying every 20 seconds. :)

i liked the slide physics, just charging through levels was a lot of fun. the physics and collisions obviously need some polish i guess but who cares, you have a cool little atmospheric game here and i also respect your use of geometry. nice entry
Not bad.  I like the music, I like the triangle's little moving feet.  I like your slighly random level design.
Once the game got hard it stopped being fun.  The controls are too floaty for the game to work as a challenging platformer.

HTML5 Browser Reqd (Tested with Chrome)

author: ned366
title: The Race Home
comments: Very nice game indeed - simple and highly playable. Great fun, mood and graphics. Shame on the [or lack of] audio. Still, a great game nonetheless!
For the record - haven't finished it quite yet :)
Great game, Amazing Idea, Awesome graphics. Really liked this one! Great work!
Nice Entry. would have been amazing with sound.
Cool and simple idea :D Good job!

Very difficult! Or maybe I'm just bad at it. I liked the graphics quite a bit. The gameplay was pretty repetitive, though I liked the challenge of juggling the gun and the cart, making progress while keeping zombies at bay. The threat of being alone made it fit well with the theme.
Beautiful work. The art style and parallax look great, and the minecart + shooter combo is challenging. (Love the swinging arm anim for Molly sprite!)
Control scheme was a bit rough on the fingers (A,D,R,O,P hard to reach all at once), but solid game overall.
Very funny game! Very scarry too. I would have prefered S for the reload button.
That is one tough game. Kinda cruel with that reloading, and you can't jump. You can't even regenerate health. Cruel cruel game. That reloading was a pain.
The controls overall were a pain. It just felt unnatural with that layout.
I like the graphics, good job on that. Also theme was done okay.

description:
A LOT OF PEOPLE ARE ASKING WHY THEY RANDOMLY DIE. They don't, read the instructions before playing! (below and in readme).
Created in C++ with Ogre3d engine with SdkTrays GUI with my own gui images. Please, don't be afraid to rate just because it's not very good (it's my first ever game, any thoughts are appreciated)!
The Lonely Gun - you control a character ( = cube) that has a gun that makes anyone it hits lonely, meaning whenever you hit an enemy with it, every enemy *except* the one you hit disappears!
A and D to move, space to fire, right mouse button to move camera. Further instructions are in README. To run the game, look in /bin for LonelyGun.exe.
INSTRUCTIONS:
a and d to move, space to fire, right click to move camera (only if you have to, it is probably better not to).
The weapon you have is the "Lonely Weapon" - anyone it hits is immediately lonely, meaning every enemy except the person you hit
disappears. Enemies will spawn randomly every ~1 second (depending on what I change it to and forget to change the readme), and you need to stop them from getting past you bearing in mind the lonely weapon.
You have 100 health. Each enemy takes 30 health if it goes past not (not if it hits you). If you didn't know, you are the blue cube
and the enemies are the red cubes. Score is how long you survived, in seconds.
TIP: Wait for the ones at the back to span to remove all of them and give you the most time afterwards. Hitting the nearest one may make it impossible to save yourself from
being hit,
ABOUT
Why is it in 3D? I have no experience with any 2d engines. Don't ask me why I decided to start with this one (Ogre3d), but this is my first game in C++ :D It was planned to
be a lot more developed, but I completely underestimated how bad I was at C++, having only been using it about an hour a week for a few months.

description:
Well, we worked until the last few minutes to get this done. It's a short but sweet game and I think we're mostly happy with how it turned out.
Divided is a short puzzle platformer with 11 levels for you to enjoy. You play as a character named Ink, working as you try to escape each room and remove him from the clutches of the mysterious "other person" he talks about.
You control both Ink and his shadow at the same time, so you'll have to get creative to solve some of the puzzles you'll come across. Keep in mind that the placement of your character means everything in this game.
There's bound to be some glitches as there are with most of the games here. To remedy any glitches in the game, we have a reset button for each level.
Here are the controls:
Right and Left: Move
Up: Enter Doors
Space: Jump
Enter: Select
R: Reset Level
Note: This game also supports gamepads!
We hope that you enjoy our game, we worked pretty hard on it and hope you have as much fun with it as we did making it!
[Edit] - If the game crashes for you, try the "Windows - Minimal" version.  The minimal version doesn't load all of the level text overlay pictures at once.

description:
"Adventures of One"
http://www.gavpugh.com/ludumdare/ld22/WebPlayer.html
by Gavin Pugh (Drebin on WordPress).
Tools:
- 'Engine' is Unity. Used Visual Studio 2010 to edit the C# code.
- Art in Paint Shop Pro 7
- Sfx generated from the 'Bfxr' website
- Music generated by 'cgMusic'. Then midi to mp3 via http://solmire.com/
Summary:
A turn-based tactical RPG. In a similar vein to the "Shining Force" series of games. Unlike those however, "Adventures of One" consists of just a single member of the heroic force. This lone adventurer has to wipe out a series of battlegrounds of it's demonic spawn. Progressing through each battle unlocks harder enemies, more equipment in the shop, and fancy magic spells.
The terrain layout, and placement of enemies are procedurally generated.
"Adventures of One" has a guest voice-over provided by "The Room"'s Juliette Danielle.
Postmortem, time-lapse, and journal log here:
http://www.gavpugh.com/2011/12/21/ludum-dare-22-postmortem-journal-and-timelapse/
author: Drebin
title: Adventures of One
comments: I'm impressed with the scope of this one, even if it is derivative, pulling off a tactical RPG in 2 days is nothing to sneeze at, but it seemed like it was impossible to make even a dent in the monster forces unless you just grind your way through.  Music is actually pretty good, and I didn't see Lisa coming at all.  It probably wasn't a priority, but the art is very rough, it seems you might have been better served with more simplistic or impressionistic art.
Great start, and obviously a lot of work went into it. I probably just suck, but I died pretty quickly - too many monsters against me.
Your textures would look a lot better if you set them to point/clamp. Bilinear filtering makes them look blurry.
I really like this one, great work! My fave game from this event so far :-)
The game took pretty long in loading...any idea why? don't put in too much that won't be used.
also, when you add a voiceover by a different person to your game, i think you're disqualifying yourself for the 48hour compo. two persons -> jam entry.
It's the music that took up most of the space. (the total size is ~16mb, it drops to about ~1mb without the music). There's six tracks in all.
The voiceover stuff is fine, it's noted in the 'special competition exemptions':
"Photos and recordings you make of people or things are acceptable content, just you must acquire them during the competition."

description:
A little Matlab-esque shooter. I guess it is vaguely to do with the theme since you're alone ... with a ghost ... in space.  Also, there's a kitten!
The game uses hand-written Javascript/HTML5 and isn't obfuscated and doesn't rely on any third party libraries. You can view-source on the HTML document and it should be fairly obvious where the code is. The graphics were generated using a project I wrote a while ago, BatchSVG (Google it if you're interested) and just straight rendering of Javascript primitives. Sounds using SFXR.
In hindsight, a game using similar mechanics, but on a simulated mini-golf course would have been both a better fit for the theme (alone: no enemies) and probably a better game. Ah well, if there's enough interest in this I might look into it.
author: madmaw
title: Space Ghost
comments: Love the idea. This would be perfect as an educational game for a raspberry pi (http://www.raspberrypi.org/sample-page)
This would be more fun if I knew math!  But it's a really cool concept.  Backspace ruins syntax though...
Amazing idea! Wish I knew math better. But I don't really see how it's connected to the theme... Well done!

Thanks for the comments guys. I'm trying to think of a way for the game to teach the basic shapes of different equations to the player, maybe through some kind of extended tutorial or function builder (operators are power-ups?). It would be good to make an educational game that didn't suck
This is an awesome idea!  It reminds me of the gif that shows what sin(t) looks like and how it relates to a circle (http://js.2x.io/trig-paperjs.html)
Visual stuff like that makes it much easier to grasp what's going on behind the numbers.

The only frustrating I encountered was.. I wish it was more of a text box interface and not a command line.  The command line made it difficult to try different things, swap out components and keep another, copy and paste, etc.
Other than that, overall a great game!
Great idea :) Good game for mathematicians and programmers, but right now I'm too tired to play it to the end :) (but going to bookmark)
(For the idea alone best overall / innovation rating I gave today :)
Uhh...well I'll admit I really didn't understand this at all. I tried typing in the equations you listed at the bottom of the page and nothing happened.

A good idea for an educational game. The graphics were absolutely appropriate, especially the screen flicker for some reason. The theme didn't fit so much, but only because of how the game is shown, not because there is only one 'character'. Good job.
Innovative idea, but quite unintuitive to control.

If you run out of space, try typing CLR followed by the enter key, that will clear the screen. There are some examples of what it expects if you look at the help, or scroll down on the page.
I was going for an old telnet style interface, but yeah a simple HTML textarea would have been easier to use and quicker to implement.

YES! MATH! This game was really innovative, and I enjoyed it quite a lot since math is the best thing ever. I would like it if you could repeat levels (or choose not to advance to the next one), because I wanted to figure out lots of formulas for each one.
Although, the fact that you could define piecewise functions through tables or the ternary operator made it easier (although I didn't use this solution 'cuz it's not fun):

that lavel part is hard :(. Very cool game. I wasn't able to beat it. (and then an error screen appeared)
I like the simplicity of your game. I think you set your mind on doing something and you achieved, congratulations.
It was fun to play at first, but then the level with the rising lava where you had to jump through the small spaces was impossible just because I couldn't get to those spaces.

description:
My first actual game. Written in Python with pygame.
To launch it on Windows launch file named "glow.exe" and to launch it on Unix-like launch file named "glow".
To launch it on Windows you don't have to install anything else.
