Nice mood here. The thoughts add a lot to what is otherwise a simple game. Good work!
I liked the atmosphere of the game particularly, that music is great.
Points for mood, audio, and graphics. The game was kind of fun until there were so many crowds I couldn't walk 32 pixels.
Where is the source code? Source is required for a 48 hour entry... If you don't want to release the source maybe switch it to a jam entry?
That said I like the mood and feel a lot. It starts to get a little frustrating when the difficulty ramps up but over all a pretty neat idea that fits very well with the theme.
This was interesting and ambitious, I'll say that. The visual style was super cool.

The problems I had with this mostly seemed like byproducts of the 48 hour deadline. A lot of stuff seemed haphazard-- I felt like there was a lot of text and I didn't really get to read any of it, I had to keep my eye on the character at all times so I couldn't look at the bottom of the screen. Except for a couple levels where I got swarmed right at the beginning and there was a bit of strategy in quickly locating an "empty" area, there didn't seem to be much happening, it was basically run dodging yellow things until you get the sound effect saying you can go on. (Since the crowds couldn't hurt you the "now go for the exit" bit, though it looked cool, seemed unnecessary). It was frustrating to not be sure either how close you had to get to a yellow dot to start losing memory, or what it is you even do that causes you to hit the "no need to remember" lose condition. The actual moment-to-moment process of dodging yellow dots was quite fun but since it was the only mechanic it got repetitive kinda quick. It was fun while it lasted tho
nice man. didnt hook me though
Thanks for the comments, everyone!  They're very helpful.
Sorry about the source code.  I left out an 'http' in the field when I submitted, so it didn't show up at the top.
Music is awesome. Graphics style is awesome. Mood is awesome. This game is awesome.

description:
You are Subject Six, and you awake in a tube in the Blue Moon laboratory.
You don't really know much other than that. Oh, and you can power things with your life. And, as can be predicted, you're all alone.
Instructions are in the game but if they prove a little vague, here's the list:
Left/Right - Move left or right
Up/Down - Transfer power up into yourself or down into devices
X - Jump
C - Use terminals and transit devices
This game is kind of a sibling game to my LD21 entry, Aphelion Incident. The setting is the same, but the mechanics aren't. Enjoy! I'd ramble on more like I did for previous LDs but I don't have as many excuses to make as usual :D
author: Cirrial
title: Blue Moon
comments: This is a fantastic job! I really enjoyed playing it! The primary mechanic of the game is really innovative - I think it's a downside when you turn the generator on the rest of the game is trivialised. To have come up with the artwork, mechanic and smooth implementation within the 48 hours is really impressive :-)!
I really liked your game, good job.
Very nice indeed. The style reminds me a bit of Another World, which is definitely a good thing. :)

I liked it. In general, for a short game, it's really enjoyable all-around, although it really feels like it needs more depth. This was a 48 hour game, of course, so that's nothing that is actually expected, but I just don't seem to enjoy the wandering around and picking up stuff too much. It feels like it just needs either more puzzle like or more action based gameplay, because the sparks are really just an annoyance. Don't take my criticism wrong to think that I don't like it, it's just that it feels like it could have done more. I really liked the graphics and stuff, however, especially in the opening and ending scenes. They're way too cute to dislike.
Nice work! I love the energy-idea, although it does need some balancing.
That's a very original mechanic, powering machines with your life force, and a very interesting one! It was very fun playing around with the energy levels. +1 for kittens :3
The graphics and animations give the character a very polished feel.

The only suggestion that comes to my mind is to increase the difficulty a bit after powering up the generator. Being able to infinitely recharge from elevators made the game a bit cheap after that. One alternative would be for the beams to turn back on after a short amount of time, so you can't just turn off half the beans, regen at an elevator way back, turn off another half of the beans, etc.
INNOVATION! I really dig the core mechanic. The art is phenomenal, and the game feels super epic for a 48 hour entry. GREAT WORK!
This needs to be extended into a full game.

description:
You are alone in space and you have to find your way home..
I've always loved open world games and that's what I wanted to give what I was designing this game.
The Idea is that you  have been stranded in a unknown area of the universe and you have to go and find your way home by doing tasks for alien planets, all the while defending yourself from the hostile forces around you.. I had also planned to give a spore type trading/mining system and this was partially implemented but I gave up with that as it was way to much work for the amount of time I had left.
Currently I have implemented a few quests, a quest log and planetary trading systems. (black hole warping is also included :D)
It is also worth nothing that all planetary positions/names are randomly placed each time you load a new game. You should also know that when trading items that all shops differ in price, sometimes greatly..
Controls:
W to go forward,
S to go backward,
Q to zoom out,
E to zoom in
Mouse to steer,
Mouse left click to interact,
Mouse right click to shoot.
System Requirements:
Windows 7, Windows Xp with .net framework 4.0 installed
xna framework 4.0 installed (Have you played Terraria? Yes? Then you have the xna framework).
author: The search for home.
title: Alone
comments: I dont seem to be able to edit the submission to include my Timelapse video, Either way. Here is is...

Didn't feel spacey at all.. Felt more like a quad slowly going through void cake. Ran out of fuel really easily, didn't have enough to get the package and return. No fullscreen option but for XNA I can understand, even though the screen was actually bigger than my resolution. Sounds were too loud, had to turn down the volume a lot.
If this is your first game, keep on keeping on. You have a lot to do still, but this is getting somewhere! Try to add acceleration to your ship now ;)

I agree entirely, I'll actually be surprised if anyone finishes it (yes, you can find home) I simply ran out of time as I was passing out on my desk, it does have a heap of items in the game to collect (like fuel drops) but I was never able to stick a loop in their to place them. It is my first game, I'm more of a application developer then games, I spent way to much time doing bad graphics.. And about the sounds, i hate the xna audio engine, i usualy re-write a sound engine using the direct-x dll's..Either way, thanks for the feedback.
I quite enjoyed it. Yeah, the graphics are simple, but I think you have a very solid idea here. Some comments:

* The fuel consumption vs income is brutal. I completed about 5 or 6 missions and had to refuel twice without any income. This meant I had not money to repair and died on the battle mission. Suggestion: make "w,s" accelerate, not move, this would give the opportunity to use some skill to save fuel.

description:
John travels through is mind drowned in insanity. An introspection about himself and about both his past and future.
The game is incomplete. There was a lot more that I wanted to make, but as first time with Unity and a to greedy game design the game ended up not being completed.
But there's still the soul in there and I hope that you can see what I intended to make.
---------------
Controls
---------------
WASD - Movement
Left Mouse Button - Touch
Right Mouse Button - Pick Up
Note, when you touch something the area around iluminates, you can use it to your advantage in dark situations.
---------------
Technical Stuff
---------------
I made a build for MacOS but since I don't have any Mac computer, I'll have to blindly trust in Unity. I made a Universal package, but if you need something specific, just leave a word in the coments.
Sorry for Linux-only users, Unity doesn't provide Linux binaries. I'll try to confirm on my PC if the game works in Wine.
author: 89cookies
title: Alone in His Mind
comments: I think with more time and development this could have been pretty interesting, especially the switch of game mechanics per level. although i fell out of the world in the 3rd level (went through the doors) and stopped playing, i felt like the 2nd level was a bit unforgiving. also the ambient music in level 3 was a good choice.
Similar to Redwind, with a bit more work, this could be quite nice.   Personally, the player speed feels too slow, jumping too high and the mouse movement feels off.  Keep at it though!
I would like to have been able to move a bit faster, perhaps holding down shift to run or something.

Wow.  I was going to complain about the lack of sound in the first level, but the play on sounds and music you did in the 2nd and 3rd levels is beautiful.  Really, really well done.  Somehow the almost completely darkness of the 2nd level made me feel the mood of loneliness and despair.  At first I was all lost, then I noticed how I could follow the music and manage to find my way.  I suspect I was able to do so because I have an habit of using headphones; I am not sure if I would be able to find the music sources with regular speakers.
I hope you find the time to finish this game.  With some polish (I concur the the player needs more speed) this could be very good.
I'd suggest making a web build to save having to install it, you'll get a LOT more reviews that way...

does not work under WINE unfortunately, game loads but can't grab mouse, so it's impossible to do anything (or exit the game for that matter, it has to be killed from another shell). Sorry but can't rate :/

description:
A game about creating a game in 48 hours. You task is to complete your game before the time runs out whilst overcoming problems like power outages, hand injuries, hunger and sleep deprivation.
Requires:
.NET Framework 4.0 (http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=17851 , web installer)
XNA Runtimes 4.0 (http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914 , 6.7MB)
author: Jase
title: ALONE .. Developer
comments: Haha, I liked that I died of depression playing minecraft too much.
Good game, I died of hunger and my cat ate my body

Good idea (I was thinking about something like this, so it MUS T be good idea :D), but whatever I've done, I wasn't able to finish... when sometimes bugs occur every two seconds and I just don't have anything else to remove them...
Fun game! :D Managed to win by cycling production -> eating -> sleeping and using the consumables only when necessary.
LOL, perfect! I was thinking just about this idea midway through my game. Glad to see that someone else thought and went through with it!
And it was a fun game too. I had to try 4 or 5 times, but I finally managed to finish my game (and with 30 hours to spare too!) I was a bit sad that you didn't put a win screen in :-)
Oh, you can go out, I'm not sure you intended that to happen. But nothing happens. And the music got annoying on my third way through the game.

You should definitely expand on this! More items/interactions. A motivation level separate from productivity. Maybe some choices like ambitious/simple game in the beginning affect the difficulty. And an ending! :-)

I finally figured it out and was able to make a game with 32 hours to spare. What a hoss. This is a neat idea, but the audio makes me want to split my body in half with a rusty shovel. No offense. I dig the hilarious ways to die and the overall concept. It was confusing, however, that just standing at the fridge is what refills your hunger bar. I thought I had to use the 'powerups' so I died of hunger 4 times before actually realizing what was happening.
OMG I so enjoyed this game! No winning screen? Cause the game just went back to main menu when I beat it.

description:
For our first participation (and our first game) we chose to make a platform game for the jam.
Unfortunately, we didn't had time to add the scenario. It really stuck to the theme... Many other elements remain unfinished as the graphics or sound effects.
Anyway, we are proud to have managed the challenge of Ludum Dare : that was a great pleasure working along this 3 days !
We are three in the team :
Eldaryze (programmer)
Enimal (game designer and level designer)
Oxydam (game designer)
author: Oxydam
title: Alone
comments: I liked the feeling of this game.  The gentle blowing wind made it more relaxing to play, like the solitude of going on a hike.
Certain jumps had to be just perfect, which got a bit frustrating, but I liked the super meatboy-esque wall jumping.
This reminded me of super meat boy, because as said above, it was frustrating at times, but also fun!
"Certain jumps had to be just perfect, which got a bit frustrating" that and that place where you had to chance the right way
Vous auriez quand mÃªme pu faire un effort pour le titre ^^
A part Ã§a, bon, c'est un platformer...mais un platformer qui fonctionne et qui se rÃ©vÃ¨le aussi amusant que frustrant. En 72h, c'est presque un miracle! :)

This was a really fun game. It wasn't the same kind of frustrating that other entries are, it was a fun type of frustration. The other comments explain it perfectly, it was like Super Meat Boy in that way.
Thanks for your comments, we are happy to see you enjoy our game. We don't integrate the story but you find it fun so it is the most important.
My first thought was that his knees are bent like his running even when he stands still.
Then the auto-scroll kicked in and I thought "damn I shouldn't be standing still"

description:
The game is silent because I got a little carried away with feature creep and my body just can't code anymore...
This comp was a hell of a lot of fun, and I'm very happy with what came out the other end; Now is time for sleep.
Have fun reviewing it. :)
Quimby
Controls:
W/Up arrow - Tap to increase speed
S/Down arrow - Tap to decrease speed
A/D - Hold to roll your craft left or right
Mouse - Steer craft/aim weapon
Left mouse button - Click to fire laser (unlimited ammo)
Right mouse button - Hold to slow time (limited, recharges)
author: Quimby
title: Vestige
comments: A bit difficult to get into and very confusing at first for what to do, was not sure at fist when the next mission started as there was no ending screen for each mission, basically a general lack of direction for the player. Also the difficulty curve was a bit steep once the turrets were introduced, overall though it was quite fun flying through all of the mountains dodging and blowing stuff up :)

I totally agree that my tutorial doesn't do a good enough job explaining the rules and the general lack of direction/polish was primarily due to the fact that I didn't do any work on the tutorial/menus until an hour or so before the deadline. (plus I was exhausted after a 14 hour cram session)
To help remedy this, I have shot a video to upload to Youtube that walks you through the tutorial with commentary so that future reviewers might actually know what to do. :)
Thanks a lot for reviewing and thanks for the feedback.
Congrats on your first Dare, Quimby! I definitely remember that poor tutorial/instructions and a lack of sound were my biggest regrets too on my first. Adding content gets addictive. ;)

Speaking of which, I'm impressed with how much 3D content you managed to add, and making runs back and forth gets to being pretty fun. I didn't really understand the theme in your game, and the barrel rolls didn't really seem to serve a purpose besides giving me a slight headache...
All in all though, great job in your first Dare. :)
The rolling buttons are mainly for my own benefit as I enjoy rolling the craft into turns to make myself feel cool. :P

Thanks for the feedback; I think the confusing part is the kind of mission I put in - Perhaps a "Kill all the turrets" mode would have been more appropriate for this entry as people don't really have much time for each different game so the simpler the better.

description:
(Requires Java)
For my first LD, my game was created in Java and uses the AWT library. You are alone against ghosts who roam in order to meet human flesh. Your mission is to find a secret chest which is in an isolated place.
Throughout your trip where some statues of kittens (\o/) are hidden, collect all the golden coins to open the passage towards the following level, otherwise you will remain alone for ever, roaming as the souls of the lost world in which you are. Good luck, because you can only rely on yourself.
author: harusame
title: The Lone Adventurer
comments: this game looks absolutely beautiful, but the collision detection and controls are painful. If I were you, I'd leave the graphical polishing for after you've made sure everything works as a game. I'm not sure if this happens every time, but when I went through the portal in the first level, it spawned me directly above a spike pit and I would've died if not for using a glitch in your collision detection. Maybe next time, enter the jam so you can keep your (really excellent) graphics but also spend time on the programming
The controls are a bit fiddly, especially with such direct camera control. You cannot see what's below you and above you is nothing of interest.

More importantly, the concept wasn't really clear to me. Some enemies could hurt me but others couldn't, right? I think it had something to do with if they were transparent, but it didn't make the game any clearer.
The ending is a bit abrupt, but oh well.
And yes, you might try entering the Jam instead, because those are some neat graphics.
It is a platformer, not much variation, too difficult early on, didn't really pull me in. The vibrant colours didn't help towards the mood or theme.
Great graphics and audio. I like that there is a lot of feedback to player input, it feels good.
My main concerns are the broken physics (stopping mid air) and the randomness of the difficulty (level 3 is much easier than all others for instance). A solid entry anyway =)
Good first time go! It was lacking a bit of a challenge. Audio was appropriate and there is good graphics. Well done.

This is a great-looking game and the sound is enjoyable, although a bit repetitive.  The slow falling took a while to get used to and it was often annoying to have to backtrack to get one missed coin to finish out the level. Fixing the jump mechanic and only requiring 75% of the coins to clear a level would go a long way towards improving it!

The audio fit in quite well which is rare for a ludum game go kudos to you. As others have pointed out the jumping is sort of terrible. A good way of doing jumping is when SPACE is pressed set an upwards velocity of a certain amount. Then have a constant force (gravity) bringing you back down.
You also should have gone with a less harsh, bassier jump sound. I high pitched sound goes well for tiny characters like mario but yours was larger and more defined.
Really great job on your first LD entry! Overall it was a pretty fun game, I managed to finish it.

The jumping was a bit weird due to the constant acceleration, the camera that followed the player vertically made it hard as well since you can't see what's below you, it may have been better to just go for a centered camera.
The graphics were good, it's nice that you had a large variety of different backgrounds including things like grass over the tiles and a parallax background too.

description: A and D move left and right and Space jumps.  Collect the heart to move on to the next level.
author: shiftingParadigms
title: The Breakup
comments: The intro sequence is way to slow! I like the idea, but the game is also extremely short! A bit more puzzles would have been better, but it's ok! :D I like it!
Yes, the intro sequence is very slow. The gameplay is also very simple and quite buggy. Nice simple retro graphics though.

I quit during the intro because I thought the controls were broken. Then I saw the comments here and tried again. It wasn't really challenging. The graphics were neat though. I liked the space needle.  :)
Sweet, but a few too many leaps of faith. Music would have been nice. As others have mentioned, nice graphics.
I like how you approached the graphics, and it was an admirable shot from someone who says that graphics and animation aren't his forte.  Nice job on that count.

I agree with the others though, that the cutscenes are too slow.  Also, the weird wall jumping mechanic wasn't very intuitive, and there seemed to be a lot of "leaps of faith" where you had to jump without knowing what's under you, which didn't work so well for me (I never died, but felt frustrated that things were hidden in that way).
Congratulations! It's the only one I have been able to play in a Linux Non-Flash Icecat system by now. It truly is too short but I'd been very happy being able to play it.
I liked the part where they had sex.

description:
First time using Stencyl, resulting in a horrible 48 hours. Survive the desert by navigating through using the compass in the bottom right of the screen. Mouse clicks for everything!
MS Paint for graphics, audio in Audacity (murdering a guitar), game in Stencyl.
Native resolution is 640 x 480 but it seems to stretch in browser, so I uploaded it to the Stencyl site: http://www.stencyl.com/game/play/10168 same game just the proper resolution.
author: angrygeometry
title: Survive The Desert
comments: Okay I laughed pretty hard at this! The music and graphics do an amazing job of conveying a mood and when you get into the later humorous screens they work better because the initial serious mood is undercut so heavily. I like how the graphics feel like they work whether you choose to interpret them as examples of that particular kind of lo-fi adventure game art or a send-up of that same art style.

I got a bit frustrated on my first playthrough or so because I could not tell if the things I was clicking on were making any difference. The interface was erratic enough that I thought for a moment the progression from screen to screen was random and/or the NESW clicks were being disregarded.
It certainly inspires alone-ness. I was eventually cut down by capitalism but that's life. Extra points for creepy guitar noises.
Graphics and music are plain awesome. I like that weird and creepy mood. Good job :)
I laughed, too, the humor works really well with the mood :)
You nailed the theme on this one.  Music and graphics worked really well with the mood.  Has a 'Demetri Martiny' feel to it... and i mean that as a compliment.
I wish sometimes load between 1 thing and the next were slightly faster though.
I love the interludes where you just stand there. And the style is amazing! Great job!
Funny, the music sets an excellent mood along with the graphics, I like it
to think.. an indie game dev brings a grown man like myself to tears...
I was kind of shocked to see my LD entry on the PC in the desert.
my favourite entry so far. taking a break for now, but i'm hoping i'll survive the desert by the end of the night.
The pacing, the music, the dark humor - it all works together to produce something immensely likeable. Thoroughly enjoyed it, many times.
nice work on the music and artwork, I only wish it progressed a bit faster!
This is weird, but in absolutely fascinating way. I love this. One of my favourites so far.
good guitar :) fits the mood and the gfx..good job :)
Thanks for pointing me to your entry! I like the mix of "I hate the world" and bizarre scenes (even though I think you could have pushed further to the later).

description:
You're caught in a snowstorm on top of a mountain and must survive to base camp without freezing to death. A really simple adventure game experiment. Multiple endings and story paths.
See my journal entries for more info.
author: gimblll
title: Summit
comments: Awesome! Will certainly come and play it again (didn't come far â�¦). Great graphics and typing the text to feel yourself more involved with the story is a great idea.
Ah yeah, one problem: The Keyboard isn't localized. On a german Keyboard i have to type Zeah instead of Yeah.
Very interesting concept, I liked it! Took some tries to figure out what to do but I manage to finish it.
I did not figured out what to do...
Led to a blank screen for me so I couldn't play. Looks good though!
This is actually a rather simple, but a interesting concept for a game I have to say: Only issue it definetly is difficult to play especially if you have a non calibrated Screen:
Also I found Rob, and spotted the guy (Was it jack?) throwing the flares, but not sure if supposed to follow jack or go where he came from. since he kept going much faster than the player :P
Very very hard, but I liked it. The minimalist style worked to keep the snowbound mood, and the ambient sounds were great.

description:
Once upon a time there was a small town in which a hero lived. His town was destroyed and he was late to wake up. Sound cliched?
Well, what if the villain set out to destroy the world is nowhere to be found? In fact, there doesn't seem to be anyone other than the hero.
A humorous yet eerie visual novel remnant of a high fantasy world.
Made using Ren'Py. All sounds by my voice, some creaky-ish floorboards and a bag of dice, edited with Audacity.
author: Goldendice
title: Soloing
comments: Scary as shit :O, but well put together :)
Really neat, I liked the atmosphere and stuff. Really fit the theme. The endings were also good with the theme but it didn't stop me from trying everything to get a "good" ending.
I got a lot of black screens. Are a lot of the areas supposed to be just black screens? Were you hitting paper for the music? lol

@SonnyBone: Yeah, there were several black screens either a. because it was dark or b. because none of the images I made seemed appropriate. And it wasn't paper - all I used were a bag full of dice and my own voice.
Really nice game, although I don't see the need for a save option. :D

description:
Robotic Friend is a platform exploration game. You play as a robot who tries to find someone else like him. He has to avoid various obstacles and kill enemies in his way to his goal.
By the way, this game has two endings. Can you find them all? :)
author: Wirtualnosc
title: Robotic Friend
comments: Excellent game! The best I've seen so far! Took a long time to play through, which is good, and the graphics and sounds were very attractive. Very well done.

The title screen text got cut off on my screen, the "standing on the portal" sound is really annoying for me, and thus I began this game slightly underwhelmed... but then I found out how big your world was, the really nice tilesets, the precise platforming mechanics, and I was pretty blown away. AND a second ending. Nice work :)

I think this is a really cool game with a lot of small unfortunate details--such as the title sequence, certain sound effects, the lack of ambient background music--that keep it from being really, really cool.
Interesting game, thanks for the effort you put on it.

However, at first sight there are a lot of things that will turn people away from the game: the story screen cut in half, and the sounds were mentioned, but the control scheme is also a bit iffy. Ctrl to shoot and Shift to jump is a combinations that is not very good to the hands - added that there is no explanation to the controls, I had to fiddle with the keyboard for a bit until I found them.

description:
A hero. A princess. A dragon. A sword (or not). Coins. Chests. Crates.
A simple story that may reflect the decisions we take in real life.
Playing with the Sound ON helps getting in-game feedback of what is going on :)
Made with:
- Unity3D (C#, iTween)
- cfxr
- Audacity
- Garage Band
- Photoshop
Also: Kitten!
Note: The source link takes to the BitBucket Git repository for the game. Just over "get source" to the right and download the zip.
author: karnakgames
title: Loot Alone
comments: Cool, but more like a flash animation than a game :P
Thanks! It can actually be called a "short game" because it requires you to do something. :D
Neat little game. A little strange you were given a choice at the end but you couldn't actually choose (or could you)?
Thanks! Actually you can't choose. To be honest, I planned to allow choices, but due to the lack of time, I ended up with the "bad" choice only :)
Well, I really enjoyed this... until it ended :(
I sat at the "Alone with a rocket kitten" screen for at least several seconds waiting for some awesome game-play to kick in where I would ride a rocket cat across the landscape or something...
The graphics were very charming and the comic-book panel style of game-play (if you can call it that) was really interesting.
If this had more 'doing' then this would have been the best LD22 game I'd played so far (well, other than mine, obviously :P); Nice work
It would have been 10x better, if you had included a little animation of you flying through clouds or space or something with the Rocket Kitty.
Sorta like a nyancat animation or something, but with rocket kitty!

Not much in the way of decision making. In fact, when I decided to forgo opening treasure chests on my first run, it still said "Ooh, a sword" when I had not even picked it up. Moving forward and continuing dialogue don't make a game alone. Nonetheless, it's good that you're learning about coding. You should definitely be able to make bigger and better things in the future.
Thanks guys. I worked shortly on the game, with some rush and laziness.
Goldendice: actually there are bugs, it's impossible to do something polished in 8 hours (the time I worked on this game).
By the way I'm not learning, I've worked on more than 22 games to date :) It just hapenned to be my first LD, but not my 1st game at all.
Quirky humor, nice graphics, but I couldn't find the key??
Not much in the way of a game, but it gave me a chuckle.
Probably should have had an animation or something when opening the boxes... otherwise they just seemed like decoration.

description:
Story Notes : You just want to get home, but the sun has set early and you've lost your way. You know that these caves are full of holes and passageways, lets just hope you can keep enough batteries in your flashlight to make it over the wall and home!
GamPlay Notes : Use your flashlight to see further and move faster, but remember to conserve that battery life!
Look for hidden items, each item will make your adventure easier.
Falling is okay. Sometimes its best to start from the bottom and work your way up.
Dev Notes : Wow was this a crazy ride. I think I was horribly unprepared for just how much this takes out of you. You have to be so focused and so productive and also pretty fast to make any significant progress. I'm content with my creation, but its far from what I envisioned and I plan on finishing the project and polishing i tup so its something special.
author: JAH2488
title: Long Walk Home
comments: The first time I played it, I thought that the game was super-short, but the second time around it proved to be a bit deeper. It seems like there is a lot going on, but I spent a lot of time waiting for a jump to charge. This has potential to be an awesome game, if it contained some sounds, music, and a bit of guidance for the player at the start.
Pretty cool. I had a lot of fun just wandering around, but I couldn't really tell what the point was. Nice looking game, the overall style is solid.
Too much time waiting for jump to charge.

Wow, that was pretty cool! There's a lot of depth here (excuse the pun). Now that I look back at the items list, there are actually fewer items than I perceived, but that's what counts. Felt like a real adventure, with lots of possibility. Took me a minute or so to figure out how to use the jetpack (had to re-read the instructions), but it worked well once I did.
No audio was a bummer, but easily rectified in future versions. Nice work, and I would play it again!
Thanks for all the positive feedback guys! I'm glad you like it
This game is awesome! It has well written mechanics - what a lot of game doesn't have. Good control, good collision detection and particles! :D

I liked the Idea of having batteries recharge, although it would be nice if they would recharge a bit faster. That said, finding the extra battery packs scattered about kept me going for quite a while.

description:
My first ever entry to LD48. I just learned what I'll need to do next time.
The game is an adventure of a Castaway, with some meme humor inserted.
Edit: A web port added.

author: ziomorti
title: Do NOT Hug Me!
comments: A fairly fun button basher that is unfortunately a little buggy. Would have been nice to have more variety in enemies and graphics.
Interesting concept. I can identify with the misanthropic vibe. The WC and paper spawns were a funny feature, and the "ugh" voice at game start was a nice touch too.

Felt a little claustrophobic, since the enemies all sprung at once and overlapped player, but I guess the point was to fight them off, after all. I think adding a knockback to player's attack would've made a big difference. Nice work, though!

I loved the run animation for this; Sheer brilliance.
The game itself was a little shallow, but you score some points for doing it in HTML5.

Good job and way to go reviewing so many games;I came here due to your 11% coolness rating - That's roughly 100 games already!!!.
Well, thanks for the review! I think that creating a game for Ludum Dare is only half of the event: reviewing, learning and getting in touch with other people is important, too.
haha i love the little walking/hitting with broom animation. this was pretty fun. i was also terrified when the boss showed up. nice job
hahaha, very fun! I love the little hug me sounds. And once I found out what the power ups did it was an extra dimension of fun. Need moar bombs! :)
Hey, ziomorti. Congrats on your first LD and thanks for all your work commenting and reviewing games. I'm returning the favor. :)

I really liked how different weapons changed the gameplay, and the animations and audio gave the game lots of personality and likability. It was pretty hectic and fun at first, but I ended up (like others) just wanting more depth.

Also, not being able to avoid damage is something that stresses me out quite a bit. Once the map gets crowded, I can only run to a corner (taking damage by running past enemies) and fight them off one at a time. Either knockback or maybe jumping adds a layer of skill that I would have really appreciated.
All in all, great effort. I think you executed some things really well, and if you had a bit more time to polish and add another feature or two, this could have been a pretty fun game. :)
it's a bit buggy, but i like the concept!
pretty tough! couldn't beat it, unfortunately.

Well, I'm sure the animations are bugged and there is a small exploit (but I won't tell you what :D). On the rest I totally agree with Aaron, but just one note: not being able to avoid (or at least, for not so long) the enemies is kind of intended. I think it underlines the urge of loneliness of my "robot" and how he must struggle to have it.

Fun entry. The idea is not new, but the concept could be fun nevertheless with some polish. However, art doesn't really justify it and highly contrasting colors, although good at setting apart world elements, are a bit inconsistent. Unfortunately gets repetitive very quick and I would love to see a wider monster variety. I guess you get some humor points too, but the humor does feel a bit forced and not subtle at all. Wacky animations are a plus though and make the graphical style appear almost intentional. Could be great with an actiony soundtrack. A jump button would be really nice (even though you say it's not there intentionally), and I kept thinking you could use doors. Love the "hug me" sfxs. I did not quite see this as fitting the theme or mood well, as you are constantly "not alone" and the "loneliness" bar is just a health bar renamed for theme purposes :) But the hints are there. Overall, good fun first try. Definitively 5 stars on community for rating many games.
Thanks Rudy (loved your game, btw) for the huge feedback!
the sound was a little grating and i agree that it got repetitive but i'm sure that was down to the time limit. i liked it though!
Fun animations, nice gameplay and the concept is totally relevant to the theme, but I would have loved to see some variation. Also, that boss is hard.
Many thanks to all of you! The boss is pretty hard, but not impossible :D
Really loved your game! Hitting enemies with a broom and throwing toilet paper are fun ideas.

Nice little game.  It seemed a little busy to me... especially when the map gets crowded.  A broom or tp buff would have toned that down a bit.  Or a knock back like others suggested.
HUG ME LOVE ME - WHAM WHAM ATOMIC BOMB

description:
Arrow keys or WASD to move
There is no goal.
Other than maybe finding a purpose in life. Or at least someone to share it with.
-----
I tend to work by thinking up some kind of interesting interaction  first, and only thinking about a challenge or goal to go with it later on. This is very definitely still in the stage of experimenting with interaction.
I do kind of like what I had here, but it does need a lot more feedback for the player to tell what's going on - when you've died, what the companion is doing, and so on. And ultimately, it needs some kind of direction or purpose.
author: roBurky
title: Companion
comments: VERY cool! I love how you interact with the little cube, it seems to have a lot of personality. Is it me or the little square cuddles up with you for a while if it takes damage? I wonder how much of it is intended and how much is just me making it up! All in all, very cool feel to it. Its too bad it doesnt have a goal, Id probably be playing it much longer.
The game would be really good if there were any objectives (which i can see a lot with this), but just wandering around doing nothing just doesn't cut out for me :\.
A restart button (dunno if there's any) after you "die" would be nice too.
The graphics looked nice and fitted the mood.
I really liked this. It had personality and mood in bundles, and I'm glad you experimented.

I think just a bit more feedback/suggested meaning would have gone a long way. I didn't know that I died (or could die), so I was staring confused at my screen for a good 5 seconds. The cube doesn't rotate to movement, making it a bit static until it finally interacts with something--not sure whether that was intentional. And I got into the experience, and definitely enjoyed it, but it didn't really pop because maybe I'm just not somebody who naturally self-imposes stories/meanings to visual interactions. Something more--like tiny hearts that popped up when you're nearby a cube (or maybe that's too bold)--would have really helped me out.
All in all though, pretty awesome experience.

Aaron: Those are all very good criticisms, that I agree with. Dying needs more feedback. The static starting rotation looks a bit weird. It needs some kind of purpose or goal at least as a background to you goofing off playing with the little cube.

Fortunately you came well armed spending your life savings on three, reliable guns. author: pireninjacolass
title: A rather Lonely Darkness
comments: Thanks for the game. It was not bad at all.
- You need better visual clues for the dungeon area - the dark gray walls dont really look like walls, and the "insta death pits" were annoying when I found out what they were.
- Make the game detect when it loses focus and auto-pause. With a "aim and click" shooter, there is always the risk of the mouse clicking outside of the screen during combat.
- Maybe increase the speed of the character a bit?
Thats for the info! we're going to work on that in the next update (:
Good fun! Just work on some visual clues and perhaps changing some of the world colors so you can better see the bullets you shoot!

author: Sophie Houlden
title: 3 Missing, 4am
comments: Well done! I finished it and I really enjoyed it.
Spooky. The bumpmaps work also quite well.

Whoa, majorly impressive work. Fits the theme perfectly. My only complaint is that while it should be dark, it would be nice if there was some kind of lighting. I'm having a hard time finding the rest of the batteries, and I'm not sure of where I've already been. Regardless, awesome work.

Really awesome. There is a *ton* of mood in this game, it reminded me a lot of playing Alan Wake (in a good way). Played  it to the end, loved the generator "surprise" (at least, I thought it was surprising).
Very cool, kind of a Blair Witch feel to it (admittedly I couldn't find the 3rd battery, so I don't know how it ends)
Very cinematic, good use of camera and light.
As others have commented, a tiny bit more direction on where to get the batteries would have been greatly appreciated. And keeping in mind that I'm a lazy bastard on a tight schedule.

Something about the atmosphere didn't quite grab me, maybe it could have done with some ambient background music or something? Also, searching for batteries and to a lesser extent turning on the generators felt a little arbitrary and forced rather than being part of the game world since they actually didn't provide that much benefit (well, the batteries did, but why would they be scattered around like that?).

On the other hand, nice animation, good lighting - I especially liked seeing the glow of the generators a little way off and being drawn to them like a moth - and I think that the overall concept was pretty good too.
Overall a pretty nice game (especially considering the time limit).
Really impresive! Took me forever to find that small cave and the battery inside
Very atmospheric, indeed. Could be transformed into a great survival horror game!
Came back here after finding two batteries to look for hints.  If someone didn't  mention the cave I likely would have given up.
I love how this conveys a story without dialogue and leaves room for imagination. 5 stars for mood.
Brilliant atmosphere! That last item was tough to find! >.<

This is very impressive! The graphics are super intense and give the mood and theme character! The audio could have been a little more variation even though I liked how the one sound faded out as you walked. It fit the theme perfectly but I was't sure what I was doing and at one point I stopped because I wasnt sure what to do. Maybe thats the puzzle but I'm not sure. It really is a great game though! Good job
wow, this is one dark game. i love the atmosphere and i had a lot of fun just looking around. nicely done

Nice use of shadow and camera movement. It was very cool when the buildings lit up - I hadn't even noticed them until then. Searching for the battery in the cave was annoying. Would have like more of an ending.

Wow, this was fantastic. It felt original and was fun to play. This did a great job of creating legitimately spooky moments, like the first time I saw a blinking red light in the distance. I don't usually find "scares" in games, even when the game is designed for that, but I found myself actually afraid of things like straying off the path or the way that my shadow looked like something huge and looming following me.

A lot of moments in this looked really picturesque, I kept taking screenshots while I played. A lot of Unity 3D games look kind of same-y to me but this game avoided that. The electric noises as ambient "music" were great.

There were only a couple of problems I had. The camera did odd things when I tried to climb the "towers", like going behind/through walls and forcing me to readjust, which was distracting. (On the way back down the camera worked great oddly.) The only real problem I had was it felt unnecessary to do the battery thing three times. The first battery I found, on top of a tower, actually felt like a discovery and something I'd thought about and worked for. The second two, I basically had to comb the space to find it, which both wasn't fun and also made me feel like I was "playing a game". (I actually found the second two batteries by left-hand-rule-ing the wall, which I think if a game ever leads me to do that something went wrong.) By the time I found the other two batteries the sense of tension and threat in the environment the game had carefully built up was gone and I was fearlessly doing things like walking off cliffs (in the process finding the engine lets you do lots of odd things when you try to do that, like walk on stone walls).  I think maybe the game would actually be better if the only battery were on top of the tower. (I also wondered why I couldn't try to scavenge a battery from my original, wrecked car.)
i found an easter egg, it says "poo :p" on the doors

Old Dungeon Master style RPG with pirates, ninjas, undeads, kittens and some insanity thrown in the pot.
You wanted to be alone with your zombie kittens, but oh no, not even on the moon you can find solitude. Some rotten (meaning literally) pirates ninja looted your bag of adorable zombie kittens! Can you beat them with their own weapons and ninja loot your kittens back?

Why are you here, who brought you here, are you alone, those are the questions that come into your mind. And then, you begin your quest. It's simple as opening a door: you enter a maze with some strange lights on the walls, their meaning are not familiar at all. During your journey, you will encounter some people, and yet you will still be alone.. at the end.
Who will you be at the end ? Who will you chose to leave and live ?
That's the question you will have to answer to be able to complete the game.

description:

The game uses Adobe Flash as a platform.
Timelapse video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=DWThOd09lDI
Software Used:
Flash CS4 Professional (with ActionScript 2.0) - general development and animation;
Wally - floor texture;
ASEprite - sprites;
Paint.NET - general image manipulation.
One or two code snippets (such as those used to make objects rotate) were taken from some of my older projects.
The .swf can be used to upload to websites - feel free to upload to your website - just please give credit to me.
I would recommend using the Web version, as it is the most likely to work, and you should be playing the game in quite a small amount of time.
Platform specific versions should work, but they are quite large.
Use the .swf version if neither of the above work. Most web browsers with Flash Player installed are likely to run it.
The source is going to be quite hard to understand as it is very unorganised. As far as I am aware, Flash CS4 Professional or higher is required to open it - but you may be able to open it with other software.

comments: I made it! Good game, overall. Concise, and easy to get into. Looks pretty slick too. There wasn't much challenge or player choice, but it was fun to play with nevertheless. I liked that you could run out of fuel and still coast slowly onto the refueller (sort of a second chance).
Might be fun to reduce gravity a bit so you don't stick to the ground (e.g. allow jumps off ramps with enough momentum)

Unfortunately, "always hold the right arrow" seemed to be the answer 90% of the time -- you don't really coast fast enough downhill for it to be worth "saving fuel" that way -- since it takes a looong time to coast anywhere, you're still burning a lot of gas, AND you're making it less likely that you'll make it over the next hill.
I liked the mechanic, though, and it's some nice, clean and stylish art!

Thanks for the feedback. I ended up turning to level design with only a couple hours left, and realized I should have started that much earlier. I started creating a longer level 3, but without a couple more gameplay pieces (like jumping or ability to save fuel more effectively) it just felt repetitive.

description:
This game runs windowed mode. Dodge the squares using ARROW KEYS, hit ESC to quit. Game quits if you fail so you may have to run the game a few times to reach the ending. If you happen to have the XNA redistributable and other frameworks installed, you can use a zipped version of the game if you prefer [ here it is ----> http://dl.dropbox.com/u/122720/TOGETHER%20ALONE%20ZIP.zip  ]. If you are having trouble finding the game after install you can just search for the "TOGETHER ALONE", as XNA installer puts stuff in a weird spot under your All Programs list. It should then be uninstallable through Add/Remove Programs. It's not very long, so I have faith in you! YOU CAN DO IT! Enjoy my first ever LUDUM DARE entry made with XNA, ASE, and Audacity.
PS - LESSONS LEARNED - Make sure you really know your environment well. My newness to C# and XNA led to some horrible looking code...check it out in the source! : ) Also, don't be too ambitious. I had to scrap first two partially completed projects because of this. Oh wells...will be really ready for my second LUDUM DARE!

description:
This game looks at the concept of a person's preference for being alone (introversion), or never being alone (extroversion). I know the science and exact nature of these things is not captured in the game, but the game is meant to be fun/funny too. Check out the instructions in the game menu for the skinny on controls and goals.
More info on this here: http://whilefun.com/games.php#LD22
Controls are X (select in menu), and C, and arrows. Read the instructions for more info :)
More details, if you want them: You select your "alone" preference then play through day (office) and night (city/street) cycles. You must carefully balance your anxiety and energy levels, while striving to be understood by those around you. The more anxious you are and the less energy you have, the more likely you will be misunderstood. At the end of the day (you're understoood, or too anxious), you get to recharge in the way you like. The goal of the night cycle is to lower your anxiety and raise your energy for the next day. Failure to do this means you won't be understood, and ultimately your self worth and lonliness will increase. If your self worth goes too low, you will die. Boy did I make that sound boring. HAH :)
