Don't get me wrong. The game's pretty good, and this is definitely a great entry. Although the gameplay feels kinda lacking, I really love the mood and your postmortem is really nice to read - I'd just prefer to rate it as a jam entry, where it belongs. Oh well, maybe next time.

Marudziik, you are right, I should had read the rules first. About my framework, I have to say it is just a couple of classes on top of flixel, nothing fancy, really, I made it time ago to clarify some obscure flixel parts.
When I said "preparing the whole month" I meant psycologically, not a single line of code was written nor graphic was created till the start (I took the 48hs seriously).
But yes, I had help on the graphics, which let me focus on the coding (although I was supervising the graphics all the time).
Thanks for your comments, next time I will try to make it just by myself.
Surely this can't be accepted for the Competition, because all content must be created yourself.

description:
You goal is to earn money, upgrade your ship, and defend the Mining station.
To Play:
Unzip the files to a location you prefer, and run alone.exe
To Win/Lose:
To trigger the ending sequence of event you first need to find the Drone, and shoot it. The drone can be anywhere on the map, and will turn and move away when you near it. (its a bright white circle)
The Controls:
These are the defaults, you can set them to another set of keys, or to a Gamepad by clicking on the control in game.
Move Left: A
Move Right: D
Move Up: W
Move Down S
shoot: Spacebar
Upgrade Engine: 1
Upgrade Weapon: 2
Upgrade Sheild: 3
Upgrade Cargo: 4
Replay: Escape
Submit Score: Tab
Scoring:
You earn points for destroying stuff.
Online HighScore table:
http://allaroundgames.net/LD22/highscore/
Known Issues:
-Sometimes crashes giving a render error, no solution that I know of.
Source Files:
I have removed two bits of information from the source files.
- My MYSQL database information, just your standard php mysql information on a db.php page.
- Inside of the .cap file I removed the location of the submit.php file.
author: Sandcrawler
title: Alone In Space...
comments: Crashes all the time for me straight off the main menu when I click play. No specific error - just the Windows 'Check Online for solution' thing.
If you re-download (using the same link) I updated the game to fix this issue, and the render error. A full change log is listed at the top of the Readme.txt file.
I played for like 20 minutes and had upgraded my ship a lot... but nothing happened. No enemies, no kitty :( I never got a win or lose. Not sure what happened, but I had to move on.

Sorry, I should have mentioned in the post (I'll do that now) that there is a white circular drone object that is somewhere in the level. When you shoot the drone it triggers the spawning of enemy ships.
The Drone can usually be found on one of the edges of the map, but sometimes they are near the station.

The kitty is placed randomly (like everything except the Mining Station) someplace in the level. I usually upgrade the ships engine first, then use a grid search pattern to find the kitten, and the drone.
Really cool, reminded me of galaxy on fire. The only issue was the resolution was too high and I could not see my credits. but otherwise great job
too hard! i upgraded everything a few levels before hitting the drone, couldn't kill a single enemy.

It definitely has potential, but... first time around, I probably hit the drone thingy without even knowing it and then when enemies started to spawn and attack, I had no chance... next time, after reading what i'm supposed to do, I've upgraded quite a lot, took out drone and... nothing...
(I'm thinking it would be too hard even with the upgrades).
But some improvement and it could be really fun game.
Yea its on the hard side, when you have 6 or 7 upgrades into engines, and as many as you have patience for into Weapons you can finish it fairly easy.
With the higher engines you can outrun the shots they fire, and the higher your weapon is the more accurate they get. Then it just a matter of kiting them where they need to be so you can hit them.
Shigor; I have seen that issue as well, I'm not sure what causes them to not spawn.

description: Alone and stranded is a survival game, I know my source and game could use some work but my game changed a lot in terms of ideas and I got rid of a lot of ideas I had for it. I also gave up for a while, so it's probably more like 30-40 hours rather than 48. I'm happy I finished it though.
author: AwesomeKT
title: Alone and Stranded
comments: Not sure what to do here except button mash WASD, and then I won. Did I fix the ship? I dunno...
I didn't get the chance to add like half the features I wanted to add, so yeah button mash.
One of the worst entries so far. Don't give up so easily next time. (Also, DON'T use installer next time)

Using the installer is annoying. It means I have to find the program in Programs and Features and uninstall it after I've finished playing. The game itself was just a button mash, and I seem to have just randomly won without passing a certain survival chance %, unless I missed something.
Keep working at it and next time, don't use the installer, and I'm sure you'll make a more complete game come next Ludum Dare.

Congratulations on sticking with it and submitting your game! I found this one pretty hard to figure out, although I experimentally guessed the controls after awhile. I am sure you've learned a lot this time, and I look forward to playing your submission for the next one.

I realized I had left the button Q as instawin while I was testing it. I wanted to have a much more complete game and I had written the systems to do so, but I had issues which I later realized was caused by not calling my methods long after I gave up on the code. It was going to have different areas and more dialogue but the last few hours it turned into a if statement mess.

description:
You're alone on a space station. An Abandoned space station. With no where to go.
Use the Arrow Keys + X to play.
(Or alternatively WASD + IJKL)
UPDATE 1: Uploaded a new source, with cleaned up and properly commented code.
author: Noel
title: Abandoned
comments: I was really impressed by this, especially for a 48-hour project from a young developer! You're really talented, great job with this game!

Really impressed by the level of polish! Getting stuck behind boxes was annoying, but otherwise a good puzzle game. With some additional mechanics to play with (like, for example, objects which fall downwards without having to be towed) it could get quite involved. I was also really impressed with how finished this game felt... my own feels hacked together by comparison!
Thanks guys! I appreciate all the feedback and comments :)
Definitely agree it could use some more mechanics to make it interesting. I plan to continue work with this game, so I'll definitely be adding more than just the crates/lasers later on.
i was about to write an anti-level design rant (and still may) after playing a number of other LD48 entries, and then i play this game and its greatest strength is satisfying level design.
the story/connection to the theme was kind of unsatisfying to me, though. =\ not saying it wasn't there, but the game just didn't make me feel 'alone' or even 'abandoned'.
This game looks great! I don't think it did much to honor the theme, however.
Brilliant, however it was rather dull near the end, nothing really changed it was same-styled puzzled. Got a bit confusing with the amount of screen turnings that occurred.
This is great! It's all very smooth and things seem to work really well. There were some cases where I would get trapped, and a reset button would have helped.
Was fun to play. Good job!
Gameplay is kinda fun and original, puzzles are challenging, art is awesome and really lovely + cute.

Sfx were ok... they did the job basically! :) - but no music. This would have also helped setting the right mood. Really, just one simple, sad loop would have improved the experience a lot (although I cheated a bit playing adequate music of mine on background haha :P)
Overall, neat experience, specially considering Ludum Dare conditions - also, fantastic polishing! :)
Great job. I look forward to seeing more levels and puzzles.
Fantastic! Even Metal Storm and VVVVVV didn't think to bring grappling hooks into the mix. This one's a strong contender in a few categories!
Great game Noel! Love the art, love the feel of the game and the mechanics. Once I got the feel of the grappling hooks, it felt really good. Smart puzzles too, lots of potential here.
Very impressive for a 48 hours of work!

A good game, especially given the time constraints.  The art is great.  I especially love the guys floating in tanks in the background.  I found the controls really frustrating until I figured out that you grapple in whichever direction you last pressed (I might have missed a screen) and that grappling while holding a crate throws it forward (I kept expecting to grapple out from under it, dropping it).
Incredible! For a 48 hour game I really can't give any serious crits :D
Great game mechanic, solidly implemented. Really good.
Enjoyed it a lot, but got stuck into a wall at some point (because of two blocks one on my left and the other on my top). Couldn't get out. Still very nice
Thanks for the feedback, suggestions, and constructive criticism everyone!

@Wgemigh: I definitely think the controls need to be a bit more obvious for sure. In my eventual post-ludum dare version, I'll work on that. I'm not sure how to make them more obvious, but maybe explaining them in-game a bit better would help.
Hmm, looking through my code I realize why that happens, and I've fixed it now (not in the Ludum Dare version though). Thanks!
I think I'll also add a restart button in strange situations like this, in case someone ever gets stuck again.
This game is sweeeeeeeet. Sexy concept.
One of the best entries so far, congratulation.
Generally very strong entry.  Good mechanic, nice art, pretty polished.  Controls are quite a way from intuitive (first time I played I didn't realise I could shoot grapple upwards).
After the initial ah-ha of the core mechanic there wasn't much else compelling going on for the rest of the game.  It was just more of the same.
Great game. Creative and fun. I wanted to play more levels!
Great core mechanic. Got tiring after a while. Good puzzles... totally crazy that this was in 48 hours. Good job!
Brilliant stuff, really enjoyable bit of puzzling. A bit of music would have been nice but obviously 48 hours is a tough timeframe.
Best entry so far. Absolutely brilliant. 5/5
Great game. I found a bug dealing with shooting up and suddenly floating where there is no platform, but other than that it was fantastic.

Great game. The grappling hook, with changing gravity, is a nice mechanic. Just the orientation and pulling blocks wouldn't really be enough to take the game farther, I don't think, but it's very solid for such a short game.

I think just adding some animation to the player, where he aims up, might be enough to make it clear to the player that they can shoot upward. Adding visual cues like that might be a better way to show the player's capabilities than more tutorial text.

description:
[Greeble] is an HTML5 game where you are the captain of a crashed spaceship. You are ALONE but need some help to survive. Collect the cryo-keys to activate the stasis pods in order to free your friends.
Features pixel-perfect, non-grid platforming, bounce-pads, transparent glass tubes, a fun retro "scan line" effect, silly AI followers and A KITTEN, your objective is to use the arrow keys to navigate to the exit, where you will be rewarded with a trampoline party!
I had so much fun making this game. I even had time to hang out with friends, go for a hike, and decorate my house for the holidays! There is a lot of room for improvement but overall I'm really happy with the final product.
Created using ippa lix's wonderful jawsjs game engine.
The word "greeble" comes from the original Star Wars ILM special effects artists who used the term to describe generic "tech" bits and pieces that adorn sci-fi hulls. There are thousands of greebles in this game's level art.
Ludum Dare is so much FUN.
author: Breakdance McFunkypants
title: [Greeble]
comments: Certainly felt "alone". Found the kitten first try due to my perceptive/antagonistic nature. Could have used a little more to jog the "fun" along, felt a quite empty.
That could've been largely due to the constant unpredictable slowdown I was experiencing though :(

Weird... when I played it earlier The player's movement is slow. But when I played it again again the movespeed is significantly faster. Got to say I prefer the slower one. Also, the music should loop instead of stopping after one playback. Nice atmosphere at the game btw :)
Solid little playtformer. Love the animations :-)
great graphics but didnt hear any sound for some reason.. good stuff :)
Outstanding piece of work, good style, fun character animations.
Could do with some SFX, but the drone soundtrack was a great atmosphere catalyst.
I loved the graphics. The game lagged a lot on my computer, unfortunately.
Nice game, but a little lacking on the fun side. The absence of danger, I think. But good work!
Very nice graphics, but a little bit lacking on the gameplay side. I didn't read the text below first, so I was disappointed that the characters that follow you aren't an actual gameplay element.
Great visual aesthetics. Where is the sound? And why last LD's theme :P.
A little lagging, but you certainly show that there's a huge potential in HTML5 games. Love the background music & level design/ artwork.
Amazing artwork, really well done! I like the parallaxing background and the subtle horizontal lines. Controls are smooth and simple on Chrome. You've got some great HTML5 skills there!

I was fairly disappointed when the followers turned out to be completely irrelevant to the gameplay. I think I would have liked less graphics in favor of having them do SOMETHING, even if it's just stand on switches while you pass through a door.
had a fair bit of random slowdown that made moving in the game unenjoyable (firefox 8.0.1, latest version of OSX).

Pretty neat! The graphics and level design are pretty cool, but it doesn't really use the theme much. Also the framerate was all over the place - sometimes really smooth but most of the time it was pretty sluggish.
That said, I did finish it and it was pretty fun, so well done.
Nice graphics but other than that it's not very fun or aloneish.
Doesn't work properly on FF, only Chrome.
Feels like you're using a fixed timescale update, as there's a lot of random slowdown.
I really like your animation style and illustrations.

The idea of having mindless followers is really neat, but I would have liked to have seen a use for them, such as bait for monsters, fodder for traps, or perhaps to take over as the main character if you die yourself.
Really enjoyed the art style, and as others have said, I experienced a lot of random slowdowns while playing

Good platformer. Left/right controls are too responsive. Love the following NPCs, though that kind of breaks the "alone" part. Pixel art and scanlines work nice, but a little variety might have helped. Kitten easter egg is a nice touch, though easy to find. Score fits nicely, but some SFX may have helped. Didn't have any audio/lag issues (Win7x64SP1,FF).
Nice style, the eerie music created a great mood. Not really challenging, though.
I found the kitty! But that was before clipping got turned back on.
the audio and graphics really work well to create atmosphere, the game ran pretty poorly on my computer unfortunately though.
Amazing atmosphere! I loved the parallax background and convoluted level.
Otherwise it felt like a good tech demo, not an overly fun game. But again, excellent graphics, and you got my "mood" vote for sure.
Great job overall, the artwork was amazing and the audi went with it but I think there needed to be more sfx in the audio. It was fun but a little too easy. Great job
Thanks for all the kind words folks!
QUESTION: do you think this game shows enough promise to be worth of me expanding it into a full game with multiple levels, plot, battles and enemies?
Yeah, I also experienced the slowdown. Reading your blogs... I am now incredibly interested in how this was put together. I know nothing of HTML5 and all that jazz... so this is pretty dang rad.

Overall it was a nice game, though it felt lacking in certain area's... Not much in the to-do section other then trying to "catch 'em all". Also I'm using Firefox to view it and I think I isolated the cause of the FPS drop. When the background image was still the FPS were normal. (around the map edges) When you got away from the map edge and the background started scrolling the FPS would drop. Don't know if this is the cause for everyone but that's what happened on my browser.

The funny thing about slowdowns is that on my 5 year old computer I get 60fps on ALL browsers - tested in IE, Chrome, FF, Safari, and all stay silky smooth 60fps the entire time. Thet said, when I play it on my netbook it runs pretty slow.
I bet it you update your browser to the latest and greatest version the fps will double, since recent versions use hardware compositing for canvas while 6 month old browsers do it all in software.
Pretty game. Not much to do in the game though.
Solid platformer, great art. Could use some hazards to make it more challenging though.
Just the "Web" link would've done. In fact, the "Source" link is not terribly accurate, is it? ;)
Your question is a bit broad to answer. Right now, it's a fairly plain platformer, and you can take it in a hundred different directions that involve â��multiple levels, plot, battles and enemiesâ��.

What this has to offer right now is a lot of style and mood. That's definitely something you can expand on. It looks absolutely gorgeous, but I did feel that the audio intro and cryo-themed story were a bit more grim than / out of line with the vibrant colors used in the artwork.
A lot laggy with my config, but abstract of that, I had some fun playing this game, find the way out, meet the kitten, that stuff... Really well done, dude !
But... With a little more time than 48h, I'm shure you'd notice the potential for the "friends" to help exit. Like stand on buttons, or help jumping, somethings like that.

As a lot of people have said already, slow, but cool, and the first HTML5 game I've ever seen. When I picked up the first guy, I thought "Wow, that's some great AI!" but then realized I was complementing myself.
Camera was a little shakey at times, not very fun but cool graphically and stylistically. I know that the blocks would have been hard to program :)

description:
Something bad has happened and now you are alone in your escape pod drifting through space.
Make your way to Delta Station to seek rescue.
By Dan Cassidy and Nick Griffiths.
author: Dan C
title: 10,000 Space Leagues from Delta Station
comments: Spectacular intro! The President of Space really makes this. The game itself is really difficult; haven't completed it once! I've found that turning opposite to the direction of motion, allowing me to reverse, works ok. I always just run out of fuel though!
Be reassured that it is quite possible to get to the end, although I didn't get a chance to make a proper ending so there will be scant reward for your efforts.
There is a trick to it, you need to be a bit clever to make very frugal use of fuel.
At risk of giving too much away, you generally only need to apply rotational thrust once per game.
Dodging the asteroids was impossible for me. I just aimed towards the station, blasted the booster and prayed. Never made it.
Cool intro, but this is really hard to play (even if I'm using very light key presses)

I am disappoint (together with mr. President). Even after getting your hint (start rotating ship at start and then just use good timing for dodging) I wasn't able to get to the end. Well... maybe if I'd fly really slowly, but then my tea wouldn't be no good probably.

Set the ship rotating fast at the start, and then apply forward thrust in *short* bursts while you're facing the correct direction to get yourself moving in the correct direction and to avoid the asteroids. You can't slow down much at short notice, so keep your speed down to avoid crashing. It's really not that hard.

It is however practically impossible to reach Delta Station before your tea freezes, but that doesn't actually make any difference to anything. We only really put the timer in for a laugh, I should have slowed it down to avoid discouraging players :(.

I enjoyed playing this game, I couldn't beat it however. I kept running out of fuel or into an asteroid. Still I enjoyed the humorous theme. Is the president of space a decedent of Teddy Roosevelt? The graphics and sound were good too!
Here's a video demonstrating how to play: http://youtu.be/T9AY9W6EKfA
Incredibly hard, but I must say fun as well. Best I got is a distance of 1200.

The hint is rather unintuitive; wouldn't have discovered it without your help. Perhaps this would've worked better if there was no rotational thrust at all? Just have the ship spin at all times, with only forward thrust available. Can even advertise it as a one-button game then, which is all the rage these days. :)
I always seem to die, its a shame because I do like my tea.
@kosinus It did occur to make it a one-button game, but unfortunately not until after the deadline. It would be a better game with that change, I agree.

description:
The apprentice wizard seems to have gotten himself into trouble.  How he got locked in the dungeon of a tower alone is a mystery to him (and you).  Help him escape.
EDIT (12/20): Added OS/X Build.  First time publishing an OS/X build from Unity, so if it doesn't work, let me know please!  Thanks
author: Ralkarin
title: The Wizard Apprentice
comments: far too puzzles-for-the-sake-of-puzzles for my tastes.
Pretty fun, loved the ending lolo :)
Good game :D But that catapult at the end is little buged. It didn`t shoot me away :D But good idea... with that broom especially :D
@devwil, Sorry to hear you're not a fan of puzzles!  I admit, it probably did feel intentionally "puzzley" instead of more natural.
Thanks @Wompus and @Ghostik.  The catapult went in during the last 45 minutes.  The broom was my favorite part to code and see it come to life. :)
I really, really enjoyed this! Controls were a bit wonky, to be sure, but the puzzles were my favorite kind: charming, logical, and likely to make me feel like a genius. :)

I like how the game 'opens up,' too, in the sense that you start in the third person and then watch your capabilities expand into first-person manipulation. That makes for some pretty sneaky set pieces, haha.
HAHA that was brilliant! Loved it!
First person should look in the direction that you are looking in when activated.
Just add music, sfx and make it larger and you have something to sell, in my opinion :D

"I feel so alone and amnesiac..." Erm what? Judging from the rest of the game I assume that was supposed to be funny, but it just seems like poor writing, especially when it's the first impression of the game.
Some of the later bits were more amusing though and this is a pretty nice puzzle game prototype.
One suggestion for the gameplay is to make it more obvious when you pick up a key because I picked up the second key without realising it and spent ages trying to find it before I realised I had it.
Thanks for the feedback!  I'm compiling a list (internally) of changes I want to make, but my intention is to keep running with the idea, so keep the criticism coming!

@Snuffypot11, great idea on the first person activation. I think there a few things with the controls that need improved, and that's definitely 1 of them.  Music, sfx, and bigger are definitely on the way. Thanks!

@QXD-me, I agree that it sounds awkward.  I admit that I googled synonyms for "memory loss" and looked for the adjective version of amnesia which turned out to be amnesiac, so I tossed it in and shipped it.  Ya know, 48 hours and all.. :)  I do agree with the key on the 2nd floor, because I watched 2 other people do the exact same thing.  A sound or making the key "pop" out, would be more helpful.  Thanks for the feedback!

description:
The Lonely Sphincter.
You are a giant worm and people want to be friends with you, but you eat them so you are lonely.
Controls: Mouse moves, Space to bite, Z to toggle posterior clenching.
There is no goal. It's just a toy at this point. The bar at the top of the screen doesn't do anything. Make noises with your mouth as you play.
I wish I had more time. There's something really compelling about eating people as a giant worm. The main thing I would like to add is helicopters.
* people will keep spawning forever, therefore it will eventually start to chug your computer.
author: crackerblocks
title: The Lonely Sphincter
comments: I wish they stayed inside of me! nom nom nom!!
I found this to be amusingly fun :)  Work on it more and release !
Something about eating people is just rewarding, especially munching on them to breka their bodyparts off

Remarkably fun! Wish you'd had time to put a goal on it. Are you familiar with the Death Worm games which also feature a giant worm flying around (from underground) and eating people? I think that may be phone-only, but the gameplay is mostly like Moby Dick 2.
Anyway, I hope you do something with this! Good stuff.

Incredibly funny! Really enjoyed playing it for some minutes. :) Some kind of end or challenge would have been nice. The worm could also start smaller and grow over time as he eats. Or he would grow a bit each time the stomach is full, also increasing difficulty at the same time, or something like that.
Wow ! That's a Katamari Damacy Rank game ! Very fun to play !
It just need some way to make it easier to eat people, maybe by sucking people inside for one second when you open the mouse
Funny little game, not really that related to the theme though. It entertained me for a good while.

Nomnomnomnom. This is surprisingly fun! :-D Needs a bigger mouth, and separate controls for the teeth and gullet. Also, it would be nice if the citizens started saying more desperate things over time :-D

description:
You've just woken up, alone, in a dark cavern deep underground. You must attempt to navigate your way out of the caves whilst disarming traps and avoiding the creatures that live within.
Controls:
Press Z whilst standing near traps and switches to interact with them.
Use the arrow keys to move.
Press Esc to quit.
If the music starts to get on your nerves, press M to mute it.
Switch to full screen with F4.
When lockpicking, use the 1-3 buttons to select a pin and then press the space bar to nudge the pins up, you can also click on the pins to nudge them.
Also, read my postmortem: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/2011/12/19/the-deep-postmortem/
author: Cryptoporticus
title: The Deep
comments: There was a lot of actual gameplay content in here - a Lights Out minigame, a cut-the-wires minigame, a lockpick minigame, and the exploration/enemy avoidance game. Unfortunately, none of them were very fun to me. What could have helped are a reset button on the lights-out game and some checkpoints.
DANG THIS IS HARD! Your post mortem is very honest and insightful. Congrats on your first Ludum Dare!
Controls were a little slow and I wasn't a big fan of resetting at the start of the level when I died - but other than that, seemed alright :) Good job with Ludum Dare!
Hard like a hell! :D You should create some checkpoints ;)
The gameplay is really good. I like the system of minigames that you created(especially lockpicking :D).Audio in background is simple but not bad at all. It fits the theme. ;)

description:
Hey everybody, here is my game. Keep the monsters (the evil black things with red eyes) away from the person, who is trying to get too the far right of the screen. Features randomly generated terrain/dirt textures, high scores, and difficulty levels. Enjoy!
Tools:
Sfxr
Game maker 8.1
P.S, please don't use any of my code with out permission from me! :)
author: orseoste7o
title: Alone in a cave
comments: I liked the concept, and also the graphics! Having an option to change the difficulty level was nice, although I didn't feel much of a difference other than the light radius was smaller.
However, even though the concept is good, the game was not quite fun yet. It became repetitive way too fast. Maybe add some levers to pull, buttons to push? The sounds didn't help either.
- The score is always the same, 1 point per level, regardless of the difficulty. Make higher difficulties award more points!
- There is a bug where if a mountain is generated that takes the character off screen from above, the level is considered completed when the character leaves through the top.
- Tweak level generation to avoid those "off screen mountains".

description:
You are in your dream. Your goal is to escape from maze. I have limited amount of battery for your flashlight, but you can find some charges inside maze.
Note:
#Doors and keys are randomly placed every time you start maze.
#Exits can be found only in ONE place, but exit is placed randomly.
author: mastazavr
title: Super Bad Dream
comments: Fun little game. I really like the background effect on your title screen. I found several sets of batteries, and I think the door I'm supposed to open but I never found the key.
I like the ray-casting flash light but am very bad at the game! Anyone have some pointers for me?
Your main goal is to find exit.
Use arrow keys to move and you must find batteries to recharge flashlight.
pretty fun, though possibly rather slow-paced because of the lack of a run button, and i like the lighting/raycasting effects

description:
You wander and explore this mysterious land looking for traces of the people before you.
Arrow keys to move
Up to climb ladders.
Space to jump (Y on Xbox controller)
**SPOILERS**
Ending: You win the game when you collect all three shards and the optional kitten.
Double jumping doesn't work well. If you jump while standing still and then use the arrow keys to move in the air it will be much easier.
author: zazery
title: Statue
comments: Seems like the controls aren't quite right.  Jumping in particular is a bit of a chore and there is one section where it is particularly bad since the only way out is to double jump several times and I can't reliably do it for some reason.  Otherwise I like this game.  I just wish I could get out of that hole.
Pretty average. Very short, faulty controls; also, I thought I had won because the statue was all lit up, but I got no "You win!"
I have rendering problems when I played it. The world is all ultra blocky and pixelated.
I liked it but I'm not sure if I beat it? I got the shrine lit up, went and got the thing that made repeating explosions emit from me, but wasn't sure what to do after that :(
I got a sense of achievement for reaching the kitten thingy
and falling into the void after climbing over the cave system
with a few double jumps. Getting all symbols, on the other
hand, wasn't really rewarding. But I liked that the game was
straight forward, with not too much confusion and waiting.
It's true, the controls are glitchy and too slippery. Double
jumping appeared to deliberately troll me when I was just

description:
Shoot, Stab, Sprint, Save and Shooter your way to victory in this fast paced, action tactical shooter. Take cover from enemy weapons, shoot grenades into the faces of your enemies and save your friends from the brink of death.
Minimum of 2 players, Maximum of 4 player (local multiplayer),
xbox 360 controllers required (for now! Keyboard + online multiplayer not for compo timeframe)
Controls :
Menu  :
Y : Switch Class
A : Ready / Unready
Game :
LB : Defibrillator
RB : Knife
LT : Use Item (Hold to place)
RT : Shoot weapon
LS : Move (press in to sprint)
RS : Aim
Y : Switch weapons
Try and keep your team mate alive. He dies if not revived for 5 seconds. If both team mates die, the other team wins that round. First team to 3 rounds wins.
Each class has unique items, Health packs regenerate you and your team mates health (consumable), fast clip beacons improve weapon reload times for you and your team when in range, and the cover can be placed to protect fallen team mates and give time for reviving etc.
Different weapons (grenade launcher is not implemented in full).
Theme Tie In :
The theme is that it is a bad idea to move away / become alone in the game. Friends have 5 seconds to revive you and if you are alone they probably can't get to you in time. Team focused gameplay so that being alone is a bad thing.
Mac/Linux builds coming in the next few days, plus fixes and additions :)

description:

Lonely Tower is not only about being alone. It's about leaving behind, and the consequences of that.
____________________________________________________
Hi everyone!
I started saturday 7:30 with my game, and at 1:00 am monday I was done. I've only slept 7 hours between those times, wich isn't really special or something, but just to let you guys know.
The first half hour I was looking for an idea, and I'm not sure how I got this idea, but I was thinking about working together, where you have to leave someone behind.
Yes, there are bugs in this game. Some big bugs. But there just wasn't enough time.
I learned a lot of this Ludum Dare. A lot about programming, about planning. I really enjoyed the community and was talking on the IRC chat half of the time. People there gave me the motivation to go on, when I was about to quit.
The most important things I wanted to improve were the level features, and the amount of levels. Right now the game isn't really long, but I hope it can amuse you for 5 minutes or longer.
For everyone who has found the secret kitten: Awesome!
Please send me a message or write a comment about that you found it. But please don't spoil where you found it! Thanks.
Everyone: Thanks for playing this, thanks for reading this, thanks for making Ludum Dare such a great community. I love you guys.
Greetings, Daniel Haazen / Sheep

@iforce2d: The Windows link is an executable inside a 7zip archive. We tried to compress in standard .zip format, but it kept getting corrupted. Sadly, we couldn't figure out how to compile to an executable for MacOSX or Linux (even though most of our dev work happened there). If anyone wants to try creating binaries, I'd be happy to host them on GitHub.

@Saxon Douglass and @ScreamRawr: Thanks! We really wanted to add actual gameplay, add a starry background through a window to indicate the ship movement, and add interactive elements like firing hanging turrets, but we ran out of time and faced a number of speed issues with PyGame. I'm thinking of doing a Pyglet port or rewriting everything in C++ with SFML. Any suggestions? description:
Battle self doubt and the turmoil of existential crisis to overcome the banal and the asinine. Press X to ponder the bleakness of existence.
I took 'Alone' to mean sadness and made a Philosophy-em-up. Enemies are mere bystanders who shout meaningless drivel at you, which drives you to self-doubt. The more doubt you have, the more you fall into depression, represented by a parallel world. To overcome the trials of the real world though you must face doubt and uncertainty.
Basically there are two levels overlaid on top of each other, and they are blended together based on the damage you have taken. You must take at least some damage to be able to walk through the 'happy' terrain and on the 'sad' terrain, but if you take too much you'll die. To complete the level you have the pick up a maguffin (the bit of paper lodged in the side of the hill).
I kind of liked to concept, but ran out of time, as usual. Consequently there is only one level. I spent my last couple of hours polishing the graphics, which came out rather nicely, I think.
I used Flashpunk and Flash Builder for code. The art was done with the Gimp and a cheap graphics tablet. The sounds effects were made in Sfxr and the dreadful music using Wolfram Tones. You can press M to mute the god-awful music!

Arrow keys/WSAD to move
X to interact with the cat(the only thing you can interact with)
N to go to the next level once you're finished with it

comments: Nice and simple. I was most disappointed in graphics by the eyesite.
There were also some playing issues, when they started chasing you, and stuff. But fun overall.
I didn't hear any audio so I left that n/a.

Haha, They were supposed to be people trying to sell you stuff or something, but I didn't end up adding anything to signify that ^-^'

Cool game. The freakish 3-eyed creeps will haunt my nightmares.
I like this mechanic. Really fun.

Open source, cross-platform, art & audio assets included.
author: object404
title: Defend yourself
comments: Lacking in all departments except brain teasing :)

When no-one was looking, Object404 made one really interesting article. He made 1 really interesting article. That's as many as one one. And that's pretty cool.

description:
EDIT: For you who can't download the game. Right click on one of the links above and save it to your harddrive. Unpack the files somewhere - they are in a seperate directory for your ease. Run the only runnable file you have there.
In the game you are a game tester who racing with the others 'how many mazes sold / minute'.
Use WASD to get to the exit of the maze in the bottom-right corner.
Watch out for your stats! If you get stress to much, then you going mad and the game ends. Try drinking water to calm down. It's good to solve hydratation problem too, but it will raise bladder bar. Similarly if you getting tired you fall asleep. This is why you have coffee in the desk. Click it. If it's empty, then you can make another dose by clicking it once more. The game ends when hydratation goes too low or bladder goes too high so maintain them as well. You can go to toilet by clicking in the bladder stat area.
(The following isn't implemented yet... :( )
When going to toilet or making coffee, you can encounter ghosts and hallucinations that raises stress. You need to avoid collision with objects in running mode and click them to conclude they are not real in coffee making mode.
(...to this point.)
Some of the parts are not playable and there is no sound, but It more or less finished in about 12 hours. It contains 2 minigame - the 3rd isn't included sadly and the 2nd isn't playable - and a monitoring system that you need to keep an eye on while you play.
Written entirely in Processing with graphics made with Gimp. Source code is included and well noted - in hungarian - except for the not finished and temporary parts.

author: TaslemGuy
title: Alone with the Enemy
comments: This is a pretty fun game, the controls are tight, and the level design is pretty good.  I got to say, though, I was pleasantly surprised with what you find halfway through, but I won't spoil it for anyone.
Thanks. But it wasn't quite as ready as I had hoped, and I didn't have time to add more interesting level design.
Nice storyline. Good difficulty pacing for such a short game.
Sort of generic, but very competently made and playable. The inclusion of checkpoints alone makes this one of the best designed games I've played yet! Also, surprisingly long! Good work.

Mac users: Windowed mode only. 64-bit build.
Windows users: Coming soon(TM).
author: noffle
title: Alone in the Rain
comments: Haha, this was actually funny. BAM refrigerator to the head! It was a bit too difficult though, got tired of trying at area 3. The collision was a buggy, you can jump inside the wall. Did you use double buffering? I saw some flickering on the middle of the screen.
cool idea, had fun! But really hard :-)
Sound was weak, but better than silence!
Some sort of leap or roll could add an interesting element.

Good fun, but it gets a bit too reliant on chance at the fourth area.  It took about twenty tries to get the right "refrigerator topography" to cross over the first uphill gap, then while going down into the next valley a bouncing fridge flies in from the slope behind me at two or three times the falling speed delivers the killing blow to the back of my head.
The game is deliciously challenging and insane.... I couldn't stop laughing while playing it. Whatever you had when you made this, please send me some!
Ah, there is a strange bug where sometimes the main character will take some damage even if he is not remotely close to a refrigerator... just walking.
Thank you very much for all of the kind words!

description:
Keys:

D. Move right
S: Shoot
SPACE: Jump, Skip Cutscenes
author: Lilleman
title: Alone
comments: With the lack of scrolling, I was really confused. I thought there was an invisible wall for a while. You die a bit too quickly, there's not enough time to get away from a zombie munching on you.
I had the same confusion as wbobeirne, didn't realise you could actually move along to the right until I saw his comment and tried again.
I found the lack of scrolling very very confusing. At first I thought I was just stuck on the side of the building.
I wouldn't notice that this was a side scrolling game if not for the comments. The invisible wall in the middle is ok, if there is some kind of moving background.
Like whilefun I enjoyed the zombie sounds =). Cheers
lack of scrolling is confusing. Hit boxes are way too big, not enough ammo... it's just not very fun :(. Sound is nice, though!
non scrolling background with invisible obstacles in the foreground!!
The player needs more information in order to make decisions.
Is it is now it feels to random.

yea... a few things that kinda match what the other people said, the fact that the background doesn't scroll is annoying,  as is the fact that your health drops to 0 in about 1 second, and the fact that the zombies' hitbox is about twice as large as the zombie itself, also, if you start actually shooting the zombies, you'll die, simple as that... it's easier to just run and jump over them all, even with the annoyingly large hitbox
I had the same confusion many people had with the scrolling too. I liked the sounds though :)

The first thing you receive should be bullets. In my first attempt a zombie came and killed me. In my second attempt I got a gun and one zombie came for a minute. I heard zombie noises though but didn't see any zombies. Visually you could make the area the player must stay in more obvious like others have suggested.

description:
A simple platformer in 13 acts.  Navigate through a dark world but watch the corner of your eye...
Now with 2 endings!
Edit: I've seen from comments that most are getting the 'bad' ending.  I know you aren't likely to play it again for the good one, so here's a hint: use your ears on the seventh level.
If you have problems, please try installing .NET 4:
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=17851
and XNA 4.0 Redistributable Package:
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914
I apologize for the inconvenience.
author: A
title: A Realization (in 13 acts)
comments: Excellent work. Although I got the bad ending, you made a very good job. The music is the best aspect of the game.
- the one-wall cutting knife > original and very handy, you also designed good levels relevants to its use.
- The ??? feedback each time something special happen. simple and efficient.
- The music with the ambient switch near the end ( I had some "Shadow of the Beast" flashbacks when it happened )
- The plane background : It break the contrast with some of your platforms making them difficult to see.

- The very short range of light. It's good for ambience but is very counterproductive for your screen side events like mysterious shadow escaping and other stuff. I notice him just one time, and I had to guess that he *spoil* in the end. ( Maybe my monitor color are too dark ).
Very good overall and huge ammount of work for 48h !

@Benjamin: thanks for the feedback!  The one thing that sticks out to me is the plane background issue-- I realized this pretty late because I was so used to the level setup.  At the last minute I tried to change the brightness/contrast of the assets to make them stand out better.  Unfortunately, I agree, it wasn't quite enough.  As for the lack of light-- I toned that down too near the end.  I thought it was passable, but I knew it would be an issue.  Brightness might help.

I was really impressed by this. Excellent level design, very atmospheric. The platforming was frustrating because the physics were fairly simplistic and a lot of the jumps were fairly unforgiving. Excellent use of sound to create a creepy atmosphere!

description:
A lonely, simple platformer that I hope folks find visually appealing.  It's pretty short, but I like to think it highlights both the lonely and exciting parts of being alone.  I also hope other people find the player death as amusing as I do :P.
Made in Unity Free and Blender by me.  Sounds done in cfxr.  Music created with atrk-bu.py :D.
author: TyrusPeace
title: A Lonely Moon
comments: Nice game. Runs smoothly but, no end?

There's an "end" that says "Teleporting home...", but then I respawn the player at the beginning of the level because I didn't have time for a proper ending cinematic and also because it seemed like it'd be fun to restart the level with dash.

Adding the dash and sinking platforms really helped.
The visual style was super cute.
Great game. I wish it were longer though.
Cool visual style, cute main character. Dashing was fun, and the bits where you move the view back are really cool. Very nice execution overall!
Not a bad game. I like the rectangular prism visual style. It's got some fun moments, and I like the dash ability. I just wish there was more game here.
Nice visual style, and a solid start on gameplay. Good job!
Very cool game, i like how dash work! :)
Shift-key is problematic, as it causes windows-popup
A pretty decent platformer but not much more than that
Zooming out and in was nice idea.
The dash and the zoom in / zoom out are pretty clever ideas.
Charming visual style and simple but well-polished mechanics! Love the attention to detail on the sinking platforms and the dynamic camera framing. Thoroughly enjoyed it.
Box-graphic style is amazing :) Your game is really amusing... but you forgot to respawn all floating platforms after "teleporting home" message :D

author: Maato
title: Tomes of Solitude
comments: Fun gameplay! It takes a second to realize just how powerful the tomes make you!
This was fun! I had to compile the linux version myself, but it worked when i did that. (It was complaining about SDL_Image)

I REALLY dig the oil/fire combo and the strategy that you have to use on some of the fights. The controls could be a bit more friendly for switching between abilities, but this is still pretty fun. Keep working on this!

There aren't enough games that show case how truly powerful wizards are, but this one does. From the very beginning you are using a massive fire spell to take down waves of enemies, and you only get stronger from that. Nice job!
It's a fun little game! I got creamed by that giant goomba thing though.
great fun, I like they way you get you first boss so early
I liked this game. Quite difficult but a nice basic idea. Putting the oil on fire was fun.

description:
A game initially inspired by The Cube (http://www.imdb.com/title/tt0123755/) and Portal (no link required).
It's a short game that can be completed under a minute playable in a browser using javascript.
Controls are:
left and right arrows to move
A to jump
S to use objects.
I've tested the following browsers and they seem to work fine:
* Chromium 15.0.874.121
* Firefox 8.0.1
* Opera 11.60
It does even seem to be working in the Android browser, but I don't have the keys to control my character on my phone :P
If you have any problems with any browser or version, please let me know. I'm interested in the kinds of problems.
Existing code used: require.js underscore.js.
If you can't find how to solve the later stages you can decode the following base64-string for a hint:
UGxhY2UgdGhlIGNvcnBzZSBvbiB0aGUgcHJlc3N1cmUgcGFkLg==
(Decoder: http://www.opinionatedgeek.com/dotnet/tools/base64decode/)
author: FrozenCow
title: The Square
comments: Animation and arrow controls seem really fluid.
Needs to disable typeahead find for the keypresses to work. Every time I press 'A' to jump, the find-in-page box captures all further keystrokes. (Firefox 8.0.1, but any browser w/typeahead, really)
In general, this means returning false from your key handler functions. If you're using a framework, it probably has a disableTypeAheadFind() method of some sort.
I *almost* stopped at the ostensible ending screen.
Fun little game - I played through to the end. The first time I played, something strange happened when I interacted with the switch - I ended up in another room, stuck at the top unable to move.
@mildmojo, javascript performed better than I had expected, so I was surprised about the fps the game could run at.

description:
Requires an HTML5-capable browser. Tested on Firefox and Chrome. Chrome is preferred, it gives better performance and the music loops correctly. The game is designed to be playable even at low framerates, it just might not look as smooth.
This is a game about losing your companions. It's an action RPG with the twist being that you start with a party of five and lose one member at a time until the final quest when you're alone.
You mostly play with the mouse, but use SPACE to cast a spell, and a couple other keys come in handy. There are no in-game instructions, so please read the controls listed on the webpage. If you get stuck, check out the tips.
author: Cosmologicon
title: The Last Adventurer
comments: Good job!  Sort of like Battlehearts.. I like your cute bouncing head guys.
I have some weird framerate stalls in Firefox, not sure what that's about.
I just made my guys roam around in a pack rather than trying to manage them individually.  Then it was kind of frustrating trying to click on them.  So that didn't work out too well.
It was frustrating trying to pick up the little orbs.

Not sure how well it fits the theme... I read the comments on your web page and I like that you went for mechanics rather than plot, unfortunately you aren't really "alone" for most of the game so it still doesn't seem to fit for me.
You can press TAB to select one character at a time. Also sometimes pressing LEFT or RIGHT will make it easier to click on what you want to. Thanks for the detailed feedback, and thanks for playing!
Great idea, the progression is nice too. The controls are really awkward though : they would really require more polish, maybe by adding a visual feedback to target (rollovers)

This game was good fun! I enjoyed the art style how everything moved. I didn't really find the rotating arena useful; I just kept in the default view. It didn't really seem like you were alone for most of the game since you only play the final level solo. But the story behind why your friends left was good, I would have kept it in there even if it is depressing. I had fun playing the game all the way through.
The game is pretty solid and fresh. I think that you "forced" a bit the theme. Still, great work! (and bonus point for using HTML5)
Impressive game, it seems quite well thought out.
The visuals and audio worked well together, and set a good mood for the gameplay, which unfortunately didn't really fit the 'Alone' theme. I get the idea, but it just didn't seem 'Alone'.
The gameplay itself was fun, even if a bit tough. I love the ability to rotate the screen, it adds a neat effect while not really changing the way it plays.

description:
DISCLAIMER: If you are looking for a platformer/arcade game, nothing to see here. If you want a game that challenge your ability to solve puzzles and riddles, with a dark atmosphere and a bizarre story, you are welcome!
A unique experience about loneliness, with a surprising ending. Based in the shortest short-story ever written by Fredric Brown, The Knock features a sliding puzzle, a "cutscene", one character, and requires lots of thinking and observation.
You control a headless person, using the keyboard to move and mouse to click. It's your classic escape-the-room/point-to-click with a twist, in that the last element you need to find is outside the game, as the tip already mentioned.
Please report any bug/problem, but don't write spoilers. This is one of those game that if you know how to solve it before playing, it gets boring.
NOTE: Here's the last tip which you will need to finish the game: "The last syllable is found in the periodic table."
author: Jorjon
title: The Knock
comments: I gave up, then came back, beating it on the next try. Bravo!
It took a minute for me to realize you had to walk with the arrow keys. I didn't get far because the quick time event was too difficult.  :(
Nice mood, but same here, didn't know you could move with the arrows. I couldn't click there now, too fast.
Quick time was hard to catch (actually I gave up) I might come back. Apart from that, looks very interesting environment.
The solution is waaaaay out of where I would even begin to normally think... but somehow I actually got it. Totally confused about the ending, though. Nice concept!

Amazingly, I just "knew" the last syllable.  Once I looked at the ones I already had in hand, it just felt obvious.  I think the time-challenge felt a little to "beat the user over the head," though.  A more subtle cue would have gone a long way.
Thanks for suggesting me the game. It was really interesting, and I think you managed to achieve the mood you were aiming for.

I thought the puzzles were a bit on the easy side. I really didn't like the "hint" -- as far as I can tell, there is no way to figure it out from information inside the game alone. The "check the periodic table" tip should probably be IN the game somewhere.
I really liked the sound effects. I think you could have made a few more graphics so that the "hotspots" in the room change after you interact successfully with them.
Nice the game, and see you next LD! :-)

As a 48-hour effort at an escape-the-room game I think this is pretty good. It's not a genre I care for much, and the gameplay and story didn't do a whole lot for me, but I thought the periodic table puzzle was well thought out. An in-game hint (or hint button) might have worked better rather than spoiling it in the game description, though.

description:
Alone you wake up on the shore of a deserted island only. A flock of strange creatures is shooting through the air.
A giant Pyramid is on the shore and waits for your ritual...
In the beginning I felt like an Island would be a good place to feel lonely and when i started to play around with the music I suddenly realized that being Alone does not have to be desolate and negative like i was thinking at first. It can be quite nice to feel yourself on the inside.. that lead me to abandon all ideas of unfriendly environments and led to the game like you can play it now.
I feel like there could be something more behind the Story of this game, so I will probably keep working on it.
Tools and asset creation:
I have been using Unity3d for development. I am using the built in lensflares I hope that doesn't violate the rules too much. I wanted to make my own but time didnt let me.
also for the textures I have used some photoshop brushes I have downloaded somewhere.
The music and sound effects are entirely made in FLStudio with the help of mostly synthesizers(the waves are entirely synth) but also a few samples i recorded with a h4n1 recorder(footsteps, birdsounds).
Models were done in modo, Textures in Photoshop
I will upload the whole Unity Project in the next days for current lack of bandwith.
Edit:
Instructions:
Use WASD and mouse for movement, q shows the map e hides it there is no mousecursor in the map menu sadly.
The objective of the game is to collect all 6 eggs and place them in the moulds before the the big stones. After each succesful placements you should hear a sound and after all placements the pyramid should have a light on top. Then go to the pyramid then to see the ending.
author: Balooga03
title: The Chosen
comments: Man you are the master of Unity! The art and the music is outstanding, awesome work!

Great work! You really nailed the feeling of the theme and the audio worked perfectly with the visuals. I was very lost though. In the first 10 minutes of playing I feel like I didn't accomplish anything that was intended. its really hard to find time to properly instruct users with such a small build timeframe though.
When I first started, I thought that it was a Jam entry made by a team of at least 4 people, it was not, amazing work!

While artistic feel is excellent, both video and audio, worth of five stars, I'm probably missing something, or there's not much of a gameplay - after wandering around for about ten minutes (even with the help of the map) all I managed was to pick three boulders... So... any hint what to do?
Thanks for all the nice comments so far. I updated the description with some instructions.
Awesome feel and artwork (incl. music!). However I felt it was quite slow.. exploring took way too much time. Put the walk speed up by double at least and it'd be a lot more enjoyable!

Music and visuals really help create an interesting atmosphere that stands out but, I think because I'm really tired right now, it took me quite a while to figure out what I was supposed to be doing and when I did I didn't feel compelled to finish.
I think I might come back and play this later though.

Astonishing!  The visuals and especially the music are perfect for this theme.  I wish I knew what to do before starting and wouldn't spend so much time exploring the beautiful environment.  I event climbed up on top of the pyramid to see the whole island from there.  I wish the player was a little faster that it is now, though.  And it lacks in gameplay even knowing what to do.
It took forever to walk around and pick up those eggs. I saw tons of crash-landed 'birds' as well. Kinda funny. The world was interesting too look at, but it eventually felt very bare.
Amazing mood and style! But the gameplay is quite dull and slow.

It LOOKED good, but looks only take you that far. (that = not very) you moved slow, there was no way to know the controls (there WAS a help screen on the pause menu,but I didn't know how to pause until I I realized that escape was NOT to quit the game). Also you walked WAY to slowly, and I don't think that anyone's head is THAT close tho the ground. all in all a 3/10 (Just cause it looked pretty :D)

Music, textures of terain and water are great but game stared to be boring after minute or two of gameplay. The terrain is too monotonous. Just one big dezert with one hill and some stones. Maybe some more rocks, ruins, old huts or something would help. Why you assigned one key for showing the map and another one, different, for hiding it back? Assigning only one button and then detecting if the map is opened or not is little more elegant way. But lets say opening and closing the map are two different moves :D so you must use different keyboard keys :D.
And you forget to lock the mouse in web version of game. Few times I almost closed the page with game :D
To ending ... lets say I was not expecting flying pyramide :D. Maybe if it slowly sank in to the sea.

"On Top Of The World" is a platformer game where the world
beneath you is falling apart!

Excellent art and music, but I'm seriously confused about gameplay, especially as mouse click doesn't do anything and all I can do is climb over boxes...
Good gameplay with nice difficulty progression.
Only grips is the jerking collision once the level starts falling around the player

Graphics and music are great. The rest is a bit lacking, though... i don't like the gameplay, but thats mostly subjective. Collision detection and the camera are very bad. author: leedo
title: Not Alone
comments: Pretty boring I must say, probably because it was too easy, maybe having multiple enemies come at you at once would be better but apart from that it was an okay game, liked the retro styled graphics and sound.
Despite the fact the gameplay is repetitive, I sort of like it. And the graphics too. The difficulty curve is slow, but it works well.
About firefox, I've found that flashblock kill the game. Unblocking the redish piece of flash should help.
You got 3 stars for innovation from me 'cause it wasn't another platform jumper! hehe.   It was a little too easy and I'm not sure how this fits into the 'alone' theme.  Good job completing.

description:
Nightmares of a wizard was produced by three people, two of which got about 14 hours of sleep, consumed apporximately three pounds of food, ingested a box of ice tea, attended the washroom approximately twice and spent about 58 hours spriting/coding/ROFLing... (not kidding about the acronym there) ...at their work.
NOTE: Make sure you walk up to the writing desks in each level to find out more about the story behind the game! The second desk in the dining room is bugged, however, will be fixed soon!
The uncompressed folder is exactly 200mb but it's worth it so be patient!
------------------------------------------------------------
README FILE-------------------------------------------------
------------------------------------------------------------
Nightmares of a Wizard
==---------------------------==
Hey there Ludum Dare Community member! On behalf of TeamEpsilon and company, I would like the thank you for
downloading our game and would like to urge you to rate it! This game was created for the Ludum Jam and was
produced, from scratch, within 72 hours (almost exactly, more like 71.5).
If you have any problems or questions, please post them in the comments.
Installation/Running the Game:

2.) right click on the folder NoaW and Extract all to a destination
3.) Go to the destination
4.) Double click the executable file to start the game, it may take a second or two to load so be patient.
5.) Play through entire game
---HINT:(There are hidden achievements so to get them all, you may need to go back to certain levels)
6.) Go Rate the game
7.) ???
8.) PROFIT

description:
ISOLATED ASSAULT V1.4
In a world, where the sun burns so furiously you must constantly seek shade...
Where endless cubes fight to get a shot at you...
Where your only weapons are a sword, and a pair of glasses...
Isolated Assault
This 48 hour game was meant to implement the theme, alone, in a new way--you're alone in a cube wasteland until you put on the sunglasses.
The sunglasses make you see things. Enemies. That must be destroyed.
If you can find a shaded zone, (a small building or overhang) you can take off your glasses, making the enemies disappear, and regenerate your health. But, you can't stay there forever. You have a chopper to catch!
The longer you take to find the chopper, the more enemies appear, and the harder it will be to find. It's easy to get lost, so just try to find the shaded zones.
READ THE README.RTF FOR MORE (Controls, hints, humor, etc.)
This is my first Ludum Dare Entry, and I'm exciting to finally be doing this! Good luck to all, and thanks for playing!

description:
Enola is actually "Alone" backwards. You have to figure out why this "backwards" thing.
This is actually an "exploration" game, since it has no combat or any kind of "fast-paced action." The whole idea is for you to roam around and figure out what is that place and why you are there.
The game was made using UDK, and to keep things simple I opted for a first person view (pretty much staying away from modeling and animating a character). BTW, I hate how the binaries turned out so big for such a small game...
This was my first LD and I really had fun, trying to come up with a simple concept really quick and see how it evolved as I developed the game.

description:
Ok, so here's the deal.  I used Construct 2 as my game making software, think of it as GameMaker HTML 5, only better IMO.  I didn't get to any of the sound unfortunately as I had some neat ideas planned.  The premise was supposed to be that an alchoholic verbally abuses his family, and goes to storm out of the house, when he knocks himself out by tripping.  He then wakes up in this prison to find his family frozen in ice.  All he has is his bottle to try and save them.
My ideas were bigger than my 24 hours (stupid work!!) allowed me to implement.  There was gonna be demon family, a good and bad ending, and you'd have to face yourself!  Ooo and there were going to be a couple brief cutscenes.
All things considered, given the fact that this is my first attempt at any kind of game making contest, let alone a timed one, I'm very proud of my entry here.  I hope people find it fun to play, there was no time for bug testing or playthroughs of any kind.  So if it winds up being incompletable then I sincerely apologize.  Enjoy.
You need Construct 2 to view the source.  This can be found at www.scirra.com, they offer a free version of the software.

Arrows - Move
Shift - Jump
Z - Attack

title: Spawn
comments: This is excellent! I love it! Well done!
collision was too punishing for my tastes.

Good game! The graphics are very cute, they're probably my favourite part. The interesting creatures kept me going, but it would be interesting if there was some more variety- I'm not sure in what form, but some threat would be interesting. The sea didn't feel very lonely because I was constantly creating new friends, though. But I get the idea of alleviating loneliness by creating friends. The audio was nice and relaxing, but I think the hitboxes on the dots should be bigger- it was sometimes frustrating eating them.

Yes, I agree with all of that. I wanted the sea to be more sparsely populated to make it feel more lonely, but I was worried it would be too boringâ��especially considering most people would only play for a couple minutes at most.

If I continue to work on this I'd like to add more variety in the the creatures and in the background graphics. I think it would be a lot more fun to explore if there were different areas and things you could discover.

I should have done more user testing with the collision detection. For me it is challenging, but not frustrating. But I played the games many many times while developing, so I should have accounted for the fact that new players would be far less experienced...

I got used to the collision, I think it's fine.  All I would really add is for the species to have behaviour.  And for there to be some kind of logic behind why certain colours create certain species.

I really like the aesthetic, the music and the visuals really work well together.  And explaining the controls, the game name and the creator in the background is genius.  It also created a sense of depth in the water.
After playing for a while, I kind of wanted some form of closure, some kind of end.  But maybe that is a result of conditioning from years of playing more conventional games.
I really enjoyed it.  And I think you should be commended for how complete the game feels.
Next time I will keep in mind this game as an example of design clarity.
Thanks for your comments, I really appreciate it.

I agree about the lack of ending. I really like the _idea_ of having it open ended like that, but the current implementation is definitely missing something. I think maybe having more variety in the creatures and the backgrounds might help you to feel like you are least making progress, even if there is still no ending.

description:
Note that this wasn't an attempt to follow theme.
This game is our attempt to make a competitive time travel game within 72 hours. We ended up with more of an toy than a game (though we'll hopefully get multiplayer working properly soon!
The game is the story of Romeo and Juliet with a twist. After the basic story, the 5 dead characters (Romeo, Juliet, Paris, Mercutio and Tybalt) are given the chance to use a time machine to change the past. Each player takes on the role of one of these characters, taking it in turns to change the past to try and fulfil their objectives.
Controls are as follows:
Press 'left' and 'right' arrow keys or use the scene navigation bar at the top to move between scenes. Text that can be changed is highlighted in green (for original) and red (for changes), with the one on top being currently used. Click on the lower option to swap it in.
You can also 'lock off' a decision by pressing the button on the top right corner. Locking off a decision or choosing a decision each take a turn.
The objectives for each character are laid out in a scene one to the right of the final scene (yeah, it needs a button). It also shows the current progress of each of the characters.
The game ends either when a player gets all 6 of their objectives, or when all the options have been locked out (note that we didn't get to implement this).
Hopefully we'll have the online multiplayer on this will be working soon. Till then, enjoy the single player browsing mode (you can use this to hotseat).
The team was:
Jonothan Usmar
Paul Sztajer
Louise Fisher
Saul Alexander
Xzander Whillier

description:
Update: The soundtrack for One of a Kind is available at my Bandcamp site at http://ddrkirbyisq.bandcamp.com/album/one-of-a-kind-original-soundtrack
Hey everybody!
Here's my entry for LD22, Titled "One Of A Kind".  It's a puzzle platformer based around a mechanic of "uniqueness".  The style is somewhat similar to that of "The Company of Myself".
Note: the opening screen says "I am not very special."  You might miss it if you press buttons and such during load.
=====
OS specific notes:
Windows users: *You should be totally fine.*
If running OneOfAKind.exe doesn't work for you, give OneOfAKind_VS.exe a shot. (You'll need the .NET Framework for that version)
OSX users: *You should be totally fine, as long as you extract OneOfAKind.app from the .dmg file.  Do not try to run it within the .dmg.*
Note, however, that the download is ridiculously large (150MB) and the .app is even larger (>400MB), because I had to fit the entire Mono install in there.  Just delete it after you play.
Linux users: Tao seems to be broken under 64-bit, so I don't know if you can run if you're using 64-bit.  If you're under 32-bit, it runs fine if you install mono.  You need to install the following packages:
mono-runtime
gtk-sharp2
libsdl1.2debian-all
libsdl-mixer1.2
libsdl-ttf-2.0-0
libsdl-image1.2
Alternatively, you can run the windows version using wine.  Simply use winetricks mono2.8 to install mono and you should be good to go.
If you can't get the game to run, you can just watch a video of me playing through the game here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B6WRB7Vl3dE
(Note: Sorry, there's no "quit" button--just close the application window to exit)
If your keyboard is super-duper-weird, you can use Enter instead of Space or R instead of Escape.
======
I don't think the puzzle difficulty is quite too hard...there's a little more you can do with it, but obviously I don't have time for more than there is right now.
Fun fact: if you want to have a shot at editing the levels, you can edit the images under the /lvl directory.  The level[x].png files are the tile maps, while level_backdrop[x].png is the background that gets displayed.
Apologies for any weird glitches or bugs you run into--this was made in less than 48 hours after all (closer to 24, considering how much time I spent flailing around before I actually got started).
Framework/tools used:
-C# with SDL.net and Mono
-Visual Studio 2010 to develop, MonoDevelop for release
-Graphics done in GIMP
-Music in FL Studio
-Sound with FL Studio/bfxr
My first LD, and it was a lot of fun, despite being terribly unprepared for it and freaking out when I couldn't seem to think of any puzzles.
--DDRKirby(ISQ)
=====
Update: the download links now point to v1.01, which adds no content but fixes a bug that causes the game to crash when you reach the ending (yeah...).
If you really want to be strict about the 48 hour guideline (i started late anyhow), you can get v1.00 here:
Windows: http://db.tt/8o9U8Tzz
Linux: http://db.tt/rlrftTaw
OSX: http://db.tt/l85ISncw <- requires Mono + SDL frameworks

description:
Really enjoyed doing this Ludum Dare! The game began from an idea based on "The Omega Man", but it changed a little bit - so the one "last survivor" is now three survivors, but at least they're still "alone" as a collective... except for the mutants. But that's how the film works, isn't it? I don't know I've only seen the Simpsons spoof of it!
Anyway, I don't care about the points, but would /really/ love some feedback. I don't know if it has potential to evolve into something bigger from here and where I could take it, so I'd really appreciate any thoughts you have :)
---
Use the mouse to play. Press "R" or "Escape" to reset if it gets stuck.
Your objective is to get to the checkpoint, marked by a light-blue square towards the top of the map.
Each turn you can move one of your guys by clicking on one of the glowing squares - these represent the squares you can move to. If there are mutants in your line-of-sight then you will have a chance to shoot one of them. Any neighbouring mutants of the same colour will also be killed.
Then it will be the mutants' turn to move! If a mutant moves to a square adjacent to one of your team that team member will be killed.
---
Known issues:
- Line-of-sight isn't spot on, and probably could be made more intuitive/clear/consistent.
- Pathfinding is sometimes wrong. But all the locations enemies go to are within their reach, even if the paths they choose sometimes go through rocks! ^^;

Thanks for the feedback, pythong :) Thanks for pointing out the mutant on the blue square bug!

The players walking through the stones is because I didn't have time to implement the pathfinding into their walking paths - just the bits that tell them which points they can access. It should be easy enough to fix that for post-competition versions.

I'm really glad you liked the graphics! I wanted to do something very simple that I didn't need to animate much, so making the characters out of bean-shapes without feet seemed to make sense. I find that when making shapes look round it often works to draw the big round oval in a base colour, then do a lighter tone and put a small oval somewhere on there - that gives you an idea of where the light is coming from, so it's really easy to imagine where the shadows are coming from. Hope that helps! I drew them in a really old version of Paint Shop Pro with a graphics tablet.
Wow, really fantastic mix-up of genres! Very impressive!
I did run into a bug where the game wanted me to shoot a zombie on the checkpoint, but wouldn't let me shoot or cancel, but otherwise it ran great.
Really love the audio clips, it makes a huge difference. I think you missed out on the opportunity to make zombie noises, however.
Glad you like it! :) Thanks for notifying my of that bug. I'll see what I can do about it (shouldn't be too hard to fix!) Yes, zombie noises were a missed opportunity! ^^;

description:
Your best friend is moving away tonight, so sad. You already feel so alone... like really alone... perhaps insanely alone. Hey, is that your friend? I bet you can catch them!
Whew, I had to cut quite a few things (including animating the player's arms, who needs arms...) but managed to finish in time.
This is my first flash game, I started learning flash this week and it has been a lot of fun. (This is also the most 'complete' game I've worked on so far, Thanks for the motivation!) I'll probably continue working on it a bit more to explore Flixel and to see if this gliding mechanic would be fun with better planned obstacles.
Note: This game includes the mandatory kitten! (vote for meee!)
Controls: Mouse movement controls pitch while gliding, click to Jump. Escape to reset the game. The cursor isn't loaded at first but you can still click play. (the button will light up when you are over it)
Gameplay Note: You can jump higher by pulling up with the mouse, but you will be sacrificing run speed. You can regain some run-speed if you dive mid-jump.

Nice entry, I liked the forrest. The sliding was bit annoying especially if you slide slowly into the water and suddenly you're dead. I would have liked to hear the wolfs breath and paws on the snow would have made an even denser athmosphere.

description:
(Since the blog link is currently broken, you can find it here if you want to judge "Community" :: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/author/dr_soda/ )
The Hug-Monster (-o^_^)-o can never get enough love or hugs, and is always happy to see you.  Unfortunately, it's a little too excitable and at times doesn't seem to know its own strength.
You  on the other hand are small and fragile, and most definitely want nothing more than to be left alone, especially from the big, scary Hug-monster!

The Hug Monster

author: dr_soda
title: HUG MONSTER
comments: Hug monster, what a creep! Personal space!
