That smiling thing will be in my nightmares :-P. No, imagine: a *HUGE* bus-sized smiling monster, constantly flapping his gigantic arms, to squeeze you in a fatal hug with misleading cuteness and a force strong enough to throw away whole ... stuffs!
quite like the stick graphics.. and the acceleration mechanic :)
This is THE TRUE SPIRIT OF LUDUM DARE.
I liked that in some levels I was able to "defeat" Hug Monster by tricking him into running off the level.
Overall an awesome game. Lot of fun, the way the character accelerated as you kept moving was pretty cool, but some of the jumps were very tricky because of it.

Thank you everyone who's given feedback on gameplay elements in particular.  In my evenings I'm working to polish up some of the rough edges you're all pointing out and plan to re-release it as a more finished product with more of the features I considered "nice to haves" while I was concepting this.
And for those who enjoyed it, thank you for your kind words. :)
Re-release *outside* the LD site, that is.  Obviously I won't change anything about the linked project above. :)
Found the controls pretty awkward to use, bit of making them a bit less frustrating and it's spot on :)
Hey! Thanks for pointing me to your game!
The hug monster is so cute <3, although I was a bit sad every time I saw him happily jump off a cliff to his death :~(. Poor hug monster.

I liked the idea, but I'm having difficulties playing the game. First, the controls are really sticky. It is very hard to gauge how much you need to run and jump to get atop a platform, and, when you fail, your guy gets stuck in mid air.

Second, the fourth level (third?) is a bit buggy. It is the first one where the hug monster does not begin behind you. When I try to reach for the house, it floats to the skies and disappears. Then if I die to try again, the house is not there anymore and the level is not winnable :-( </3
Hope you can solve your problems with sound, and thanks for talking about other people's games! :-D
The character should face where the player is pointing, not where he is running too - it gets a bit easier to tell your brain that the character is trying to stop that way

I realized last night what would happen in level 4 too late to fix it.  You're right that there's a bug, *but* It was actually designed to float away if you hit it with your head, but what I forgot was to reset it when you restart the level.  If you jump down onto it from the top you can actually see the platform fall down.  Part of me likes this, but part of me also doesn't.  Maybe sfx would indicate that it floated away because you bonked it out of reach?

Anyway, the "I can't win the level anymore" has been resolved in the version I'm working on currently, but I don't think I can really submit that now and still be in-bounds in terms of the compo rules.  Would a bug fix like that be by-the-book?

I've gone ahead and patched the bug.  Thanks for pointing this out to me and for all the feedback!

description: In Abandon, you play as an individual who has lost track of their friend while wandering an empty tower. Your friend has dropped a few items along the way, which you can gather while trying to track him down. The game uses simple W-A-S-D controls for movement and the spacebar for jumping. If you die, press any key to reload the last checkpoint. The game was made using the Unity game engine, Blender, GIMP, bfxr and Audacity.
author: Acheron
title: Abandon
comments: Very cool game! I even got a vertigo effect when on the high parts of the castle... and then died when missing a jump...
Regarding art, the architecture is very nice, though having simple white objects without textures didn't really fit with the land.

For me, the mouse was EXTREMELY sensitive, so it was really hard to move properly. The physics also felt a bit weird. I didn't collect all the items, mainly because I couldn't be bothered struggling with the mouse sensitivity for 30 minutes.
Also, that big dome object near the player's friend didn't seem to have a mesh attached; I could walk straight through it.
Nice architecture indeed. Feels a bit static

I like the building its really nice, the soundeffects are quite harsh, and the lighting is somehow strange i suppose the character is carrying a light. also when i fall of a height it freezes for a second or so and the image is glitchy.. nice execution could be improved a lot with a little more attention to details.
Very cool feel to the game. Made me feel all explorator-ey.
Aside from a couple non-serious graphical blips, this was a fantastic exploration game.
Very pretty. First thing I did was walk off the edge...
Tuning jump is one of my least-favorite things about rolling/managing a character controller... so frustrating!

I think your game did a good job at making me feel like I knew what to do. At first I had to find my friend and then I had to search the world for clothing items and bring them back to my "friend". The concept of having to do challenging jumps and not getting lost seems okay.

However I felt that the world was too big. I like the ideas of fractals and huge structures but I'm not particularly interested in having to walk repeatedly back and fourth great distances. It feels like a waste of time.
The jumping felt floaty. I'm not sure if this is preset by Unity but I remember a game from last LD that was the same in that regard. Put some more effort into that since it's easy with Unity.

Your text adventure actually looks pretty good. Nice choice of fonts and background.

That said, there were quite a few bugs, and the game was almost unplayable to me due to them :-( It seems that most of these bugs comes from you treating every action as a room. I can tell that by typing "look" after a common action, and getting the text of that action again. For example, when I was in a place with two doors locked doors north and south from me, if I typed north, I would get "that door is locked". Then typing look would get that same message - I would have to use "back" to return to my previous room.
A more sensible approach would be to have "rooms" as locations with a number of possible actions in them, so you separate walking around from performing those actions.

The exploration in itslef made me think of a more quick and edgy version of japanese games like Yume Nikki and derived fangames. The good thing here is that the map is generated randomly each time, inducing strong replay value, and the many items serve a definite purpose to unlock the endgame.
The footprint idea is really good, and well executed, you do really feel alone in this one,

description:
Long ago, there was a great warrior. None of his opponent could survive under his blade. His body was immortal because he had stolen the cloak of invisibility of the Death. As a revenge, the Death cast a curse on him - not only the Death, nobody in the world could find this great warrior. Year after year, the loneliness made the warrior going crazy - now, there was only one thing left for this immortal one, fight against his spell-cloned body.
This is a First-Person fighting/action game.
IMPORTANT: You need a mouse with 2 buttons(Left & Right) to play this game. Touchpad of NB is not suitable for this game.
============
Controls
============
#Attack
The success of attack depends on if you could land it on your opponent's vulnerable bits. The enemy's vulnerabilities will be exposed when he has lost his defense stance(attacking, blocked by your shield). And there are 2 type of vulnerabilities: Far & Near(with red circle in it). Slashing attack can only reach the near vulnerabilities while piercing attack could reach both.
##Piercing: Click with LMB(Damage: 1-3)
##Slashing: Drag with LMB(Damage:1)
#Defend
The enemy will attack your head, chest, or legs, so you need to position you shield at the right height while defending. When enemy begins attack, one part of the screen(upper/mid/lower) will flash red to inform you where he is targeting. Use your RMB to defend yourself as follows:
##Shield: Hold down RMB at the red screen area.
##Block: Hold down RMB just before the enemy's weapon reach your body! If you push RMB too early, blocking will not be triggered but you can still defend successfully.
============
Hints
============
If you've defeated the warrior, the attributes of him will be randomized in the next game. The "Attack" attribute may be a little puzzled. In this game, it means the percentage to land a power attack which could make the camera shake a lot even if you defense successfully.
This game seems quite challenging at start, until you've learned how to attack efficiently and master the art of blocking.

author: Erifdex
title: Transposure to the Void
comments: It's a little tough to find things to say because it's not very gameplay-driven. Maybe if there had been some way to have the narrative unfold as the player interacts with the world, rather than it being an animation with a short sequence in between, it might have been more engaging. The music, however, added a lot and really helped sell the mood.

This is a tough game to review or even rate.  I'm not sure if it qualifies as a game.  But I know it has worth.  To say what you should improve really depends on what you were aiming for. You said you were aiming for the emotion in this one.
I think you conveyed emotion, possibly of being alone.  The emotion I picked up from this was teenage depression, self pity.
I think the art style in the room works really well.  Outside of the room it felt less consistent.  The buildings seemed rushed, along with the clouds.

As for the poem itself.  This isn't a poetry jam so I won't rate it based on the poem.  But this game was essentially a poem.  It wasn't my taste in poetry.  It was predictable and metaphors were scant.
I think this is good though, I am glad I played/watched it.  And I'm interested to read your post mortem and see what you were going for when you made it.
Nice work, and keep it up,

The cave generation is kind of dodgy. A lot of quick fixes to make it work *most of the time*, but there's a small chance that it'll only generate a small cave. The weird enemy spawning is based on a few things... firstly, if you're in a small area, the closest valid area for a monster to spawn could actually be quite long in walk distance. Monsters have timed life, since the next wave won't spawn unless there are no monsters, and the number of them in a wave is based on the total number that you've killed (to a maximum of 20). The length of the game is based on the game's timer instead of number of waves fought (in retrospect this was a terrible idea).
All of these together make a kind of inconsistent experience!

Blasting apart those monsters was a good time, and the darkness helped enhance the feeling of being alone in a cavern. Not sure I liked the choice of yellow for the cave walls, though.

description:
This was my first Ludum Dare, and I must say I'm somewhat surprised that I got anything done given how busy this weekend has been.
In between studying for a philosophy test, practicing for a physics quiz, going to driving school, and going to an interview, I really only had around 8 hours to work on it. It will only last you 5 minutes, but I can guarantee that what you read in it will last you for a very long time. It only has one gameplay element (figure out the password), and the rest is a loose story. This was my first LD, and I realized how little I knew about programming, especially seeing what others have made.
I would appreciate any advice on more efficient or better programming methods (perhaps a generous soul would look at my poor, aching source code and tell me what I should have done instead?). Does anyone know a good way to map in java OTHER than defining rectangles where you can/can't go. Better question: can someone tell me that way? I'm sure I did a very poor job of it.
In perspective, though, I'm happy with it! I learned a lot about game programming, and I'm hoping to do much better next time. Thanks for giving it a look! I hope you try it and enjoy what little it has to offer. Have a nice day!
Controls:
Use arrow keys to navigate the menu, space to select/interact. Mouse is only used when entering the code in the first room.

description:
Whilst your owner is away, you, a black cat, have been left to guard
the family's lettuce patches. It's currently breeding season for rabbits,
so there are lots of hungry kittens about.
Controls are very simple, the black cat will always follow your cursor,
and the rabbits will be avoiding the black cat whilst also trying to eat
all of the lettuce. The rabbits hate being seperated, so what you need to
do is try to split them up so they get scared and run away whilst simultaneously
preventing the lettuce patches from being eaten!
All game code is written in C++, and my own engine, Psybrus, was used.
PS: It is known to work in Linux under Wine, and also runs in OSX with Wine.

description:
You are stranded alone, in an asteroid field, and must gather parts to repair your warp drive. However...?
This was heavily inspired by the amazing Metrojd mini-game by Daniel Remar. I wanted to do a lot more with it, and explore the concept more deeply, but halfway through I had to fix a broken audio engine and then realized my shader pipeline was much more broken than I had initially thought.
This game uses OpenAL for sound.
UPDATE: No more crash on exit or alt-tab breakage. I've fixed a couple of bugs in the graphics engine, optimized the physics and turned off vsync and yielding by default (although you can still change the settings in config.ini). I've also made it so you can turn off the audio and enable small nebulas, which makes run a lot faster on integrated GPUs.

comments: Okay, some genuinely terrifying moments in there. Well played.
Were there plans to have more in the way of breakables/enemies or some such? I basically didn't shoot at all in the end.
What I liked the most was the absolute removal of both screen and audio at the event horizon, it made it even more scary.
I had to turn of postprocessing (at least I guess post=1 means that) - otherwise screen would show anything for just about half sec and then get all white.
Quits when I get swallowed by the black hole (i got tired of running away from it, so I tried what's going to happen) - is that intended, or bug?

That's a weird bug with the postprocessing, I haven't seen that anywhere else. It seems similar to the other bug I had but it wasn't caused by postprocessing. The game is supposed to quit when you get swallowed by the black hole though.
I tried so hard to find all parts, but each time that black hole swallowed me :( Why does it follow you? That's unfair! ^^
Anyway, really good idea, graphics, audio and mood. :D
Nice game! The black hole is scary, but easy to get away from once you know what to expect. Could be more challenging.

You should add timing score, to add some re-playability :-)

I really liked the black hole, it was a neat audio, visual, and gameplay effect. However, the game as a whole was pretty straightforward and easy. You get the first core, freak out when the black hole first appears, and then the rest of it is just a leisurely stroll through the asteroid field to collect the remaining cores. It'd have been nice if there was something steadily ramping up the difficulty as you played... like the black hole getting bigger or faster, or more of them spawning nearby... or even just spawning the new cores close to the black hole.
The ending was also rather abrupt... a victory screen would have been nice, because getting kicked out of the application as soon as I won was pretty jarring.

description:
I wanted to write more running inner dialog for the game but my brain parts fused after the all-nighter. Play it. Preferably in Firefox 8 (reportedly works fine in other browsers but the graphics might be blurry). Try to figure out how to passively use the different light sources and the impact they have on the barely perceived threats. If you want more info (including spoilers) and a peak at my workflow check out the text doc I also uploaded.
Things I would change. HTML5 may be ready for "real" games but my particular HTML5 framework is not. Wish I had switched to Flixel once I realized the game was running at 4fps on my 1st gen iPad. The game has touch controls but good luck using them at 4fps. Collision detection was quick and dirty (broken in MobileSafari, probably because of a precision bug). Could be more forgiving. Keyboard input is unidirectional with the most recent key canceling simultaneous keypresses.
Things I'm proud of. I used cellular automata to generate levels dynamically and A* path finding to ensure they're solvable before presenting to the player. Check the source for references. Pretty happy with the art too.
Sleep now.

author: Bullseye8841
title: Phil: A Search for a Friend
comments: That was actually pretty good, but it needs an end to it...
Thx, we agree completely, but we're glad you enjoyed it! lol
Hey guys, congrats on your first stressful dare. :D Thoughts that ran through my mind as I was playing:

It's obvious that a lot of art time was spent on characters and the eating animation was really cool, but the missed visual details really stole my attention: people levitating 5 inches off ground, really big doors and trees, and lack of reaction to me.

Eating is cool, but by itself, just leaves me wanting more to the gameplay. From what I can tell, it's really bare-bones without any sense of challenge (was there another level?). Out of loneliness, I jumped off to the endless pit on the right.

And speaking of which, the theme was not conveyed well (something I regretted with my entry too). If it was a game about a zombie wanting to be friends with people but finds out that everybody he hugs just plays dead and ignores him--even if he eats them--or something. But you have to tell your players that. Some way of expressing his loneliness rather than just a description (especially because the game's music clashes so much against that).

All in all, I can definitely see where your heart was. You guys did a solid job for your first dare, and for future entries, I recommend really focusing on the theme itself and making use of your new time management skills to give yourself plenty of time at the end to make the experience more polished. As for continuing this game, I would really like a lot more feedback and a lot more challenging elements. I think you guys have a pretty nice set of mechanics set up, and I wish you the best of luck going forth. :)

comments: There were some issues, like having no way to recharge the bullets if you used and picked them all and you got spotted, and the game way too hard, but i guess the game was ok...
I'm quite sure my game bugged in some horrible way - I could walk through walls and none of the items I picked up did nothing. 32-bit Windows 7 here.
That's odd Hempuli, the game should run on all platforms, including Android if i would have had time to make onscreen analogs.
Fun idea! But it seems a little bugged. I got stuck multiple times where I couldn't move anywhere.. :(
What format is the game? I downloaded the linux version and it's a .exe so I'm not sure exactly how I'm meant to play the game.
Um, I was able to cross walls and the guard never saw me at all...  Windows 7 32-bit here.
Works now. Thanks for the fix!
The crossing walls shouldn't happen. My dropbox was giving the wrong version. Try again :D Mjiig, I put up the linux link. Didn't realise that Linux couldn't use .exe
Good iea to make a stealth game with the theme. No bugs here but it was so hard I did not manage to reach the end.

A neat idea but well beyond my capabilities. I died about 10 times on the first corner before I got any further, and gave up pretty soon after that. Also, I found that the gun didn't really do anything, hitting the guards with it achieved nothing.
Thanks for getting a proper linux build up though :)

Ah, the guns were a last minute addition as you can see in the timelapse. I was planning to have pickpocketing for gun/knife and it'd be required to get through some levels... although time told me otherwise. For the difficulty, this came with my hate of block movement. If I were to make the movement based on 50 increments rather than 2 increments, It'd be easy to get around those corners. (Stick character movement to block grid, one block a time)

Pretty difficult at times, I couldn't' get past the second level, I got up to the door and it wouldn't open for me so I got stuck. I couldn't work out how to open the first door either, it just seemed to open after lots of random clicking and button mashing.

There are hundreds of other things there... closed mouth pacmans or whatever. This is hard as crap, too. I had no idea that I was being spotted. I just thought that it was glitching up or something. The stealth idea is refreshing amongst all these other games, but several things are holding it back.
@Jigxor: The doors are opened by clicking them when you have the required keys. Not sure if this was working wrong for you, but it seems to work for me just fine.

@SonnyBone: Closed mouth pacmans, or lack of art skills prison guards ;) Whatever you want to call them. The difficulty was mainly because the character moved freely around rough corners. If it was grid movement it would be 100x easier.

author: JH
title: First

I'm not sure how 'alone' I felt, swimming around the world with 30 clones, but the atmosphere of the game is certainly very good. I felt kind of bad when I noticed that some of my spawned lifeforms were actually dying :(
The game is great, maybe a bigger collision box for bonus would make it more fun to play. The control are ok like that, improving the maniability by upgrading is cool. nice soundtrack too !
I really enjoyed this.  It was beautiful.
One of the best entries I've played. Amaaaazing work. I actually wanted to finish it and see what happened. Great, great job! :)
Very nice game - lots of depth, themes etc... Outstanding!

description:
So I got the game name from http://videogamena.me/
There's no sound and most of the artwork are just placeholders. But I found this to be an enjoyable game. There are highscores on the main menu aswell :)
The source code is bundled with the game download, the game will run on practically any system with a JVM (Java basically).
Just to clarify, it says highscores, it should say scores. It keeps track of your last 6 games' score, and remembers the highest one that you've gotten so far!
I did intend on there being multiple weapons and enemies, but time got away from me :(
If the game doesn't open, and it says "Java is unrecognised", try this download.
http://bit.ly/ubr5DI
Make sure you open it with Java, which should be located roughly here "C:\Program Files\Java\jdk1.6.0_26\bin\".

Nice game, with puzzles that are easy-enough not to spend hours on, but which still require a few seconds of thought before being solved. I'm not very satisfied with the ending: I was expecting more from this otherwise very polished game! Nevertheless, I enjoyed playing it, well done!

Well, due to my lack of graphic skills, I didn't put any texture and / or images in this game (maybe next LD, I will do it with some friends :D ).
The fact is, it was the gameplay (having the ability to turn the "motors" and not the "ship" itself like in any other space game) that interested me.

When I finished that part, I did not find anything that would "suit" very well with this so I quickly coded a score engine and a "poping" star system (star = circle ... lol ) and posted the game because I still find that the gameplay would be pretty fun if there was something else behind it :) . description:
IMPORTANT: When you play a game, everything will run perfectly and smoothly for the game host, but the clients will see some lag.
This was my first Ludum Dare entry, and I think I did OK (but I can do much better next time).
The game is a multiplayer mini-RTS, where you play as Al and use clones of yourself to fight. You believe you are the original Al (Al One), but so does your enemy.
Use WASD to move Al and click to create a clone. Clones attack each other when they get close, and they can attack you, too. You win when you kill the other Al.
I spent a good 24 hours pacing around looking for ideas, and got about 7 hours of sleep for the last 3 days. I can certainly say my brain is not functioning at max capacity right now.

author: davidwparker
title: The Social Network
comments: Well, the game is really too easy.  I like the concept, but all you do is continue to click your hardest attacks until the person is insulted enough.  Then buy the next best insult or whatever and continue.  If you run out of energy then just choose the next lowest.  Played for about 30mins and was entertained.  But, I probably won't play it again. Good job. I love the concept.  There needs to be more to the game though than just throwing insults.  Some insults should heal the other player (if they hate their mom and you say, "your mom" that should heal them.)  Give the attacks meaning instead of spamming the hardest hitting attack.
Thanks for the feedback, asharwood. That was definitely one of the things that I felt was lacking (depth, other than just spamming attacks, as you mentioned).

description:
Team "Underpriced Donuts" proudly presents "The Lonely Knight - The Dark adventure".
Prologue
Once upon a time, in a land far far away, there lived a knight who was very lonely. He did not have a real horse - so lonely he was.
He was spending his days over a pint of ale since he did not see a purpose in his life. One dark and rainy day he was sitting in the tavern "Mug of hero", sinking his miserable life in alcohol as usual.
When he finally lost count of how much ale he has drank his blurry attention was captured by a  strange conversation.  He heard that a daughter of a King was recently captured by a band of necromancers from the Spookywood forest, lead by the Evil Wizard Magazu al'Thaal.
Only a true hero would have the courage and the SKILL to take the epic quest and save her people whispered. And, as a nice side bonus, the King promised her hand and a little bit more than a half of the kingdom to the savior.

If it wasn't randomly generated, then I would suggest trying to mix up various things so the player doesn't do the same thing over and over again.

Not being able to go backwards was a little annoying, also no real explanation that shooting the barrels several times will make them disappear. Those things seem to really be holding it back. Other than those, nice game for 48 hours.

Well, it's all a matter of underestimating the amount of time everything would take. First of all, there isn't any real random level generation. It has a set of "fragments" that it assembles in a "random" order, I had no time to test how random this really was. Also, I ran out of time to create enough of these fragments for it to really work, there's only about 20 of them available to the level generator, and for some reason it feels like half of them never shows up in the game.
The not being able to go backwards was first a quick hack to avoid refactoring the collision detecting code, and the idea was to cover it up with a "there's no going back" part of the "story".

The menu, gamestate and pretty much everything that isn't the core game mechanics was slapped on the last 90 or so minutes, There was no time either to add real explenations for how everything works, I was writing the menu system when I hit my coding deadline (as I needed to make the windows port as well...)
But yeah, for being my game ever (well, excluding the ones I did in game maker 9 or 10 years ago), it did turn out better than I expected considering the time limit.

Hey guys. This is my game for Ludum Dare #22, "Cave Wanderer".
It's for the Sega Master System.
The file you want to run is ld22-gm.sms.
Feed that into an emulator. Here's two recommendations.
The best one for accuracy is probably Kega Fusion:
http://www.eidolons-inn.net/tiki-index.php?page=Kega
Although I quite like Mednafen, and it's plenty accurate enough:
http://mednafen.sourceforge.net/
There is no defined plot. Invent one yourself to explain the aloneness.
Oh yeah, compilation / assembly instructions.
You will need WLA-DX (possibly built with a maximum string length > 64) to build the .z80 source code.
You will need Python 2.x to build the music.
It would help if you had GNU Make or something like that.
Finally, if you wish to modify the .it files, you will need SchismTracker. I don't have the .it file for one of them.
Of course, if you're just wanting to play this game, open up ld22-gm.sms in an emulator.
If you have any questions, read the README.txt file included before asking me.
UPDATE!
3 days after the 48 hours ended, I ported it to the Sega Mega Drive! (albeit with one glaring bug)
That port can be downloaded here: http://gm.64pixels.org/stuff/ld22/cave_wanderer_smdport_beta1.zip
Please don't use that version for judging.

description:
This is my entry Afrocity Atrocity.
Controls:
ARROWS - Drive
CONTROL - handbrake
Objective:
tl;dr - Find the red gem in 'night mode'
Wreck havoc to get the havoc meter to the threshold.
Then, you have 5 seconds to build up havoc more!
The more havoc you are able to wreck, the more time you can spend in Atrocity.
Min is 5 seconds, full bar is 20 seconds.
Use the time to look for Atro Gem while in Atrocity!
It appears somewhere else each time.
Reach it in time to win!
Don't crash cars in Atrocity, or you run out of people.
When there is no one around to wreck havoc upon, you lose.
Don't get alone!
Plot:
I had this plot... but I ran out of time. So my cutscenes are 100% TV static and no main menu or start screen.
EDIT: Ok, I will write this them I thought of. It's not like I made it up just now. I had it in mind but I ran out of time to include features such as plot, front end etc. Anyways, here we go!
You live happily with your girlfriend in Afrocity, when suddenly she disappeared. He went out looking for her, noticing that despite the city is full of people, they are all... flat! Literally and with regard to real life and 18th century sentimentalistic style he realised it's just a bunch of paper-mache figures. They just go back and forth. The Afro guy (I didn't actually think of a name for him) went rage! And suddely, he ended up in a strange place with a glowing red gem around that evoke within him that he really wants, NO! Needs it! In a flash he was back in reality And realised that once he gets the gem, he gets the girl. Not pondering too long about it, he started to wreck havoc in the city to get to the plac ewith the red gem!
tl;dr - You are alone in a full city. Everyone is just a scenery. Just like real life.
There! And there was absolutely no way I would manage to even write this within the time limit :P

The game is for iOS (and now ported to OSX) and was built using cocos2d and chipmunk.
You can get the iOS app through testflight:
Register your iOS device: http://bit.ly/gU8RCH
Download the app: http://bit.ly/u7gyan
You can get the OS/X port from the OS/X link above.
What Next?
We are going to submit Four Hats to the App Store after Apple's holiday break and will continue development on additional levels and characters if people enjoy the game. We original pictured a much bigger game, but the 72 hour time limit restricted what we could build.

description:
Nowhere Man is a resource management game.  You walk out of your house one day to find that you are the last human being.  You have to scavenge food, plant crops, and find medicine in order to survive.  There is no ending, it's more of an endurance match to see how many days you can stay alive.  Honestly, it's mostly luck.
Sorry if the UI is a bit bland, spent all my time on little features and didn't get the time to add much polish.

description:
"When I think of term "alone," I think of the
blessing and curse of the human condition. As
subjective beings, we can never totally get
outside of ourselves, and no one else can
truly get in our heads.  We are, each of us,
lone thinking things.  The blessing is the
freedom we have in this space between our
ears; the curse is the loneliness.  Our art
and creations can be seen as expressions that
can never be entirely comprehended, or as
gifts to others to use their freedom and
experiences to absorb that art and make it
their own.
Anyway, what a load of shit."
-- Robert Ellis
author: robitstudios
title: Jump Alone
comments: I don't even want to imagine the harder difficulties :P

Being able to pass through things while jumping is a nice gameplay idea, but not being able to see platforms during the jump just makes the game artificially difficult and takes away the fun, at least for me.
Q or esc should quit the game?
Perhaps offer a slight ghosting or fading away of the platforms in the alternate view? for an easier mode
The movement/acceleration thing sometimes was a little annoying, needs tweaking.
Sounds/tune/graphics everything artistic and idea was all spot on though. Just needed gameplay polishing. :D
I only found alt f4 works and to me that's inappropriate way to shut down?
I like the idea of double-view for jumping, but the difficulty is too high.
I think the disappearing mechanic is neat(and using the bombs on unseen enemies was pretty cool). The art was nice and I liked the dynamic music!

My problem isn't that the game is difficult, it's that it's unforgiving. With a mechanic that guarantees me a spiky death on most plays it's troublesome to start over from the beginning after every mistake. In most die-by-spikes games you have very fast and responsive movement, so you don't lose much time, but this game requires very slow and thoughtful movement since you spend half of it blind. It would be nice to have either a health bar or checkpoints to mitigate that. It's annoying that moving platforms never reset, so my only option is to die when I've botched one of those segments.
Still, an interesting game, it'd be fun to see more of it.

@nate427 Yeah, I was worried about how punishing it was for the player, which was why I put in the light things.  If I'd not have spent so much time messing with the sound stuff, then I would have tackled with some balance issues like that.

After eating too much candy, your difficult-teen-years kid smashes the precious family heirloom mirror and takes of into the woods. You take off in pursuit but the short day time makes things really hard to see at night, so unless you have a good memory you may find yourself running out of the extremely short-lived puff-lights very soon, and then writing silly stories in the game comments while waiting for sun-up. Eventually though you will find that little rascal and send him to his room with no supper.

description:
A simple platformer where you play as a duckling that has been left behind by it's mother, and is now all ALONE. Yeah, not the most deep, creative, or interesting use of the theme, but it works.
Here are the controls, even though most are mentioned in the game:
Move: Left/Right
Jump: Up
Flap (can be done three times per jump): Up (in the air)
Swim: Up/Down/Left/Right
Restart Screen: R
Quit: Escape
This is my first LD entry so I didn't try for anything too complex. I hope you like it, anyway.
Find the secret kitten!
The results are in, and I got in the top 100 overall (#89). Cool! Plus, I got #20 in fun. Wow, that's amazing! Thanks so much to everyone who played, rated, and commented on this game!

description:
My main aim with this game was to tell a story, which I believe I have achieved.  It's an extrapolation of feelings that I sometimes get.
Please play to the end of level 4 (it won't take long) because the vibe changes.
Thanks for playing!
Enjoy!
Tech Note: I made this in a language called Monkey which is a cross-platform language by the same people who made the Blitz3D/BlitzPlus/BlitzMax.  I hadn't properly used it before, so this weekend was as much about exploring the language and making a basic engine as making a game. I even made that font from scratch!  I chose the Flash export from Monkey for ease of use, but it's just as easy to make an HTML5 game, or iOS/Android game, or even PC/Mac executable.

As you say it's not really a game so, personally, I wasn't really driven to persevere with the 'experience' for more than about 5 minutes (sorry!). But I like the idea and it fits the theme very well! Well done.
I think this game is hilarious.
Hmmm, you might want to resize the game area. At the moment I need to scroll the browser up and down to see everything. Can't get the whole game on a screen.

description:
Team Helmet present their first entry to a Ludum Dare.... Void
Play the part of one of three characters and find yourself in the most amazing of space adventures. Be amazed by full colour graphics, and high quality mono sound, and most importantly find your friends...
Credits:
Darren Royle (AKA Cap'n Royles) - Programming, cook, provider of Tiffin/Taffin

Team Helmet!
author: royletron
title: Void
comments: Wow the game is really cool. I liked the graphics and the story. Also flying through space was pretty fun. I am not sure what hitting those robots too often would have done however. The only thing that I did not like, is that the music gets very annoying quickly.
that was pretty cool. nice graphics and sound. story reminded me a bit of portal, with the artificial intelligence going haywire and such. very nice.
The only minus is that there were robots in the space... I think you should have put something else that's dangerous that isn't "someone" if you know what I mean :P
And by the way, before I actually completed the game, I actually thought about the ending the exact same way that's in the game. So I found that funny! :D

Hmm, apparently there is a different ending depending on if you are fast enough to get to the airlock at the end. I have yet to find a "good" end, but the person on one of the endings suggests there's one.
cool little game, audio got annoying after a while, played through it twice with two different endings, great graphics and a nice story, good job!
The first thing I saw was a typo (cyro bed), which reminded me about a typo in our game. Empathy achieved in the first second!

description:
Jisus christ. I did not expect to be done this late. Even though this is my first ever LD I thought I would be more effective
I finished the game The Lost Viking a bit different than first planned. Since I don't have any prior experience with this I had no idea which parts of the development would take the longest. I know that now. The god damn graphics.
It ended up being a top-down survival shooter. Unfortunately I didn't have time to polish and balance the different weapons, and I didn't get to add any powerups, but what the hell. It's done so I'm happy.
Thanks for the ride guys!
Tools:
Code: XNA, Visual studio
Graphics: Paint.NET
Sound: GarageBand, SFXR
author: lasseastrup
title: The Lost Viking
comments: Fun game, its got the arena shooter thing right. I seemed to die almost instantly when I got hit by an enemy though, maybe there isnt any temporary invincibility when you get hit? It was cool though. The visuals reminded me of skifree!
I AGREE WITH THE SKIFREE COMMENT! Yeah, the deaths are pretty much immediate. I upgraded to the bow and DEEEEPLY REGRETTED IT. lol
Hah, yea I agree the bow is pretty pathetic :P
I didn't have time to do any proper balancing. As for the tempoary invincibility - yea, I should have done that. The monsters will rip you apart if they get close to you :P
Definetly a fun game, I have to agree with the previous reviewers about how it reminds them of skifree :D

I feel that the range of the enemies were a bit too long (as there is no temporary invinsibility after getting hit), but that might just be me: The Audio track was very good, and sound effects cracked me up as they seemed to be completely opposite to the seriousness of the soundtrack.
Anyway, apparently a cat was selling the weapons. No wonder we got ripped off with some of the weapons :D
was I just attacked by numbermunchers?

Audio was nice, the graphics were cute, if simple. Gameplay seems pretty solid, and there's quite a bit there - at least, in terms of weapons. The axe actually seems like one of the better weapons, especially given some enemies moving faster than the player/long cooldown between shots.

description:
After leaving Earth X years ago, the humans detected water forming again on earth. They send back a robot(you) back to earth to make it more habitable. It's a puzzle game where you terraform earth!
Yeah.. I'm sorry guys, it sorta wasn't intiutive enough on what to do. (something I'lll have to keep in mind for the next one I make) if you're impatient here's a few hints: click on drill and then drill the trash. it'll give you lasers to laser the ice to make water. laser'ing water gives clouds that give you more water. If you end up with more too many trees, you can drill the trees. if you end up with too much water you can use plants to absorb them, or laser the water.
author: hyperturtle
title: The Lone Terraformer
comments: Pretty, but very hard to figure out what to do.
Fun game! Would be way more playable with hotkeys though.
I didnt understand this, could've done with a tutorial.

Well I think I was able to figure out what to do through intuition...sort of. I'm guessing I couldn't beat 'easy' mode because I made way more trees than water. It's an interesting concept but the game gets repetitive quickly.

Yeah.. I'm sorry guys, it sorta wasn't intiutive enough on what to do. (something I'lll have to keep in mind for the next one I make) if you're impatient here's a few hints: click on drill and then drill the trash. it'll give you lasers to laser the ice to make water. laser'ing water gives clouds that give you more water. If you end up with more too many trees, you can drill the trees. if you end up with too much water you can use plants to absorb them, or laser the water.
Why does the item always switch back to grass every time I click?

It makes using any item (except for grass obviously) very annoying. I think it's something you should have been aware of enough to try to fix. I can only imagine how annoying it was test your own game when it behaves like that.

Also, don't feel bad about your game being hard to understand. I thought I had submitted the simplest, most-intuitive game ever to this LD, and the first comment I got on it was "I have no idea what you are supposed to do or how to do it"
I like what you have made, but just can't figure out what can be done with things. 87 is my best on easy...
I like the concept.  Took a while to figure everything out, as mentioned.  But could be turned into something great, I believe.

description:
The Last Shadow - created by Justin and Blake Mullin.
Stranded on a dark planet, you must gather enough energy from an abandoned building to escape.
Known bugs:
- Doesn't work with Java 7
- After pressing Escape to free the cursor from the applet, you are no longer able to draw power correctly from objects.
- Sometimes the first object you absorb will give you one Watt too few.
Let us know what you think!
author: JustinMullin
title: The Last Shadow
comments: I can't get past the title screen...
(have apple's Java SE 6 Update 29, OSX 10.7.2, Firefox 8.0.1)
Tried pressing space, clicking on all the things on screen, waiting for all the text to come up.

I found the game to be too unforgiving. I could hardly move my mouse away from the object enough to actually see which direction it was turning in. I felt like I had no control, which for me ruined the game a bit.

Hmph...sorry to hear you can't play increpare!  Unfortunately I'm not entirely sure why it's not letting you past the title screen...all you should need to do is click the Start button.  If anyone else is having troubles getting into the actual game, if you could post your environment here that'd be great!
works for me.. quite enjoyed it :)

I didn't understand the game after clicking through the tutorial the first time, walked around the level some, confused, refreshed the game to see the tutorial again, and then everything made sense. Perhaps pacing the tutorial differently, or adding a first screen that's like "This is a game about draining energy from appliances into batteries" and being able reactive the tutorial through [?] ingame. I'm saying that because this was a pretty novel gameplay concept for me. :)

I, like SLiV, felt that the difficulty scaled pretty quickly and never managed to successfully steal a 5+ energy. Despite that, it's a creative game with a solid execution and nice mood thanks to the lighting.
Like the concept. But it was unplayable on trackpad. I can't deal with mouse sensitivity so low.

description: This is my entry. I wanted to make a game like this for a while. I hope you like it. I am tired now goodbye.
author: prettymuchbryce
title: Take care of the trees
comments: That was fun! The music was very nice.
Graphics and audio worked well, generally it was short, sweet and enjoyable. Don't understand where the saving trees comes into it.
Lol most fun game I've played so far, good gameplay and fun story. So short and so good I love it.
Loved the ending in which.. Well you know lolol >:)
I really liked how the view smoothly followed the character, even though it was grid-based! Great work man :D
Very polished, love the restriction of a single scroll direction. Cute story, short and...well, short.
I saw both endings. Really awesome concept. The gameplay is super simple, but I actually took the time to cut down every. single. tree.  O__O
Not bad, the music was very nice! The graphical style also worked.
I cut ALL the tress, but I got nothing in return :-( He asked me to take care of the trees.... I took care of ALL of them.... why don't I get anything for that? :-P

description:
Stinky Pete is a game coded in Blitz3D (plus a little php) for the competition Ludum Dare 22.
The other software I used is as follows:
sfxr 		- sound effects
Paint.NET	- creating graphics and level files
TuxGuitar	- composing music
ETNA		- DLL which allows the game to connect the online high-score database
It was created by Martin Cooke on behalf of Drytree Studios.
I worked solo, created all the code and assets within 48 hours and have included the source.
Enjoy :)
* 'improved controls' version - several people reported problems controlling Stinky Pete so I added acceleration and deceleration to his movements. This is the _only_ change that I have made. It took fewer than 10 minutes to implement and as I had the original version submitted with nearly 2 hours to spare I don't consider it too significant a change... but it is a change that happened after the deadline so I offer it only as a secondary download link - the original version remains intact. Please judge whichever version you wish :)
P.S. Merry Christmas everyone!
author: cakemonitor
title: Stinky Pete
comments: Some comments/suggestions: Wish the controls were a bit more forgiving it feels very sticky. Also, having to click through the tutorials every time you have to restart the level gets tiring very quickly :)
Great game w. good start tutorial and theme! Love the concept!

This is an excellent game with clever level design, funny mechanics and a pretty neat bgm. The only things I would criticize are the bad controls and how you approached the theme. Still, high rating for me!
I like the 3D render of 2D platformer, nicely done. The gameplay is interesting, but the game is not that fun to play, I gave up as soon as first problems appears. Maybe beacause of the control

fairly fun, but incredibly, incredibly frustrating xD eventually I gave up on the level where you have to fall with the critter and push it while in the air, because I did it and then forgot to make turn the stink off again so I pushed him in the lava >:( ragequitastic
I played with the improved controls. The movement does feel good, but I had a lot of trouble with collision (making it through small vertical gaps, and over corners mostly).

The levels and challenges were well designed and interesting! I actually thought the theme was decently strong, since Pete couldn't get near anybody without almost killing them. I feel for the guy since he spends so much time saving people that dislike him. He's like a stinky Batman!
I gave up on level seven or so, after finally getting through a gauntlet of tough puzzles only to fall in lava that was below the screen.
Verry fun game with a good gameplay, but a little bit difficult at the end.

description:
This is a game about a lonely satellite who wants to build a friend for him. You'll explore space and collect stuff to fulfill your goal.
Collect junk and other items for you to buy upgrades, and finally, your friend to finish the game. Be careful not to run out of battery, you need to return home to base for a recharge between runs.
Control with arrow keys and space/return.
author: E
title: Sat
comments: I really liked this game.  I played it for at least an hour and plan to finish it after judging ends.  Brilliant game design and humor.
This has been my favourite game so far.  I am suprised how captivating it is.  I kept notes when I first played it so I'll refer to them.
My initial qualms were all due to impatience.
I was going to complain about how touchy the controls were, but then I saw that it was part of the game to upgrade your ship's maneuverability.  Same goes for the radar.
I am a big fan of space traders, and one of my big projects on the horizon is a space trader, and this reminded me of a game called Escape Velocity, only way way simpler.
I love the joke about game physics, and the singing of a tune and forgetting the words. They are really nice touches, and I'll remember to add things like that in future games I make.

At one point I ventured out very far, and got back in time just before running out of fuel.  It's that kind of immergent gameplay that is a sign of good game design.  A few simple rules and leave the rest to the system you have created.
It is hard to know what is a good item to collect and what is an asteroid initially.  But once I got used to the art assets it was all fine.
I like the "Hello World"...no response joke.  It fits with the theme, its humorous, its brilliant.
There are other jokes later on that made me laugh out loud, and that is so rare for a game to do that.
I got quite far and was about to buy the radar, but then got lost.
Also the fact that when that happened the game didn't simply reset, I lost my money but not my items,
literally stopped me from rage quitting.  Bravo

description:
Test your survival mettle against the elements, as you wander the deserts alone looking for food and water to keep you sustained!
The longer you spend in the desert without food and water, the closer you get to...well...let's call it not surviving. Pick up a rock to bash open a cactus and get access to the sweet moisture inside, or throw it at a snake for a tasty uncooked snack.
The further you wander, the harder it gets to find the things you need to stay alive. How long can you survive?
I wish I'd slept a little less on this one, couldn't quite get the polish level up for the end (some weirdness with high scores, a memory leak I didn't have time to track down), but overall it really captures that lonely feeling I wanted to create.
author: Tatham
title: Realistic Desert Survival Simulator
comments: I played through without reading directions at first, so it was actually kind of fun to discover that you could pick up rocks (but being told that you can interact with things with the LMB would have helped).
I enjoyed the concept, lots of cool stuff you could do with this game.  Nice job.
I like it! keep working on it, I felt like Bear Grylls ;)

This was actually quite fun. "I wandered around the desert for a bit, then I smashed open a cactus with a rock and drank the cactus water, then I got hungry so I ate a snake." Every part of that sentence is pure awesome. I'd love to see you what you end up doing with this.
Fits the theme well and I like the idea, but it was no fun for me :(
I died serveral times without knowing why, didn't manage to kill a snake and fell of the world ^^
runs ok under WINE, would have been cool though if you'd provided binaries for other systems (since you used irrlicht anyways)

description:
The premise is simple. There are multiple Yous in the room, but there must only be one left standing to pass.
(I ran out of time and had to cut the levels short.)
author: binarycoder
title: One May Pass
comments: Superb little game, one of the best I've rated so far! :) the graphics and sound are a little basic but it doesn't detract from the fun of this game at all. Good fun and fits the theme well. Nice job!
really like it.. specially the escapelevel sound :) btw mine should work for you now..ive updated the libs :)
Very unique idea!  I think that, with more polishing and levels, this could be a commercial-grade game.  Seriously.  It's really cool.
Also, I put up an alternate download link for Happy Land that should fix your problem.  Look in the description.

Awesome, thank you!  I really was planning on more levels and mechanics, but I had to cut a lot of things w/ the time constraint. 9I am actually thinking about finishing this one up, actually!)  Oh, and Ill look at your games again!

Really nice game. Nice use of the theme, and the minimalistic graphics look super nice. It also looks like there's plenty of room to expand the level design without having to add new mechanics. The game just feels good.
The concept was nice. I would have liked to see more harder levels, because it never gets close to challenging.

Nice concept for this game, and I really like what you were able to pull together in the time given.  You did a very good job of pacing the action and letting people know the rules of the game world one step at a time.
This game came out to roughly average for me. The character graphics were great while the environments felt rushed. The sound effects were cool but no music was bland.
The good was great but the missing things weighed it down too much.
I love it a bit like a robotic Highlander.
Jumping off the bodies of your fallen clones is a nice touch.

description:
Left/Right arrow keys to turn left/right.
Up arrow to thrust forward.
'A' to activate/deactivate tow cable.
Tow items (little gray objects) into your base's blue collector field and they'll drop into your base and power-up your ship.
author: vargonian
title: Loner Jetman
comments: There's a bit of a control problem in that "A" also rotates the ship (Along with D). It also might have been nice if you avoided invisible walls and used the original solar jetman's mountain barriers. Otherwise, fun game, and I liked the particle effects.

Ah, nice catch!  I didn't even notice that A rotated the ship; I changed the control scheme at the last minute from Left-Alt to rotate to 'A' because I thought it was more typical.  And yeah, the invisible walls made me sad; I purposely made the terrain bumpy near the left/right ones so that you could easily tell that you weren't moving.
If I hadn't slacked so much, I'd have a starfield background to give a better feeling of movement/desolation as well as adding those mountain barriers.
Glad to see someone who knows what Solar Jetman is. :)  That's rare--no pun intended.
The collision was kinda buggy and dragging objects had weird issues.

I liked the feel of gunning about in the ship, and the graphics were quite nice in their way. I think the most obvious omission is any kind of threat to the player; even flying into walls at top speed has no punishment.

description:
You are a robot on a rescue mision.
The rescuer and the rescued are alone
in a strange place.
Good Luck!
author: Kableado
title: Lonely Ruins
comments: I smiled at the end. Cute game :)
Beautiful tileset-- looks like a modern remake of an SNES game. Had fun saving the kitty :) Sound effects are a little jarring, because they sound old-school compared to the graphics.
Lovely graphics, very cute game. I also smiled :)
Nice graphics indeed. The hit detection/perspective was annoying sometimes, but it still was very fun to play and get the kitty. Also props on the Linux build.
Loved the game. Level 4.2 saw me dying repeatedly, but I persevered.
Would have loved to see more levels; it felt like it ended just as you were getting into the swing of things!
yay i saved the kitten. i second the point about the hit detection--a bit of generosity there would have made the last level less frustrating.
Neat little game.  Graphics were great.
Great visuals, but it needed some ambient sound/music to break up the repeating sfx. It's a bit simple, but there are lots of ways to expand this. You should keep working on it!

description: This is my first Ludum Dare entry.  Can you save the lonely castaway from starvation?  HTML5 game with Flash for sound, keyboard controls. Should work anywhere.  IE<9 your mileage may vary.
author: sanojian
title: Lonely Island
comments: Was that a good "lol" or a bad "lol".  self. doubt. rising...
Just FYI, I played this on Safari for the Mac, and it seemed to work fine.
Thats great!  There is no reason it should not run everywhere, but I just never tried it.  Thanks!
I died once, and completed it on my second try.  I didn't get the hunger/water/energy mechanic at first.  It seems like you only regain energy if you move around?
I thought this was pretty fun, even though it was pretty simple.
"It seems like you only regain energy if you move around?"
I got so used to dancing around the fire that I forgot it was a bug and never fixed it. Whoops!
The weirdness of the voice was enhanced by the fact that my kids were sleeping in the next room and I did the sounds at the end when I was pretty exhausted.

Love the mechanics. Well balanced, great that you can understand what to do but still need to do it efficiently enough to survive. Design is very elegant, deserves another pass of polish after the compo!
I like the game mechanics, I think they could fit a RTS or tower defense game very well. Pretty good!

Haha we really did almost make the same game. I absolutely love the voices and the mechanics are very solidly implemented. My only gripe is that you need to move around constantly to recover stamina but that wasn't to much a problem at all. Overall very nice game, congrats. :)
No, it was a good LOL. The voice cracks me up every time.
And... I must suck because I can't seem to make a fishing pole at all. Fun little game with lots of charm! This was refreshing.

description:
Hello there....
finally we have a "finished" product in our hands.
This is a team effort, produced by Saikai , Dero ,Mirthen , Physx and Madea. This game is our first finished game in this constellation ( and with xna.... mind you ).
This Game need the XNA Redistributable to run.
You can get it from here:
http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=15163
The game is a simple side scroll running game. You are followed by a horde of people who want to hug you, even though you sold your "free hugs" sign yesterday. So you try to get away from them. No matter what, you want to be left alone.
The Goal of this game is easy... get to level 5 with as few followers as possible. You can loose followers by throwing bombs at them (...obviously). There are also breakable objects in the level which you can break through while rolling.Also...please don't step into the fire....it hurts.
When you are caught, you can retry the same level, but your score will be reset to zero.
Default controls: ( Can be changed in Options )
[UP] -> Jump
[DOWN] -> roll
[SPACE] -> activate bomb
Good luck ...and pray that our level generator doesn't cough up impossible levels.
ps: We are very sorry that we can't give binaries to all the Linux and MacOs guys(and girls) out there . XNA at fault here :) . We will put up a Youtube Video soon, to show the Game to you too.
author: SaiKai
title: Leave Me Alone
comments: it's crashing the moment I open it

@Jack: as SaiKai said, you need xna to start it :) I forgot that I don't have it on my Laptop and it crushed when I started it. Now I installed xna (just follow the link that SaiKai posted) and it works now :)
Hope, it will make as much fun as it does for us ;)
Maybe you could try porting to monogame:
Then it would work on more then Windows ;-)
I have XNA installed to rate some other games and it was going ok, but with this one I get "ld22 has stopped working"
Nice game, but i fear i cant rate it, because its just way to difficult ^^ sometimes death is unaviodable...

Probably the most fun game from this LD I've played so far (at least of those I can remember). It looks reasonably nice, though I think that I kept dying without realising because there were some objects that I thought were in the background that actually weren't. Good music/sound. Fits the theme, not in a particularly interesting way, but better than most that I've played.
Yes, your level generator tends to create unplayable levels (or it's too difficult for me)

Graphics are really cool, and the idea is fun (kind of reminds me of bit.trip runner?)... but i think the jumping mechanics get in the way a bit, especially when you have to jump a series of obstacles - I think the player's fall speed is too slow.

I had a good time playing this, and I thought the stream of huggers following your movements was cute and funny. It was probably too hard, at least starting off, but the difficulty made me keep playing.

There were definitely collisions that caught me by surprise, since barely clipping an object caused me to enter a falling state and then slide until I hit a wall (which could sometimes be very far away). Some of the objects are too thin and/or blend in, and some platforms look low enough to run under, but require rolling.

I wish there was a form of air control in this game, since a lot of the cheap deaths and frustration came from doing a big leap only to have some hazard enter the screen directly in the path of my jump. A stomp move, or a hastened fall would help greatly, since I'd have a chance to react to bad jumps and hazards and save myself!
I have XNA but this game still refuses to run. You should use a more compatible library.
can you post a little more information then "refuses to run"? most likely your problem is that you need the 3.1 xna redistributable ( not 3.0 not 4.0 but exactly 3.1 ! )

I really liked the audio... a full music track is a rarity in the games I've played so far. However, the gameplay felt pretty unfair. Controlling the height of your jumps is difficult (a longer momentum building phase to the jump would have helped) but the big problem is that you don't have enough forewarning of what's coming to make the correct decision. Its very easy, for instance, to jump onto a platform thinking it will be safe, only to find that you'll plow into an obstacle or a wall before you can land.
Overall, though, I was really impressed with the entry. It feels complete, which is a lot more than can be said for a lot of entries (my own included).

description: Small game about life, death, and Grue.
author: korri
title: G is for Grue, likely to eat you
comments: Wow, that was genuinely tense, especially with the shrinking light source... Gaphics could use some work, as well as packaging (I personally prefer a .zip over a RAR).

Way too tense. If you're going to let me see half a block around me, you can't get me stuck in a corridor 10 blocks long that doesn't go anywhere with Gru right on my ass. But solid maze game. Well done.

the floating text box in the middle of the dark is creepy :) With some torches to extends your view for an instant, or just standing there once you have light them, it would be perfect. Or maybe some other random options like map to show the exit point or crucifix to freeze the Grue...
Nice entry and good mood mark despite few graphics effects.
Seemed a bit unfair and repetitive to find the exit, but otherwise very nice and oddly scary game.
That thing haunts my dreams now. I could never escape. :(
This could definitely benefit from some extra additions... but it IS super tense.
Tense with the noise sound effect!
When it first loaded I thought it was rouge-like but then it started homing in on me before I could even find the movement keys.
I loved the way the fluctuating light varied the tension level.
The text bubble is a nice touch, but sometimes it gets on the way and I can't see where to move.  As others have said, the game is tense, although I bit repetitive for me.  Nevertheless, well done.

description:
Works perfectly in Chrome, some issues in Firefox, untested in IE. Source is all visible and unminified.

description:
An experiment in text entry and story telling... in an action game.
We proved a whole bunch with this -- primarily that it's impossible to use typing input as the primary mechanism to a game that involves reading text as the primary output/reward mechanism.
Going to write up a post mortem on the finer points of that later in the week at http://www.36peas.com -- but suffice to say that while this didn't turn out as we thought it might, we figured out all kinds of interesting things along the way.
We used the the 2.0 beta of Cocos2d Mac, and the Component Architecture we've published previously here: http://www.36peas.com/blog/2011/9/15/lightweight-component-architectures-and-object-composition-i.html

comments: Kinda fun, but, to be honest - nothing special - and the whole idea of tetris-like construction of a ladder was already used in earlier Ludum Dare. Still, above-than-average entry.
I say, mighty fine game there. Amusing visuals and it works pretty well.

I think it's a pretty creative idea to use Tetris mechanics to build stairs, so I gave you some points for that.  Unfortunately it didn't end up being all that fun.  The character graphics are pretty good, but the lighting/background was very annoying.  Overall, not too bad, but not too good either.  I liked the music and silly voices.

It took me a few tries before I understood what I was supposed to do. The game has neat music but it's hard to get past the distracting visuals. I think it could have been polished into a very neat game, given enough time.
I liked the overall presentation, looks solid and the music is very cool. But didn't enjoy the controls and the lighting.

Great little game. I thought the mechanic was really smart.  I know kibertoad said it's been done before, but seriously there are hundreds of games every LD, it's not like we can expect everyone to play all of them.

The graphics are solid, the lighting is a bit weird but it's not a big deal. Really liked the textures on the blocks and the screen shake when they dropped, gave them a lot of weight. I think there's a lot more polish here than most people are seeing.
This has so much to do with our last Ludum Dare entry, Eggscape. I'd like to know if you guys played it.
I was not sure if that voices are so great or so horrible :D But it was fun :D

description:
A peaceful tale about a man's quest to be totally alone.
The storyline behind the game is a bit odd.  It's probably the only submission about a murder/suicide.  A man pushes his wife out of a hot air balloon so he can be truly alone, only to face the wrath of karma.  He dies, and ends up in limbo where he will be alone for eternity.  The funny thing is, he likes it.  He's finally at rest.  But there's more to it than that.  He's insane.  And not in an interesting and quirky way, in a "I painted a portrait of you with my feces, but I ate it before I had a chance to give it to you" kind of way.  There is no hot air balloon, he just pushes her out the window and runs into the street.  Those are not birds, they're cars.  Those are not fighter planes and UFOs, they're police.  Under it all, this is a pretty dark story about a man who murders his wife and commits suicide by cop.  But that's depressing and hard to draw, so you get clouds and balloons.  I thought you'd enjoy that more.
This is an HTML5 game, so it's best to use the latest version of Chrome or Firefox.  Opera and Safari also work.  IE probably will not work.
author: uzimonkey
title: Alone
comments: Hilarious! Graphics are pleasant, but i don't think the gameplay necessarily reflects being alone.

True, but it's very difficult to have any sort of gameplay while being truly alone.  But there doesn't have to be any people in the planes and UFOs.  In the UFOs, aliens (cue crazy-haired ancient aliens guy).  In the fighter plants, kittens (why not?!).
Your graphics are amazing, but your choice for sounds and their triggering methods are not pleasing.
I've updated the 'Web' link and put the game on an actual page, but the game itself is still exactly the same.
I laughed so hard at the beginning. Then I killed many, many, many, many birds.

It established a great mood and the audio was fitting. It wasn't funny at all though, and there wasn't much interactivity to it.
OKAY! So this was pretty beautiful but I agree that the interactivity didn't really meany anything, except a nice way to give you an avatar and to make you explore the image + words over time.
Absolutely wonderful. Very moving for such a short game. A work of art.
I cannot for the life of me figure out what the background is...  It always cuts to music before I expect it so I can't get a good look.
I really like how this game came together, though "game" seems a strange word for it.  This seems simultaneously like the beginning and ending of a story.
I sat and listened to the waves crashing for a long time.  Peaceful after the ominous buildup.

Nice piece of storytelling, but at a certain point the text was too small to read. And I think the wind didn't play for me.

Hardly a game, but the interactivity makes it different from a written story. Gradual progression of images also helps build an unexpected experience. My brother likes it a lot.
Beautiful, I really love the 1bit gfx, and great music... more an interactive story than a game. Congratulations.

I really dig the ending music. I love how the game begins to take shape while you play. I just assumed you were going for some kind of odd aesthetic and then BOOM it starts to come together. Not really a game or a challenge, of course.. but a very solid mood nonetheless.
I think this my favorite so far, well done! 5/5 on theme, brilliant use of graphics and music.

description:
"The Invention of Colour"
This is interactive storytelling. It doesn't play like a traditional game. You'll follow "Alrion" through his quest to find "shimmers" as he doesn't know what colours are. I aimed to create something that is engrossing and takes the player on a journey. Just enjoy not having to do much and expect a few minutes of atmospheric storytelling. It's intentional low level involvement.
There are two ways (literally) to finish the game. Just keep going.
Hope you enjoy this little trippy & eerie plunge into the heart of a bizarre world.
PLEASE NOTE: This experience requires AUDIO (best enjoyed with headphones), otherwise the game will not make sense. Controls are also explained in-game: just use the arrow keys to walk around. This should run on Windows, Mac & Linux. The only thing you need is a JAVA runtime.
Oh and yes. There is a kitten in the game.
Made with libgdx, reaper & gimp.
UPDATE: Added a complete walk-through video of the game. If for whatever reason you can't play the game this should give you a fairly accurate impression of the experience!

Humans have discovered one other intelligent race in the universe, but a new recently elected (psycho) President (might change the title to something like dictator) doesn't think very fondly of the aliens and wants to completely eradicate them, so humans can be alone in the universe again. title: Splaser Strife
comments: I enjoyed the game quite a bit.  The graphics are great and the sound enhances the mood.

I'd like the game as a whole a little better if there were autofire and you saw points appear where you destroyed a ship.  I was focused on the enemies, so I never looked at the score until I was between levels.
It would also fit my skill better if I restarted at the beginning of the wave where I died. :)

The restart at beginning thing is going to have to stay, though. ;)
Great art and sound! It was a little frustrating that I couldn't shoot straight ahead and avoid bullets at the same time.
Nice job on the graphics and the music! The enemy bullets were a bit hard to see though, because they didn't really contrast the background.

Love galaga, even more if it's as funny as hell! The down side: the background dust is very distracting and the difficulty curve is a bit jumpy.

description: A 2-player scrolling shooter. Kinda unfinished.
author: Inertia
title: Purple is the Best Colour
comments: This is just a generic vertical scrolling shooter with difficult and repetitive enemies. It doesn't even match the theme, since you are fighting alongside another ship! There was no audio, and nothing involving mood whatsoever.

Hmm, if this game was designed to work with flying both ships at once it could have been interesting, but it doesn't seem that way and comes out kind of generic, also does not fit the theme unfortunatley.
It has repetitive, simple enemies, a non-functioning health system, and a core gameplay mechanic directly contrary to the theme.
Well, it is pretty unfinished indeed, but I like the idea. One bug: when one of the players dies (no hearts or lives) - his ship still stay on the playing area, but without accepting commands.
One suggestion: on these kinds of competitive 2P games, you should add some ways for one player to get in the other's way - like sending enemies to the opponent's playing area, etc.
On the plus side, it did run in windows. This is more of a demo than a game, no sound, no instructions, no win condition etc. I couldn't even figure out how to make the red ship fire.

description:
I hated this theme, and it was really hard to pull something together when I changed my whole base idea with less than 12 hours to go.  But isn't that what makes this all fun :D
The alone part of this was supposed to be since you are station on a remote outpost taking shots at alien fleets passing by on the way to the real war zone.  Originally there was going to be a resource gathering part of the game between waves of ships, which was going to help drive home the alone thing, but it got cut due to time restraints.
author: kokido
title: Outpost Alone
comments: The shots were very slow.  I liked the warning signal for the aliens.
The speed of the bullets made the game a lot more difficult than it really should have been, and I feel that there should have been a score counter of some kind.
On a more positive note, The graphics were simple yet effective, I liked the effect of the stars in the background. The sounds were also really good.
Aside from the game over screen, the graphics were pleseant.
I loved the stars as well.

The background music is OK, in my opinion, as it is the graphics.  The bullets were too slow to be useful and I had a hard time knowing when to shoot.  I felt very weird that the silos (?) were destroyed when the UFO's were no longer visible; I guess I expected them to fire me instead of spontaneous explosions :-)
The graphics in general, and the stars especially, looked really good! Like some of the other comments have said, I found the bullets a bit too slow, but overall a pretty decent game.
Dug the music. Shots went a little slow.

Yeah, the shots are too slow.  My original plan was to allow you to buy upgrades between waves of aliens to fix that.  I was also going to have a counter of waves survived instead of a score, and they were going to shoot at the silos instead of the silos just exploding when the aliens made it off the screen.
The general reception is better than I expected though, thanks for playing everyone :D

description:

Please note that the game is supposed to be in only a few different colors!
How To Install: Download the file, and open it using Winrar, 7-zip, or any other zip-extracting software.

If you need any help, or have any errors with the game, etc., please let me know in the comments below!
Thanks for playing the game! :)
PLEASE NOTE THAT THERE IS ONLY 4 LEVELS!!!
author: GTB
title: Move It!
comments: The third level or so can't be beat. The yellow box at the top doesn't send you to another level.

It took me a couple of minutes of frustrated clicking to figure out that I had to click on the *text* of 'Missions', 'Tutorial' or 'Credits' in order to activate them. I'm sure I'm not the only one who will assume that the surrounding rectangle is a 'button' and won't be able to figure out how to start the game. Please don't do this sort of thing, it's really annoying.

If you're going to make a 3D jumping game then it is a good idea to give the player some indication of where their 'feet' are. It's very difficult to judge a jump just from the camera position. Since judging jumps is the only real challenge in the game, this just makes it feel unfair.
I wish you hadn't put in the impossible fourth level. I know you said that you only designed three, but leaving that in is just confusing.
I didn't really see how it related to the theme, although you were in the jam so perhaps it wasn't supposed to.
@Daz You cant beat the fourth level, it says so in the description.
@Dan C I will try adding feet and arms later on. I didn't have enough time for captions and all of that, but you are in a "facility" and are forced to do tests...

description:
STORY
-
You are one of the world's 10 best people called Al, and have therefore been invited to compete in the Annual Al Acrobatics championship. The winner is given the title of 'Al 1' - will it be you?
HOW TO PLAY
-
Use left/right to charge during the powerup phase. At the top of the screen is a minimap - the small red part of the line is the target, and the green arrow is approximately where you will land at your current speed.
When you're in the air, press the displayed keys to score combos, press left to slow down your flight so you hit the target, and make sure you press space before you land otherwise you won't score any points.
To score a kitten bonus, when the combo letter is 'K', hold shift when you press K. You must land directly on the target to score kitten bonuses. After 3 rounds, the game is over.
THE BIT WHERE I EXCUSE THE CRAPPINESS OF THE GAME
-
Though I actually liked the theme this time, I came quite late and unprepared to this LD, and started coding about 36 hours in. I wasn't happy with the game by the Compo cutoff, and normally I would just submit what I had as a compo entry, but this time round I felt like actually completing something. As a result, while it's missing much in the way of graphics and is completely absent of audio, as far as gameplay goes it's perhaps the most complete LD entry I've made. That doesn't make it any less terrible - the game reminds me of many horribly generic Flash games, but without the presentation, addictiveness or convenience - but I hope that the completely unrelated kitten bonus acts as some compensation for this.
I probably won't be developing this further, though if I do I think I'd turn it into a multi-event game, tune the gameplay/opponents a bit more, add a few little features to give it more depth, and vastly improve the presentation.
