description:
Run Justin, Run was one of two ideas I had for LD22, but the most fun, and I like my humorous games, so here goes.
As a very famous popstar; we'll call him Justin you've just come back from a very successful gig, however he's got a bit of the lergy, and he's feeling particularly disgusting.
He knows that if a fan gets too close then they won't be able to make it to his concert tonight, so he's only one option; get to the public toilets at the end of town so he can be alone and away from his adoring fans.
It's basically track and field with screaming girls, so press the left and right arrow keys like a nut to run away from the crowds.
Occasionally crazed fans will launch themselves at you, you'll need to kick or punch them away unless you want to lose a particularly die hard fan!
It's missing a lot of animations that I wanted to do, as well as a few sounds that wouldn't loop.
Hope you enjoy it!
I've included a link to both the executable, and the web link; however there is issues with images taking a while to load via the web; you have been warned!

title: Minotaurus

Moving onto innovation. I do like seeing multiplayer games crop up, and I even saw a dead body. Unfortunately there was a lack of innovation involving actually moving around, not even bothering with the keyboard. Aside from that the UI was fairly good.

description:
This game is unfinished and the only thing to do is fly around and trade resources between
planets.
How to play:
Use the arrow keys to fly the ship and use the mouse to trade on the planet UI.
You start off on planet Earth. Click the Take buttons to get some resources, then click Launch. Fly to another planet (use the minimap to see other planets) and land on it (your ship needs to be facing so that the thruster lands on the planet otherwise you will crash). The UI that shows up will show the type of resource that the planet produces click the Buy button to buy that resource (you can buy other types of resources, but there's probably no point) and trade one of your other resource types for it. Then fly to another planet that produces a different resource type and buy it. Repeat until bored. You will need to periodically return to Earth to unload your cargo and refuel.

description:
Look around you. Do you see them?
Blips out in the distance.
These are all that remain of those who have long since left this place.
And when you leave, you too will leave your own.
Like a message in a bottle...
A forgotten memory...
This is what it means to be alone.
IF YOU DON'T GET IT:
NONE of the blips you encounter have been hand crafted. Every one of them has been left behind by a real person--such as you--entering the realm, and not fictional beings thought up by a developer.
There is no way to know who left them behind. No name, no link, no nothing. You explore alone. You leave alone. Despite being so close to what others have done, you never meet them, and never know their name.
The closest thing to any sort of connection you will ever have is when you leave, as a blip of your own will be left behind.
tl;dr - It's art. (Though really, it makes a LOT more sense if you read the above.)
WHAT TO DO:
Use wasd, arrow keys, or mouse buttons to move, and the mouse to look. It's recommended that you first look around to discover a blip.
Chrome highly recommended. This thing is iffy about if it wants to work with other browsers; I've had mixed success with Firefox.
OH, and for some reason the library I'm using locks your movement if you hit Q, and won't give it back. So don't hit Q. I wish I could have fixed that.
WHAT IS THIS?
Each blip is generated from previous users, based on how they explored while they were looking around. When you leave the page, your own exploration--your "memories"--will become another one of those blips.
It's rather difficult to call this a game, I suppose... I was trying to create something artsy that pushed the limits of what a game is, based on the definition that a game is an "Interactive Experience." I'm not sure how well I did.
THE TECHNOLOGY
This uses WebGL, PHP, Ajax, MySQL, HTML, and JavaScript.
Going into this, I knew NOTHING about WebGL, PHP, Ajax, or MySQL, and the last time I used HTML and JavaScript was ten years ago.
Don't ask me how I pulled it off.
Maaaaaajor thanks/credit/props to so many tutorial sites I can't even remember right now, but probably most of all to a man known as Paul Lewis. His WebGL tutorials are amazing, and not only that, but they made it possible for me to follow through with my idea. His website: http://aerotwist.com/
That said, please do try not to wreck my server. :)
EDIT - Because Internet Explorer does NOT support WebGL, I've added a notification for users that try to run the game on non-WebGL browsers. The only difference between it and the 48 Original version is the bit of code that handles that notification.

description:
To download:
Follow the link, then go to File -> Download Original
For the Windows version, you play the game by running CarryMeowHome.exe
*****************************************************
In this game, you are a kitten.  A kitten who has become lost and is all alone without its mommy-cat.  Your goal is to find and return to Mommy.
There's a problem, though.  You're tiny and weak... you can't move very far, or very fast.
Yet, there's a solution!  These humans think you're SUPER CUTE, and then want to carry you home!  If you meow [Space Bar], the ones that hear you will run to pick you up!  Don't let them carry you off, though!  You need to find Mommy!  Let them carry you for a while, but if they don't seem to be going the right way, hop out of their arms [Space Bar] and look for another ride!
Good luck, kitten!

o_o Wow... Not sure of what I just played, but I wont think to it too much, it would cause me horribles nightmares... That's my first 5 stars mood mark :)
I screamed and screamed and screamed but the little scab box still eroded. I have no idea wtf I just played, but I know that I played it. INNOVATIONS!

Yeah, the way the game's set up, with the numbers I used and all, eventually the things scratching at the walls will break through. More and more just keep spawning, so they break through faster, and the effect of the volume on them drops off quadratically (with distance), so you can only push them back so far before you're not screaming loud enough. I didn't really leave time to tweak the gameplay at all (not that I would have made defeat evitable anyways).
I don't have a microphone that can be plugged in my mixer atm.
Aw yeah. Limiting my audience is almost as good as alienating them.

Hmm...that's a good idea. Better than how I did it. My roommate had the same issue with his mac's mic, but the levels work well on my laptop's internal mic, which is what I tuned it for (I hit about 60% easy on an average yell).

Or maybe give the player an option to adjust flash's microphone gain before starting or something. I cranked it down, because, with my mic, basically anything would put it up to 100% on the default gain settings.

Ok...now my neighbours think I'm crazy. Thanks a lot.

It's a very unique approach and I think it comes together really well. Very interesting and very innovative ... but definitely not a control mechanic i want in a game. :P  Thank you for submitting this game!

Although I'm generally philosophically opposed to games using the microphone, this one did it really well. I wished for a moment there was a way to "win" but actually it's kind of neat like this, it's really just an endurance test on how long you can put up with the game's impossible demands. Full marks on graphics and audio, too. If "anti-games" are a genre then this is an excellent one.

Very intriguing take on the theme. While it's both fun and awkward to scream at your computer, I hesitate to call it a "game". As someone previously said, it's more like an interactive art piece -- which is still cool.
I like it, and it rates well with me, but I would have liked to see a more tangible goal or direction.

You guys mention wanting smarter AI, but I thought the guard AI was more than decent (they pathed, they chased, what more could a thief ask for?). On top of that, you guys had some pretty sweet ideas--I was in love with the gallery feature, it adds a lot.

But I felt that the level, that tied all the gameplay together, didn't show off the mechanics as well as it could have. Having one exit does constrain the player, but the execution became a bit more "walk forever, do this, walk forever, do that" instead of an intense thief game. Perhaps multiple exits, time cap, having a bit more time to design the level (your journal suggested that final level design started ~5h left), features that just makes use of all of your existing, fun systems could definitely add a lot.

Flixel's definitely an interesting environment. On one hand, it gives you things like pathing. Unfortunately, that makes you reluctant to do other kinds of AI. I think the trick is to make sure you have all the powerful tools in your belt (like saving: http://flashgamedojo.com/wiki/index.php?title=Saving_%28Flixel%29), try to take advantage of them in clever ways, and never waste time trying to fight against how Flixel does things. :P

It was immediately obvious that art is one of you guys' greatest strengths, and this game was a fun, clever play on the theme and a tribute to your talents. From all the humor, I can tell that you guys enjoyed making it--and it's really nice to see a game that just shows off the team's personality so much. Good job, guys! :D

description:
Super Square is spawned into a very strange and dangerous world. There are no other sentient squares, only square eating zombies! Thankfully Square comes packing heat!
Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3npMRx7BHE
----- Running The Game ----
Windows Standalone: Unzip the archive. Run game.exe. Shot zombies.
** For the following you'll need LOVE 1.7.2 or later to run the game. You can grab it here: http://love2d.org/
Windows: If love is installed, you can double click super_square_zombie_killer.love to start it. If love is unzipped you can start the game from the command line "love super_square_zombie_killer.love"
Linux: Your distro probably has LOVE in its repos. Once installed, the game can be run from the terminal using "love super_square_zombie_killer.love"
Mac OSX: Grab the binary from http://love2d.org/. Double click on super_square_zombie_killer.love or run from the terminal.
If you have any problems, there's more info at http://love2d.org/wiki/Getting_Started
----- Playing -----
Find the exit without dying! There are some health kits around if you're low on health. Each gun has different properties:
Pistol: Powerful and accurate, but has small magazine size and bullets do not go through zombies
Shotgun: Fires many pellets in a large spread. Useful for pushing back a crowd of zombies, but has a long reload time.
Assault Rifle: Large magazine capacity, medium damage, and bullets go through zombies. Good for general killing.
Light Machine Gun: Powerful and can fire a large number of bullets before being reloaded. Watch out for its large spread and long reload times.
----- Controls -----
Move: W, S, A, D
Reload: R
Pistol: 1
Shotgun: 2
Assault Rifle: 3
Light Maching Gun: 4
Aim: mouse
Shoot: mouse left
Next/prev gun: mouse wheel
Quit to menu: Escape
Toggle fullscreen: F5
----- Settings -----
Fullscreen can be toggled by pressing F5. The default resolution is 800x600. This can be changed by editing the file "conf.lua" in the super_square_zombie_killer.love file. The .love file is really a zip file.

description:
==Description==
You're trying to play your video game but your mom keeps telling you to shut it down. Throw soda cans at her to make her leave you alone!
You "die" if you lose your concentration. You lose it faster with more people in your room. You regain it by being alone.
You gain score by playing your video game (surviving) and hitting your mom. You lose score if you hit yourself.
==How to play==
Windows: Unzip and run LeaveMeAlone.exe
Web: Click the link (you need Unity Web Player installed)
Click at the target (or near it) to throw soda cans
==Remarks==
The game was made with Unity and voxel art was drawn with Paint3D and converted with 3ds max. Sound was recorded with an iPhone.
This was my first ever 3D game and also my first try at Unity, so don't expect much. It's kinda half-finished but enough to be playable so I decided to submit anyways.
It was supposed to have fun dialogs/sounds and have more NPCs (dog, neighbour, little sister, guitar player) but time was barely enough to add mom :/

I used to speak to the wall ( a game about Schizophrenia ) is my second participation in the Ludum Dare. Like the first time, it was a total blast !
IUTSTTW is less a game than a short interactive story with no real goal. Find your way in the mind of the subject, and make the good choice. The story has three different endings, either good or bad.
There are many things I would have loved to add, such as music or more interaction, but ultimately ran out of time. I also apologize for the english mistakes I left there and there :/
IUTSTTW has been made with FlashPunk.

description:
Time by yourself can be fun and productive, but it can also lead to anxiety and loneliness.  Your goal in this game is to stay sane.  Keep yourself busy with the two mini-games to ward off anxiety, but be careful!  Making mistakes will cause you to more rapidly lose your composure.
There is no real win condition; you can keep going forever.  There is however a definitive lose condition.  The look on your characterâ��s face will clue you in to his current sanity level, as will the state of his surroundings.  You will know when youâ��ve lost and the game is over.  Even if you decide this game isnâ��t for you, itâ��s at least worth intentionally going insane to see the effects!
There are two mini-games that can either help or harm your sanity.  Pressing LEFT and RIGHT in the main screen lets you switch between them, while pressing ENTER starts a given game.  Use the ARROW KEYS to navigate through the game and ENTER to activate the currently selected node.  If you do well, your characters sanity increases.  Do poorly, and it will decrease much more quickly.  When youâ��re done with a game, press ESCAPE to go back to the main screen.
The computer allows you to solve simple, randomly-generated Boolean logic puzzles.  A red line represents a powered wire, while a white line is unpowered.  Pressing ENTER on one of the logic gates (nodes) cycles through the various logical operators: AND, OR, NAND, NOR, and XOR.  The objective is to set up all the gates so that current flows from the left all the way to the final node on the right.  Pressing SPACE during this mini-game will check your results.  If youâ��re wrong, youâ��ll lose sanity.  If youâ��re right, your sanity increases and a new puzzle is generated.
The bass lets you play the other mini-game: composing.  This allows you to write an accompaniment that is played alongside the gameâ��s main music track.  This gameâ��s display is analogous to staff paper.  The window represents one measure, with time moving forward from left to right.  You can turn on up to three simultaneous notes per rhythmic division (sixteenth note).  Note pitch increases as you move up the screen, with the bottom being a C.  The red lines represent chord tones; stay inside the harmony and your sanity will increase.
Iâ��m not sure what else to say.  Sure itâ��s flawed/incomplete, but I think itâ��s pretty cool anyway!

comments: If there was a way to judge scope, it would get a 5 from me - it's HUGE..

But also very disorienting. The MUD idea with the text is cool, but coupled with the visual it doesn't work. Humans always take visual above imaginative, and in the visual here there's no land marks or anything - I could never remember the route back or forwards..

Interesting game, but too short for the minimalistic story to have any impact (I was more interested in what was going on than in actually getting to Lisa). The ending can be reached well before reading the other notes and reads like a standard game over, not an ending, which makes it rather anticlimactic when you play the rest of the game and discover that was the ending. The game did do a good job of making me interested in a place consisting of only white circles.
Super cool game with a super cool idea! :D i really like it!

Well, the movement controls were not my cup of tea. But the writing in this game was exquisite; I HAD to keep on playing just to read all the notes. It fit the theme perfectly, as well as being one of relatively few games that made me truly care about the characters. Nice work!
I walked and I walked and I walked. And then suddenly I died.
The hexagonal movement idea was nice. The idea of the game was cool too. It would have been better if it there was a non-fullscreen mode, and if there was some way to tell how close you are to dying.

The size was quite daunting when combined with the art style that made the rooms hard to distinguish from eachother, especially since you jumped around quite a bunch via the entrances, the mood was there though for me.
Interesting, though I think I'd rather have explored the area without a move limit. The control system was quite a pain in the long run.

description:

A browser game in JavaScript, using HTML5 canvas. Using the latest Chrome is recommended; Firefox might also work. Enjoy!
author: ThomasTC
title: I Am A Ninja
comments: I really like this one, the gameplay is fun, very difficult at times, but not too much that it ruins the experience.  The art style works really well too, my only complaint is a lack of sound, but otherwise, a very slick game.
Thanks! There is sound, only it doesn't work in all browsers. I'll see if I can get that fixed tonight.

Although I think its more realistic how you handled extend/pull of rope. I keep expecting it to behave more like the old 2D worms games like Worms 2 or Worms Armageddon where it physically pushes you away, though "You can't push a rope"
I think you should continue to add more onto the game with more things, beyond even the theme. You got a good game going here

namrog84, thanks for your comments, and well spotted :) Initially I had a "push rope" just like in Worms, but I realized it was easy to make it more realistic, so I did. Drawing it properly was a breeze with canvas's quadraticCurveTo method.

I have completely disabled sounds for now because they were causing too much trouble -- Firefox not playing at all, Chrome completely ignoring the cache and re-downloading on every playback! HTML5 audio is a bitch. Impossible to use for games. Too late to add one of them Flash-wrapping libraries now...
Last update, I hope: now works on Safari too (workaround for missing requestAnimationFrame). Tested on MacBook Pro.

I tried to get it working in Opera but get DOMExceptions that I couldn't figure out. I tried to get it working in Konqueror just for kicks, and it almost worked, but the risk of breaking something else outweighs the required fixes.
Bottom line: use Chrome or Firefox!

Controls had a learning curve, and a quick tutorial would have been nice to help. Also the walking speed feels a bit sluggish for a ninja game, but once I got rolling Spider-man style, I had plenty of fun. :)

Pretty cool game! Took a second to get used to the controls, and overall I still found it a bit hard, but the rope mechanic works surprisingly well. If you added in checkpoints for non-hardcore players like myself I think it would be a pretty great game.

Aaron, the slow walking was mostly intentional, because yes, you're meant to go Spidey right from the word go! I say "mostly intentional" because there's also the aspect of it not being walking at all, but just a force pushing against friction; to make him go faster I'd have to reduce friction and this sliding effect would become too obvious. (Or hack around it. No time for that!)
kato9, Aaron, you both mentioned difficulty with the controls. What could be improved in that area?

I just gave the game another whirl and found that I was able to play much better this time around. I think it's just a bit of a learning curve which isn't necessarily a bad thing at all. I think my main issue is that it's hard to gauge your momentum at any given time, so you end up not flinging yourself far enough or vice versa. A solution to that might be show a visible launch curve similar, if you've ever played peggle you might know what I mean - although I can't imagine that would be easy to program :/

comments: Very fun game! Really wished you would've had more time to make levels.

[10:56:49 PM] Kerma: Dungeon Dan represents a child growing up into adulthood. You start off the game dark and unknowing, going carelessly into the rooms ahead of you, maybe even getting hurt back a bit. The queit noise guides you further, much like parents or advisors. You find yourself lost and confused until you find the switch and the knowledge to allow you to progress past the powerful obstacle that has punished you many times before. After progressing past the obstacle you find that you have fully matured as an individual and you can wander around in your childhood a bit more but end up progressing down the stairs where future adventures wait, and eventually death which is symbolized by the game closing. 5/5
Nice entry and perfect leveldesign. I wish I could play another dungeon like this one.

author: Leo
title: Brains!!!
comments: I couldn't run the exe. It stopped working the moment I ran it. (Windows7 64bit)
Did you install openAL? I guess that could be the problem.
Neat! Amusing little zombie shooter.  Took me a little while to figure out that I had to push "Enter" to start the game.  Almost quit before I started.  :)
I had to install OpenAL (quick & painless, thankfully), and then it worked.  Short, but a neat little shooter with a cool style.  Congrats on finishing!
I only ever reached level 7, where I died.

To me it seems that balancing for this game would be very difficult, and at some point (Level 7 for me) it's essentially impassible because there is no open space to be alive on. However, regarding this barrier, you did really well in the difficulty of the game.
My biggest concern for the game is the level design. As far as playing the game is concerned, there really wasn't a difference between the levels except the zombie density at the beginning.

Polishing up the game (more clear controls & direction, slow learning curve), adding more variety (in graphics, zombie type (probably by region because random mixing doesn't really accomplish anything as far as visible typing) ), and making the world more advanced (indoors of buildings, maybe, stairs?) would make it good.
Adding procedural generation for the levels would be awesome (assuming it also had the extra detail, right now, as I said about the level design, it wouldn't really make a difference).

Kind of fun and actiony. Gets repetitive. Not quite satisfying to keep swooshing through ghosty zombies while always firing in random directions. I wonder if it would have been better to dial down the enemy count and put more emphasis on evasion... or maybe... yeah - one hit kills with particles showering off when each zombie is killed. Also maybe having the zombies push you around when they bunch up nearby. Getting more of a physical inertial feeling. Also boss monsters and intense music, of course... :)
LVL 6!!! :D Really amusing game... BIG + for fun and great simple pixel graphic ;)

description:
I'm just going to be straight with you: This is a text based game.
This year I wanted to give myself a bigger challenge than just throwing together a simple flash game like I've done in previous years, so I decided to learn Inform7 this weekend, and now you get to play the result.
This game has multiple endings, so you might want to play though it a few times.
If you've never played a text based adventure game before, here are some basic guidelines:
Commands are generally phrased as "verb noun", in the simplest way possible (so, "take phone" or "go north" instead of "pick up the cell phone on the end table" or "walk to the north")
Pay close attention to the descriptions of the rooms (the few paragraphs after the bold name of a room when you first enter) Sometimes the description of a room will change based on what you do there. You can see the description of the room you're currently in at any type by typing "look"
You can "look at" and "look under" anything named in the room description. Usually you don't have to type out the full name of the thing, so "look at drawers" is the same as "look at chest of drawers" You can also "take", "drop", "throw", "wear", "take off", "turn on", "turn off", "open" or "eat" some things you find.
If you're stuck, please post a comment here and I'll give out some hints. If you're REALLY stuck, there is solution link that contains the solutions for two of the many endings.
author: qrunchmonkey
title: A.L.O.N.E: Always Lonely on Newyear's Eve
comments: Nice writing. There's a lot to do, but sometimes I struggled to get the right command to do what I wanted (though I guess that is inevitable with this kind of game). For example it wasn't clear how to read phone messages, so I only managed to get a couple of them.
Couldn't figure out how to use the phone. Nice idea though.

I did a I7 project a few months ago. Inform 7 is a tough thing to work with; the text-based adventure environment affords a really different idea of game design, that can seriously alienate a more modern crowd who aren't familiar with the idea. Bravo, sir.

Sweet writing, very fleshed out world. Both passage of time and space is played on really well. I appreciated unlocking achievements, and keeping the scoring system intact definitely added incentive to keep playing the game.

Take said, the game still limits control visibility, inherent to IFs, for unfamiliar players--and I'm still one of those. For a large part of the game, I didn't know what I could do or how to do the things I could do. I understand that stating controls for everything could spoil the experience of figuring them out, but interactions like looking under a bed (I live in a life without space under beds) might be impossible to just know for some players. The phone took me a large portion of the game to figure out to work (type mail is a weird command, and I still don't know how to respond). Maybe a command list of used commands would have helped, given your audience.
Really cool IF though, and very impressive for one of your firsts. :)

comments: Mediocre game. The graphics are meh and the gameplay didn't hold my attention, but the core concept was interesting. Polish it up a little and you'll have a neat little game on your hands.
Thank you so much for your comment Ashkin !!
nice idea that could be developed and built upon; graphics are alright but some more polish would be good. some audio would be good too.

Hey fishbrain thank you so much for your comment. I believe too the idea was good, but we didn't have time to finish all those small design ideas we had in mind. Audio was on the list but no time too :(
Even tho, I'm happy with the result; was made with a average 8kb/s connection and each of us were far away.
Nice game ! With few sfx you could have make much better, please check bfxr.net next time ! thx for posting your sketches too.
Hey Ben thanks so much for your message. I will check that site, I believe it will help us a lot next time !!
The third level is sooo hard. I wish the game were less randomized but it had me playing for a long while.

Good to know triplefox, will try to work on that randomized the next time. 3rd level it's challenged, was trying to make something attractive but didn't dedicated a lot of time (didn't have enought time at the end)

description:
You're on a shopping trip with your Mom, but you run the risk of getting lost because of all of the distractions. Don't get left alone!
Because of some Canvas performance issues in Firefox, it works best in Chrome. May also work in IE9, but untested.
Source can be found here: https://github.com/doowttam/Lost-Mom
author: doowttam
title: Mom?
comments: This is a strange game. It's not really that fun or even funny, but I can't stop playing it and laughing at the silly gameplay mechanic. It doesn't really fit the theme though.
I love the idea! The downside is that it becomes boring after some time. But it still made me smile. Also I think it does fit the theme quite well.
Yeah maybe not the most fun game, but I was laughing at all the weird 'products' that kept popping up. Needs some more compelling mechanics to really keep you playing though.
Great mechanic!  (It is actually fairly distracting after a few things!)
Neat idea, but the graphics of things seen by the character need some work. Also, a floor. Good work though, keep it up!
Very interesting. I can't say it's really fun (games where the primary mechanic involve a decreased amount of feedback from the game system are inherently frustrating), but it's certainly original.

description:
Controls : WSAD or arrows to move, space to jump.
Find the lost kitten in the city of robots and lead him back to the gate to win.
*EDIT* A few people have commented that the intro text goes by too fast for them to read. If you look at the screenshots below you'll see I included all the intro panels, so if you can't read them in the game you can read them there.
author: Beerman
title: Lonely Robot's Kitten Quest
comments: The isometry-2 colour graphics was innovative and fun, but made the judgement of distance difficult, perhaps a 3rd colour for shadowing would have helped?
Yeah, that was something I was meaning to address but in the end there just wasn't time.
Might come back to this and expand on it though, feels it has the potential to be something quite good with a little more work.
funny? yes, if only for how strange the bugs in it are :P

i also agree with xelifian, that the 2-color graphics made it even more weird, i did end up laughing so hard at the security bots i had to actually chase in order to get them to follow me i got myself killed by the first thing that actually tried to kill me, so props for fun / humor even if not all of what i found so funny was perhaps intentional ;)(such as the security bots getting stuck in the walls of the pyramids if you jump on to them)
The intro pages skipped by a bit too fast for me to read, perhaps because I'm not an English native speaker.
I also found the controls confusing. Would've expected 'up' to be the diagonal, instead of along a single axis.

I think I found the kitty, but I couldn't interact with it. The two-color scheme made it difficult to see the 3D perspective. Even just having a different color for elevated surfaces vs the ground would help a lot.
If you get close enough, the cat will jump up and start to follow you. The level generator *should* make it so you can always get close enough for it to see you.
Can't argue with you on the colour scheme, that's definitely something I wish I'd fixed before release. Would hardly have taken me any time at all to change the floor colour :(

I dunno, I dig the two color scheme. I didn't have any depth or distance issues while playing. The control scheme is odd, through. Pressing down doesn't go down, bur pressing diagonal down left or right goes down. It's kind of hard to find the cat, and the enemies didn't really prove to be a threat at all. Some fine tuning here and there will easily bump this up a few notches. HOORAY FOR UNITY!!!
This game has an interesting m.c. escher like look. I like that minimalistic style.
The introductory texts are displayed to short to read completely.
Reminds me a lot an old game for speccy named "Ant Attack"
Hooray for +1 kitten games.  It was interesting trying to find it based on the loudness of the meows.  Could use some kind of win screen though when you find it :)
@guzzungo Yep. Ant Attack was pretty much the template for this. I've never actually played it but I've always liked the style of the visuals and it seemed like a good fit for the theme.
@philhassey You have to lead the kitten back to the entrance if you want to see the win screen :)
@tcstyle I read pretty fast, sometimes I forget that's not normal. Will have to bear that in mind next time and slow the text down to a pace that regular mortals can handle...
@SonnyBone It's not supposed to be *easy* to find the cat, that wouldn't be much of a game, would it? ;)

Interesting that the isometric controls seem to be confusing people, it used to be a pretty common layout back in the day. It helps if you turn your keyboard at a 45 degree angle so that the keys line up with the axes of the game world.

description:

The game is a treasure colletting game on floating randomly generated islands.
To move use the arrow keys and if you press SPACEBAR + direction you can dig in that direction.
Once you have collected all the treasures in a map a new map will be created :)
Hope you enjoy this :) Mark :)
author: MarkSkyzoid
title: I Was Wondering on Floating Islands
comments: It's good but the physics are really buggy.
nicely done mark loving falling out the map :D
I like the game :D! but i want to place blocks too so i cant create something
Well, it's all right for a one afternoon effort, but what could it have been with a 48 hour effort?
Fun game, I ended up practically destroying the entire island.

Posting as is... it's meager though

author: Sparrow
title: Hermit (unfinished)
comments: I like the graphics and advancing time (despite being a dev thing, I feel that a hold to speed up time for a farming sim would be a feature many users would want). I would also prefer having all the UI information without having to pause the game first.
I wish you guys had more time to add to it. I can definitely see this evolving into something really cool. :)

Keep at it. Its a good start!

description: Use the arrow keys to move. You play as a depressed man who is very lonely.
author: elektron
title: Goodbye
comments: Great art style and music. I could not get past the part that had the text "That's why I have to do this"
Congrats on your first Ludum Dare! I didn't find the cat... and I also got stuck on the same part as Jiyko. THAT PART IS HARD!
Nice game! I finished it but could not find the cat.. I even played twice to find it ;)
Feels like a nicely polish small game.
I would strongly recommend using a game pad. I used joyToKey, but you could look into including automatic joystick detection.

I enjoyed this quite a bit, though I am also a sucker for anything pixel. The simplistic graphics worked well to convey a feeling of being alone. Audio worked, though some sounds sounded a bit cut off. Gameplay was challenging, but sometimes I wouldn't be able to jump while moving making it needlessly frustrating. Got stuck and decided to quit XD. Congratz on making a great game!
I also had problems moving and jumping at the same time, managed to get to the end but the "That's why I have to do this" room was really hard because of this =[
Good atmosphere to the game, I'll have to try again to find the kitten :D

description:
For Glory is a game about the dangerous expedition of a young hero into the depths of hell.
It's a dungeon crawler featuring candles, coins and a lot of skeletons. And perhaps a kitten.
EDIT: I've quickly assembled a gameplay trailer;
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WwzMRQpw9jE
author: SLiV
title: For Glory!
comments: Impressed how much context you created.  The lighting was probably the best thing here.  The difficulty curve was completely punishing though - I couldn't get past the third screen!  Good effort
I was really impressed with this one, I shat my pants when I died after being sneaked up on by an unseen enemy in a dark passage in the fifth or sixth level.
This game is brutal, but a ton of fun; Great work, feel free to pat yourself on the back. :)
Aha, impressive. Love the lighting and damn the third level was hard, damn enemies in the corner shooting ;D
Great game. It got really difficult quickly - after around the 8th level, I just ran for the exit (because my "heroic" exploits won't be known by anyone other than myself).

Love the lighting! Hard as crap... but at least I can look at pretty lights while I die repeatedly. :p Kinda hard to see the coin piles on my screen. I was NOT expecting the leveling system. Good work!
I played the first levels killing & collecting everything, after that i just rushed, so the boss battle was impossible for me due to not having enought XP. Very good game! :)
The lighting is excellent. The gameplay is frustrating. Unless there's some trick to it, it's very hard to tell the melee skulls from the shooting skulls. What does gold do?
The lighting is great, but many rooms are way too dark. Great amount of content.
I'm pleasently surprised by all the positive remarks. Thanks!
And yes, I realise the game is pretty difficult. For some reason all my games are. I guess it's because I'm usually the only playtester.

description:
My first ever Ludum Dare game. It's about a small, pixelated thing who wants to be alone. And then the monsters come.
The graphics were made in MSPaint and the sounds with sfxr.
Features:
* A somewhat epic story
* About 10 minutes of exciting gameplay
* Seven enemies to defeat (they're in each corner of the pattern)
* Cute pixel graphics
* A parallax starfield
* Only 5 colours!
author: Nanofi
title: Ego Sum
comments: Just uploaded an updated version - now with a retry button!
Great game.  I love the parallax starfield.  It's pretty clear what you need to do from the beginning.  Not all the fun, but a good game and awesome mood!
im actually not sure i was doing what i was supposed to, because i wasn't actually "defeating" anything, i was making them chase me around
There's a hint in the middle :) "you have to lure them together"
Congrats on your first dare, Nanofi. :)

As the others have said, try to make sure everybody just understands how to play and what they're doing--especially for small games like LDs. It has some pretty cool mechanics, so you really want everybody to be able to see everything.
A bit more polish, and you could have been really onto something.
I gave up after a while - randomly searching map for more enemies to lure together was too boring. If you've added something like compass hint on the edge of the screen, it would be much better.
Oh, was it that unclear? The gray lines lead to the right places.

description:
Framework: ImpactJS
Pixel Editor: Acorn
Text Editor: Emacs
Music Editor: Live
Hope you enjoy it.
author: hyperlogic
title: Charlotte Sometimes
comments: The best parts of the game were the graphics. The color palette of the flowers contrasts with the monochrome background and main character to more clearly tell the story. The overall game idea seems like an interesting take on the theme. It could benefit from some sound effects, possibly music.
Playing the web version and it seems to lock up after exiting the first room.
The web version worked fine for me (Chrome)/

Nice concept, and the game mechanic can allow for some interesting puzzles. But waaaay too slow. I had to stop at the 5th level or so because waiting for the water tile things to slide across a large room was agonizing. It also seemed like the water tiles can be used regardless of their orientation to the pump, which makes it possible to cheat.
The visuals are nice. I agree with Feyleaf in that the contrast of colour to monochrome works well. The main character could benefit from up & down facing sprites.

The concept is quite cool; I would've been interested to see more interesting elements in deciding how to place the blocks, perhaps at the expense of the length of the game. It's very original, and the graphics look terrific.
The game could've benefit more from having a strict tile to tile movement for blocks, as it was easy to get them stuck in a pixel, but the potential for some good puzzling was there.
Pushing blocks was a bit boring. But the concept is very clever, and also very cute.
Nice short game! Graphics were really good I think, audio didn't work for me. Could have used some more elements but it's ok :)
Nice idea, but too buggy: 1.You still push block if you/block can`t move because of walls (telekinesis XD). 2.You can move flowers (I did it on a level shown on a main screenshot)

description: Arrow keys to move, R to reset.
author: Draknek
title: By Your Side
comments: Fun puzzle game :) I enjoyed playing it

I feel like I've played some puzzle games similar to this one before, but I liked the wrinkles this one added (reusing a single map many times to present different puzzles, I *really* liked the concept with the music). Hurt my fingers pretty bad by the end because I kept wanting to punch the arrow keys one at a time to create interesting rhythms instead of holding down the arrows as would be easier (it is to be interpreted as a good thing that the game left me wanting to play this way). I had a little bit of trouble understanding the movement rules at very first because it was not immediately obvious the game DENIES FEMALE AGENCY.
I'm not sure if I should have laughed at the "twist" midway through, but I totally did.
If only she had been more obedient... it could have been avoided.
Great Game! The puzzles had a decent amount of difficulty in them -- It was fun to beat it! On the twist scene, I was all like Â¨I wonder If I could do this... lol, I can!Â¨. Maybe IÂ´m evil :-P
I liked the idea of the music playing as you played, but I didnÂ´t like the exact sounds themselves.
ya i liked the idea of music playing when you move..the sound sounds alot like reason :)
Loved the sound, Excellent touch to an already fun and quirky puzzle game!
Surprisingly hard, enjoyed the twist. :] Sounds concept is great.
I'm not smart enough for this type of gameplay.

I love puzzle games and this one was great. I played it again and actually saved her for being hit by the car but realize  that was not suppose to happen ;) Oh well. This was a great game and you got my ratings.
Zuieni: ooh, nice catch! I worked out that it _should_ be impossible to save her, but I didn't factor in bugs...
Suuuper intelligent game, I loved how every map introduced a new mechanic using the same puzzle pieces.

title: Apoc: Apocalypse Shooter
comments: Hm, where do I download it?
Sorry! Added links for the exe and the web build.
Not bad. Reminded me of Atari days playing Robotron.
It could have greatly benefited from some sound effects.
I ended up making my own sound effects with my mouth while playing.
The mouse sensitivity is a bit high and the arrow is visible on screen and gets locked when it hits the side forcing you to unwind it by spinning the opposite direction.
I liked the in game obstacle construction and the helpless feeling of being overwhelmed.

description:
Simple game but was fun to make :D
Engine: Stencyl
Tools: MSPaint
author: exe
title: Alone in all Elona
comments: Very impressive, the idea behind the gameplay of this game was very original! I could play it for a long time.

There is just one serious bug in my opinion, that makes the game very frustrating to play: When you click and move the mouse to tilt your hand, the position of the mouse changes (even though the hand is stopped). So when you release the button, the mouse will re-appear in a completely different place. This makes it difficult to make precise movements. Maybe you should hold the mouse position when tilting the hand.
But other than that, I really liked this game!
We did equate that issue as the major issue but could not solve it in Stencyl :)
Yes, this made the game impossible to play for me..
Damn just realised that you cannot set the mouse cursor in flash apps, makes sense but means we cannot fix this issue until we redo the entire game in another format :(
Interesting concept, but the difficult controls made me ragequit.

description:
It's half-baked but you can at least see what I was trying to do. Click through the brain menu, only 1 of the 4 stages was complete so any that you choose will take you to that one. This was a great lesson in having a more reasonable scope for a 48-hour competition.
Go shoot some creepy faces! Enjoy! So sleeepy, going to pass out now.

title: AL One
comments: Unfortunately, doesnt seem to work on my machine, spits out an error about a missing .dll file and crashes.  Maybe you forgot to package a .dll?  seems to be related to something called OIC, I'm running Windows XP, I'll rate it if you fix it.
Hey CplMustard, I'll run XP from VirtualBox and see what's missing, thanks for the heads up!
You need to have CG installed:

I don't know if the music is supposed to sound like that but it kind of worked given the theme.
The initial presentation was very good.
As a game it had its problems with control that felt a bit strange. I did't enjoy so much playing it but the presentation made an impression.
If you improve the control and add more models/graphics, it has potential for becoming a great game.
I get the same as CplMustard, sadly.
Yay, a fellow Ogre3d user! I used this for my entry, except mine was extremely primitive as I had little experience with it before =/ However I have missing dlls apparently

The music worked for this game, but gave me a headache...  The controls are also somewhat weird, but maybe is because I am not that used to FPS.  Once I've killed all the faces, I ended up in a big room with a black wall and I didn't know what to do after, so I closed.  The graphics were well done.

I have to rate you poor on community: not only I had to download a ~100MiB ZIP file that had no top level directory, but then I had to download and install yet *another* toolkit just to have the Cg.dll file, something you should distribute with your game, I think.

description: A puzzle/platformer kept short because of time constraints. Use arrow keys to move and z, x, and c in game. Also, first time entering!(Woo-Hoo!)
author: SparkCloud
title: Together
comments: Idea is amazing! But I think that the game is a little bit boring after a level or two beacuse you already got the concept. Nice game at overall!
Great job! I found the control scheme took some getting used to but it was neat once I got the hang of it. It would be cool to see some kind of "mode" indicator to show if I am using blue guys, etc.
I was able to use 64 bit windows 7 with no issues, but I have game maker installed. I wonder if that's it?
Interesting concept. Good for a game made in 5 hours, but could become greatly expanded into somewhat of a highly original game if more work were to be taken onto it. Nice job!
Sorry, the installer put me off. I don't want to install anything that tries to also install searchbars and non-specified statistics about me and/or my computer. Did'nt try it.
Z,X,C did not work for me. I was able to move with the arrow keys.  Every one in a while, my little guy would start bleeding all over the place for no reason.

author: Ethanh59
title: Thrown Away
comments: Very cryptic. Having to type move left and move right continuously is bad. Thank god for copy and paste. Got the bottle and the watch... no clue what to do to get coconuts.. nothing I typed would be accepted. I can see you tried a hint system sort of though.
What helloserve said... extremely cryptic and even frustrating. I tried throwing a rock at the tree :(. I drank some water and slept. It's nice that you implemented a day/night cycle!
It could maybe do with some better hints, at least showing basic commands...
As said before, I think the worse part about this are the controls or lack of hints/control list.
your website seems to be down :(

While it might have been nice idea, constantly writing go left / go right made me feel like i was playing some "type them up" game :( it becomes extremely annoying / frustrating after a few moments. (if you at least gave us possibility to reuse last command...)
Lol i died from dirty sea water. ^^

description:
So it's my first Ludum Dare, and I decided to make a word game for some reason.
Art made with Blender.
Music+sounds made with Ableton Live.
Coding is AS3 in FDT.
If you want to see the community posts I made during the jam, look here: http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/author/mattrix/
Note: Once you get the hang of the game, try getting a move count of 8. It's possible to do it every single game if you plan it out.
author: Matt Rix
title: The Word Alone
comments: Beautiful graphics. Unique concept. Really awesome job. I won in 24 moves!
I can see myself coming back to this again and again.
I always think there can't be any more original find-a-word-from-these-letters game ideas, and then someone clever like you surprises me.
i like this one a lot
Astounding accomplishment for 48 hours, I can't even begin to imagine how this was done. Oh, hello source code.
Ha, this is fun. And ridiculously hard.
Good use of theme :) And quite nice puzzle
I'm really impressed with this. Great Job. This is one of my favorites so far!
Really enjoyed this game. Took a bit of time, but after a few tries I got it :D Graphics and Music all really look and sound great, too.
The small-masks of the buttons are driving me insane. They should be all the way to the edge. BALRAGAHGAHL.

Great concept and it really fits the theme. My only serious critique is that it took me several confusing games to figure out how to play. Clearer directions or a play example would be nice to add if you continue development after the jam.
BlueShaman: thanks for pointing that out, small hit areas bug me too. I swear I made sure they were correct at one point, but I guess I screwed them up somehow later, heh.
Excellent, original concept. Audio and graphics fit with it well. SImple but brilliant.
amazingly simple and addictive. love it.
oh this is great! i love word games! excellent execution!
back here playing it again aaaaa
Yeah, I keep coming back to it, even though I know the trick to get it in 8 moves every time.  It's seriously fun and addictive.
Very creative take on the theme and very well done as well.  As I am not a native English speaker sometimes I had problems finding out words, but I could manage most of the time.
15 moves. This game is really good in several ways! Thank you!
Loved it! It's easy once you get the hang of it, but a very clever concept, smooth execution, and creative use of the theme.
This game is nice but a bit too short. The 3D art is beautiful, the music reminds me of Myst or something. Anyway, 11 moves. :)

description:
CONTROLS
X : Select item in main menu
R : Reset room
Arrow keys : move around
C : Surprise! :)
GAME
You're a adventurer who got trapped into a temple, the Temple of Loneliness, and you want to get out, but getting out comes with a price. You have to complete a series of challenges (puzzles) in order to get to the treasure room, but avoid the spikes because you only got one life.
The game is simple with cute graphics. There's some known bugs that I couldn't solve in time but they are so little that you wont even see them.
Please leave your comments if you liked the game about what is cool or not and, if you want, vote for my game if you really think it's good and it deserve your vote ;).
Thanks.
author: alexquantum
title: Temple of Loneliness
comments: It looks cool and the puzzles are nice, but jeeze, death is way too harsh, it makes the game super frustrating to play! Especially with how long the intro is to go through every time. I quit out of frustration after just my fourth death on spikes!
Yeah I know I didn't have enought time to play test it completely. I should've make it restart only the level... But thanks for the comment appreciated :)
This is waaay to frustrating. I rated, but it cannot possibly convey be objective..

I added a version that is fun to play. In this new version, you now have 3 lifes and when you die you can press r to resetart from this level. This version can't count for LD but if you want to finish it without rage quitting it's probably better.

Cute graphics and decent concept but as you've no doubt already realized, having the player have to restart the game after every death was a huge oversight which will cost you dearly muahhahaha. And now that I've rated this version, I'll go ahead and give the 'fun' version a try :D
Your HowTo screen ruined the surprise :P hah.
Very neat concept, like Sokoban and gladOS had a baby. My only beef is that dying made me restart the whole game, including the "tutorial" levels. Otherwise, very enjoyable.
Extra points because we apparently have the same laptop model! :)
Quite excellent indeed. A bit on the baby-punching status and the original version with the menu screen after death and all, but still one of the best I've seen so far.

the speed/pacing made dying very punishing, and replaying somewhat unpleasant.
You have some incredibly high levels of polish on this game.  I really like the visual white noise overlay, and the soundtrack is just awesome.

This is cool. Great amount of polish! I agree though that the speed is a little slow.
Very nice looking, but small area of view add some artificial difficulty. Great entry.
Sweet graphics and sounds. well done!

thank you all for your feedback, criticism, and nice words :)
holy heck, this is extremely polished and looks fantastic. nice job!
It looks very good (nice mood :), but the oh so slowness combined with restarting from the start with every small mistake makes it quite annoying... I rage quit after a while :/
Like the salvo-effect. Feels hefty. Mood is nice aswell.

description:
This is a small top-down arcade game. You're all alone, trapped in a building when the security system activates. Progress through floors by disabling sentries using EMP charges. But you have to disable them all in one shot, and stay out of sight!
I'm pretty happy with the result. My aim was something as simple as the original Lode Runner, and in about the same vain. I think I succeeded in simple; the code is less than a thousand lines, but that didn't make it less a challenge to write! ;)
What I personally find most lacking about the result is that I haven't been able to find the time to create some challenging levels. There's a short but adequate tutorial, and one very simple level.
Still, I very much hope you enjoy it!
Browser support:
- Chrome: Tested in Chrome 16, current beta. Should work in any recent version.
- Firefox: Tested in Firefox 9, current beta. Should work in any recent version.
- Opera: Requires (and tested in) Opera 11.60, current stable.
- Safari: Broken on current releases. (Due to HTML Canvas bugs.)
- IE: Broken on current releases. Might just work in IE10 preview, but untested.
Post-deadline updates:
- Dec 19: Browser compatibility update.

description:
Not/Alone is loosely based around the idea of running from your fears. Though you can't see them, they're still there...
Controls:
W/Up - Move up
A/Left - Move left
S/Down - Move down
D/Right - Move right
Collect the green blocks while avoiding the white. Collecting a green block will destroy half of the white blocks chasing you down and gain you 1 point.
While in the light world, the white blocks do you no harm and cannot move. Use this as a chance to escape certain doom.
The worlds alternate automatically - 4 seconds in the light followed by 6 seconds of darkness, each switch bringing more enemies your way. Keep collecting green blocks to keep their numbers in check.

This game gets really hard! But it's way too slow though. Mouse move would've been a good addition too, would feel much more natural.

Ok I thought the white screen was a bug until I reread your description. It's a decent idea but it doesn't feel quite right. Whenever the white screen comes on you're just kind of waiting for it to change back. Cool pixel smoke effect at the bottom of the screen though!

Difficult to play due to the speed you move at or the size of the squares. Gameplay is good, controls are good, graphics are good. However, there's no fun or audio (that I know of, I use Chrome) and the square is just a square, not a person, and I can't sympathise with a 'lonely' square. Good work with the graphics and gameplay.

description:
The God Dude, the god of the universe, is a very lonely omnipotent individual. He is stuck in a big, empty universe with no one else around.
He decides to change this by making little Dudes to entertain him! He is, after all, A GOD!!!
The only problem is that the God Dude doesn't like death. If five of his Dudes kill each other, he will get so depressed that he will send the rest of them into the darkness of the universe. So, see how long you can last!
Info:
At the second evolution onwards, the dudes will start firing at each other. You can click to heal them one point of health. Health is 4 * evolution level, so they start out with 4 health at the beginning of the game.
At the final evolution, they split into two baby dudes and it starts again.
Record thus far is one minute and four seconds (my record). *PLEASE POST A SCREENSHOT IF (when) YOU BEAT MY RECORD!!! :D *

description:
Incomitat was made in a huge hurry, but I'm quite proud of it.
There's no real 'point' in the game, you can explore the island and try to figure out why you're alone. There's a boss in the game, try to find it!
CONTROLS:
WSAD - movement
Left mouse button - action
E - drop your active item
Q - open full inventory (you can move stuff around here)
Space - view map
You can use the mousewheel and number buttons to cycle between your active items. Use Q to switch item slots.
author: Hempuli
title: Incomitat
comments: Procedural generation needs some work, enemies are overpowered, and you die too quickly when swimming.  The footprints are a nice touch, though.

The graves were kinda crazy. Would've liked more stuff to do and more reliable PCG, but its enjoyable to look at regardless, and digging and planting and chopping feels tactile enough. Likely too ambitious for an LD, hope to see it polished later.

This is such a large concept to be an entry in a 48 hour competition.  I'm impressed by how far you managed to take this in such a short time, but as you say yourself, the only way this concept really shines is via feature creep.

There's a lot of fun and interesting things you can do, and yet ultimately they seem to "mean" nothing.  It's very existentialist.  I found myself getting hungry and almost dead, after screwing around and having fun, and I asked myself "what did I just do with my life?"
Keep the hunger, but maybe find new ways you can stave it off?  Otherwise, just keep adding the strange and wonderful.

For a game made in 48 hours, its really well made with nice graphics and features. However, while its fun to explore and find out stuff by yourself, i just didn't knew what to do with most of the things...and the hunger didn't help much either (too quick).

My other complain would be the inventory screen, not only is a bit of a pain to switch out items, but from the 3 times i played the game, i managed to break the inventory, having 2 items in 1 slot, having a item on the cursor with the inventory full, unable to switch or drop, etc, so i couldn't finish the game, if there's a end that is.
Controls very nicely, sprites are consistent and stick to a cool style. Very impressive for a 48-hour game!
There is a sort of a boss that you can beat, but since finding it is extraordinarily unobvious, it could be said that the game can't be beaten!
Thanks for the compliments, and I mostly agree with the criticism - too ambitious for LD and thus lacks content to make it interesting. I'll also need to tweak (or remove) the hunger system.

I was actually a bit surprised about the inventory bug stuff - hadn't noted them myself! Thanks for telling, and I agree that the inventory is horribly unintuitive atm (it doesn't help that my mousewheel is partially broken).
It's the first one that I want to see the source :) love it! nice job.
Pretty cool entry, especially for the challenge of doing something which works on this scale. Keep up the good work!

description:

description:
hikikomori (countable and uncountable; plural hikikomori)
1. (uncountable) The phenomenon whereby an individual becomes a recluse from society, typically confining him- or herself to the house or a single room for a very long period.
2. (countable) A reclusive person of this kind.
Hikikomori Manager 2012 allows you to live the life of a hikikomori.
* Be an outcast in Japanese society!
* Live a life of solitude, unable to leave your room without having a panic attack!
* Struggle against depression!
* Watch your life decay as you become poor and unhealthy!
There is no clear goal in this game. You might want to try to become a functioning member of society again, or just try to survive as long as possible.
(The latest version can be played at http://www.stack.nl/~vdz/hikki/ . Note that that version is not the version that should be rated for LD22!)

description:

Throughout the level you will encounter different colored blocks. You can pass through them only if you are the same color. For any other color they will be a wall.

comments: I found it extremely dark, didn't really know what to do.

The difficulty curve is quite steep, and the total darkness outside of the light ball's point light is probably to blame. You should consider adding a very low intensity directional light from above going straight down; it wouldn't kill the atmosphere if it were low enough and it would make negotiating the maze in the dark slightly less painful.

Also, final point, when you are using a mouse look for a Unity game, you should use Screen.lockcursor=true; to hide and centre the mouse so it doesn't get in the way or inadvertently click a banner whilst playing.
High marks all round for a very creative puzzler.
PS. I did try to respond to your message on my game (Vestige), but it tells me to sign it to comment when I'm already signed in, so I'm not being rude by not answering. Thanks for playing :)

description:
OVERVIEW:
The original idea behind this game was that you'd be able to roam around an environment, collecting objects from which you'd gain their letters. You'd then be able to use these as a means to further interact with the environment (opening doors, story elements, etc). Unfortunately, that was slightly out-of-scope, so the concept has been reduced to this platformer.
INSTRUCTIONS:
Collect the letters in the red chests and use them against enemies by which correspond to the 'keyword' above them. Enemies are as strong as the length of their keyword, though you can use the same (if you find several) letters multiple times.
CONTROLS:
UP/LEFT/RIGHT - Move & Jump.
SPACE - Interact.
A-Z - Use letters. (Enemies must be on-screen).
NOTES:
- There's not much visual feedback, sorry.
- I was meaning to implement Scrabble-like scores for each letter, but whilst writing this I realised I'd forgotten.
author: 3ndo
title: Alone With Your Thoughts
comments: Fun game, it has a good feeling to it. But I couldn't find out how to use the letters against the enemies. I tried jumping on them or pressing space when nearby, but nothing seemed to work :(
The jumping was a little spastic at times and I couldnt figure out how to use letters on enemies, I just avoided them for most of the time.  Is there an end?
I keep hitting my had on platforms right above making jumps rather difficult
Thanks guys. I've updated the instructions with a controls section.

This is a pretty cool concept for a game. With a bit of polish it could be really solid. As you've mentioned some more visual feedback would help. The platforming is a bit wonky as well. One simple fix would be to have the jump key work on key release rather than press. It seems like it's impossible to get to the highest platforms on the level?

I like your original concept, too bad the scope was so big :P I think if you highlighted the letters the player had in enemy's trigger word rather than having to check the alphabet at the top of the screen it would have been a lot clearer what had to be done. Oh and Scrabble scoring sounds cool, but maybe that's the Scrabble fan in me talking.

Although the original concept sounds good, this implementation doesn't make it justice.  The platforms are located in such a way that every time I try to jump I hit my head, making it harder that it should, in my opinion.  Also, I tried to use the letters on the enemies, but there was no visible effect.  It is also rather difficult to see the theme in this game.

The concept is somewhat innovative. As you said, there wasn't enough visual feedback, and as has been said, the jumps and collisions are kind of frustrating. I am wondering if I've missed a wallkick or double jump mechanism, because it's easy to get stuck and screw yourself.
Points for fun, and points for innovation. Quite unique, just annoying in the collisions department.

comments: I HIGHLY suggest compiling the game now and uploading that as the submission. Many people will be scared away from trying your game if they have to compile it first (or may not know how to or have the tools to do so).

It was a bit buggy and nonsensical, but it was fairly fun and a little creepy. I think you need some consistency with how the controls behave (clicking on something vs clicking on an item, then on something), since that was a tad annoying.

To anyone who hasn't found it, there's a debug binary in 'Source Code\ludumdare\ludumdare\bin\x86\Debug' which *may* work for you (I'm running on a Vista dev machine). At the very least it probably needs the xna and .net frameworks.
Could have been a compiled file provided separately, had to use the debug binary:
Regardless there are solid elements, the theme alone along with its, creepy moods are present along with and a bit of ill humor.
It was brought down by a couple of bugs and control inconsistencies however.

description:

description:
You're a small, lonely kitten, looking for someone to love. It's a short game with FIVE different endings, depending on your actions (not very complicated though). One full playthrough should take no more than 10-12 minutes (note that finishing the game depends on events done, rather than amount of fish). One of the endings is an easter egg. :)
It's my second entry in LD48 and first game using Flixel. See my journal (http://www.ludumdare.com/compo/author/marudziik/) for more info.
BTW. See that progress bar on the top? When it's full, next event will occur, providing you're in the right place (usually near/far from the human). After a few (12 or so) such events, the game will end.
author: marudziik
title: Someone To Love
comments: OMG, at first I though you had to give him all the fish.
The ending depends on the quantity of fish given?
Yes and no. 3 endings depend on the quantity of fish given to the human, and there are 2 special endings, for which you need to find a special item.
The game definitely fit the mood, but after the first few fish, got kind of repetitive, hopping up those same blocks multiple times.
Really nice interpretation of the theme, a bit repetitive though. Nice audio and graphics otherwise.
That is one philosophical kitten! Climbing those blocks does begin to feel like work after the first 5 times or so. Liked the music and 2-colour visuals.

I like the mood and the music and how talkative the cat is without repeating itself. The controls make it hard to jump on those small platforms, also the blue color is hard too see when you play this during the day but overall it's a nice little game, congrats :)

But the art style and the music combined were just cute beyond all reason.  If you were to clean up the jumping a bit and rethink the level design it would be solid gold.

At least money bags don't reset, though I'd like a few more checkpoints. My biggest gripe is that this doesn't fit the theme. It was "alone", not "kittens". Don't get me wrong though, I like the artworks :) 5 stars on community for kitty badge :)

description:
A game where you must survive on a desert island long enough to be rescued. Balance your limited food (provided by coconuts) with wood used for your signal fire: burn too much too fast and you might starve to death!
Incidentally this game was made with a rather stricter time constraint than 72 hours - I started from scratch around 4 hours before the Jam deadline. So, it might not be as polished (or fun) as other Jam entries but I'm still pretty pleased with what I got done.
Controls:
Left and Right arrow keys: Move
Mouse: Interact
Clicking a coconut tree while it has coconuts will eat the coconuts. Clicking a coconut tree while it has no coconuts will cut it down. Win by building your fire big enough to attract a rescue ship!
Made with XNA 4.0. Please make sure you have the XNA 4.0 Runtime installed (http://www.microsoft.com/download/en/details.aspx?id=20914).

description:
This is my third game in Ludum Dare. I tried my best so far in this one spending soooo much time to get it done. I agreed that I would do a physics game for this Ludum because everyone loves physics. The only hard part was fitting the theme into it which I got an idea for. It took me a lot of resources to make this game so I will list them here:
-Photoshop (Huge help)
-Mixcraft (My Audio from guitar and synth)
-Audacity (Lowering or sound files)
-FlashDevelop (The program for flash 'Duh')
-FlashPunk Classes
-Box2d physics
-Probably more that I cant think of right now
Audio: Created by mixcraft mainly. The sounds were either recorded from my guitar or a composition of notes in mixcraft
Graphics: I basically used vectors and textures in PS for the graphics. This took a good portion of the time I had. The trash can especially took the longest because of 2 layers
Theme: I came up with a story line sort of for the whole game. I said that you were a kid growing up with your family and your family is leaving for a Christmas party and you dont wanna go. So you stay home and you cant find anything to do. Eventually you find a bouncy ball and start playing with it and that is what the game is based off of. It continues through the different levels
GamePlay:
The concept of the game is to do teh objective of the level, which is usually to knock down all of the blocks or get the ball into the trash can. But there is variation involved in the later levels
-Walls
-Red Blocks
-Gravity
-Stars
-Limited bounces
-Much more!
Good luck to everyone participating in Ludum Dare 22!!

description:
This is my entry for the Jam - unfinished and unpolished sad to say.
My original idea was to make a reflective game around the theme where the character feels alone due to suffering depression. They are in this dark pit and stuck on a pillar all alone. There would be text-based narration like 'Bastion'.
The gameplay was supposed to be as follows: as the game starts, the player would say something to the effect of 'Every now and then I have a good day, think look up and I feel like I could float on air'. As he says this, gravity stops for a moment and the player can jump and float to the next pillar. At each pillar the player would say something new, indicating the journey out of depression is working. As the player climbs higher and higher the background would become lighter and eventually the stars falling in the background would become leaves and the sun would break through the fog in the background.
Obviously the game doesn't have much of what I've described in it - you can move and jump with the arrow keys and spacebar. Sounds should work in Chrome and Firefox, music will only work in Chrome. I haven't tested on other browsers.
Mainly just putting this here so I can say I was in, and to get some feedback on my idea :P

description:
So, fine gentlemen, gentlewomen, and gentlealiens, I present to you Rocket Man Stan!
Set in the early 70s, follow our intrepid hero, Stan, as he fights his way off of a Soviet-invaded moon after a covert USAF mission goes awry on the dark side of the moon! Get him to safety by destroying all the Soviet robots Goomba-style so that he can radio for help!
Some back story:
This was GOING to be an LD48 entry, but due to a last minute(literally) happening coming up, I was not able to submit, so I took the extra day and polished it up some. Later I'll make this into a full-blown game, for Eggplant Animation(eggplantanimation.com). This is my second LD, first one alone, and I think I did pretty well, considering what I learned over the course of 48 hours and what I couldn't do just last summer. Uses Flash and Flixel, with FlashDevelop and DAME to help. I plan to release the source sometime in the next month.
Controls:
Left/Right to move, Space to jump. Kill those robots, 9 in all, by jumping on top of them ("goomba-style"). The health bar is in the upper-left corner, with the number of lives left next to it.
-Dr. Quigley the Insane

johnmagicson: Hehe, yeah, it does suck a lot. I don't work well within a time constraint, and I'm not that good at making games in the first place anyway. Thanks for the constructive criticism! :)
Sanguine: The maps are pseudo-random: Basically, this is how I do generation:
Step 1- Make an array of 'cells'. Mark four as open, and the rest as closed. These four open cells are the player spawn point, the block spawn point, the kiln's square, and a 'dummy' square.
Step 2- Link the player cell to the block cell, the block cell to the dummy cell and kiln cell, and the kiln cell to the player cell, marking all cells on the way as open.

Step 3- For every cell that is open, count the exits. For each specific combination of exits (only north, south and west, south, west, and east, etc.), there are five possible rooms. It slots one of these chosen randomly into the cell. In total, there are 75 possible rooms.
Step 4- Output it all to a tilemap and place the objects at the corresponding points.
So it's not entirely random, but I am quite proud of what I did with it.

I guess it's just a tech demo at this point, heh. I wanted to add puzzles and stuff, and there was going to be enemies stalking you through the maze, but I ran out of time due to my busy weekend. Check out my post-mortem too, if you like. Thanks for the critique <3

description:
Kuudou is an exploration game in which players should guide a "lone lorn creetur" around a huge, empty and extremely dark cave.  Somehow the creature has developed the ability to make her own body glow, but it is not enough to see far off in the distance.  Fortunately, the cave is not so empty as would seem a priory.  There are some critters lurking in the dark, and they have very, very bright eyes.
Using the eyes of the critters wandering around each stage, it is possible to make a mental map of where are the platforms and jump around to the exit.  All the levels are doable with that can be seen and what can be inferred by the position of every creature or by jumping around the area.  Some of the jumps require almost pixel-perfect collision that, together with the already frustrating environment, make the experience a little less enjoyable than what I wanted.
Please don't mind the name and the fake Japanese characters on the title screen.  In the README there is the reason behind it all, for these that are interested.
Kuudou is made in C++ using the SDL and SDL_mixer libraries.  The sound effect (there is only one) was made with sfxr and the background music with its four notes was made with Schism Tracker and a royalty-free freeware sample.
author: summaky
title: kuudou
comments: Really enjoyed it!  I liked the eye mechanic, it with the darkness just worked.
What I really enjoyed was the mood, nice job :)
The Linux/source file is corrupt, just so you now ;) But the Windows version works with wine.

I like the concept a lot, and the graphics are well-done, especially the player animation.  Unfortunately, the game is too short to really explore the concept and it's frustrating at the beginning when you're figuring the game out.
It's cool how the game tries to mislead the player in the later levels. I wish this was longer and used more mechanics!
Nice. I liked the minimalistic approach. The game mechanic works well.
It`s little short but good. Nice mood and graphic ;)
A bit short. I would have loved to play some more levels... and thats quite telling. :) Great gameplay idea.
oh wow, this was a really interesting game. you're definitely on to something here. i enjoyed it!
Loved the darkness, really got me. The way my eyes adjusted to looking for the creature pixels was kind of amazing, because I didn't notice them at first. Good job on making a special experience.
Oh no :( I get an "Unexpected end of archive" error when I unzip the Windows version.
I really liked the game. Good controls and sharp graphics. The "Pixel perfect" jumps didn't bother me at all, since dying was quite painless (quickly returned to the start of the small level).
Thanks for rating so many games too!

I read your read me and was suprised how self deprecating you are.  The pixel perfect jumping is fine, as Caranha said, the levels are so short that dieing  isn't frustrating at all.  I like the name and I like the character animation, the music is fantastic.

I agree with Hempuli, the later levels do tend to trick the player which is great.  Not knowing which critters to trust and their indifference to you works well with the theme.  Overall I think this game feels complete.
That said, the level design could be refined to explore the concept more concretely so that each level is some new manifestation of that mechanics possibilities.

author: ArchPenguinBot
title: I Should Go Back
comments: This game is ridiculous.  I mean, it does not even make any sense at all.
Strong opening, but I was not up for solving the puzzle with the numbers.

Surprisingly ambitious amount of storytelling in this one, although the story is very weird I thought it was pretty interesting. Then I realized you wanted me to solve some absolutely insane number puzzle, so I reloaded the game and walked into the space lizards mouth :)
Hmm, my description did not show up on this page for some reason.  Well, here's the tutorial:  http://dl.dropbox.com/u/25116236/ISGBexplanation.txt
All right, the description is back up.  I guess I accidentally deleted it.

My favorite game of this competition, I love the music and the way it manages to be serious yet insanely ridiculous at the same time. Plus, I like the hat. Well played, 5/5.

cute graphics... wasn't sure what exactly to do.

description:
In the dimension our hero comes from, an evil tyrant has banned magic. After leading the resistance, he was banished - censored out of his very existence. Now he wanders the shadowlands, a realm of broken dreams and forgotten things.
Ancient rumor speaks of a relic of lost happiness at the top of a tall tower, that can take one to a new world. Now it's our only hope.
Map screen:
WASD or arrows to move
Space or enter to interact.
Tilde or M for upgrade menu (every 3 monster victories gives an upgrade point)
Battle screen:
1234 or QWER will activate the spells listed at the bottom of the screen.
Spells:
Rapid - 1MP, 1 damage. +2 bonus damage to poisoned enemies.
Solo - 3MP, 4 damage. (supposed to proc extra Spark damage, did not have time)
Poison - 1MP, 0 damage. +Poison
Spark - 2MP, 2 damage. Each consecutive action raises the mana cost *and* damage. (poison is supposed to reduce its efficiency, did not have time)
