author: Falkreon
title: Erased
comments: Could not get past first enemy, I think you need more directions on how to play. When the fight starts he just blasts me a few times really quick and I'm dead. Nothing I do seems to attack him.
Yeah, I really felt the time pressure on this one. In my post-Ludum update I'll put more tutorial in. For what it's worth, 1234 or QWER are spell buttons.
Pretty sure contest rules says you can't use existing materials, and Nyancat is absolutely copyrighted.
Cool concept and I also like the random level generation.
I would prefer it if combat was a bit slower - everything seemed to die in less than two seconds!

I could pass the first 8 or 9 levels without any fight at all; not very fun.  Then tried again from the start and the first fight was a complete lost for me.  Not very intuitive for me :'(  The sound effects were also somewhat annoying.

I like how much you managed to cram into this LD in the amount of time allotted.  You had some really good ideas with the battle options and I can see where you were going with them.  I like it that poison is actually useful here!
At first I was "The brooding, it burns!"

I liked the amount of work you put in the active battles. Sadly, all that work goes to waste because your game does not have an FPS limiter. I could win the game by simply mashing the "1" button in every battle, and I wouldn't realize how close or how easily those battles were. Add some sleep time to your combat update functions.
That also applies to the "walking state" - the hardest thing in this game was hitting those damn stairs :-(

description:
Synopsis:
In Chamber of Remorse, you play as a character who is currently suffering from amnesia,
you awake in a dark chamber and have no idea as to how you got there... As far as you know, the only way out, is through...
---------------------------------------------------------
Basically, take Amnesia, and make it a top down game and add spells.
This game took me most of the 48 hours and I barely got sleep,
it has 3 unique levels and a very hard boss fight at the end, and trust me, even though there's only 3 levels, the dark maze-like feel of the game will make it quite time consuming :D
I'm most proud of myself for the lighting system I put in this game, it took me like 4 hours to get working right.
author: xBlinkedx
title: Chamber of Remorse
comments: <3 the intro noise and initial text. The lighting also really adds to the difficulty and mood. I tried to play all the way through, but gave up after 3 tries just after the destruction scroll.

I can see how the difficulty might seem reasonable if you already know where the monsters are going to spawn, but if you are ever surprised by a monster its very difficult to avoid getting hit. I think you'd have to gimp the monsters or allow mouse-firing to make the game more fun.

yeah, I had a feeling other people might find the monsters difficult, but with the little time I had left after finishing it there really wasn't much time to test. Another thing I wish I had time to fix was the bad zombie AI pathing xD

I played until the ghosts after opening the iron doors in the first level. The mood was nice, but the inventory was a bit awkward.(having to press a number to choose an item.) Perhaps it would help if things like the candle and keys didn't need to be active to use them.
You can also use the mouse wheel to scroll through the hotbar.
Creepy and fun. The only bad thing were monsters, i died twice in the first level trying to avoid and kill them.
The collision physics are really annoying, and movement is really slow considering the size of the levels. The lighting effect was well done, though.
The controls are a little to slow to move in such a big place, good job with the lights. I mush agree with the others, monsters are really difficult to avoid/kill.
Agreed, very good job on the lighting.  I would have liked mouse aiming so you could fire while running away, otherwise it's pretty hard to avoid getting hit by the monsters.  But, good job!

author: Racer260

comments: It looks really nice for a 72 3D game. The zombie model could look more zombie, but making a boy model is hard enoough, so you did a good job :)

But the game looks nice, you should be proud :)

I wish I could move a bit faster backwards and get some
feedback for whether or not I've hit a zombie.
To play online, the "Host" button must be ticked whicle launching a game, and you must have port 28000 forwarded.

Speaking as a developer of this game, Multiplayer can still fit the 'alone' theme as your group is alone in the world. Regardless, the game is meant to be played in single player and the multiplayer is just icing on the cake.
If only I wasn't too busy to help. :(
I don't like FPS neither zombies, but it looks like a pretty decent game to me.

awesome concept, the best so far :))
this is one of my favorites so far. the graphics, the idea, the music (especially the change when you're reading). this was fantastic

author: vubuntu

description:
*NOTE* I quickly added a web link. All it is is the normal game with an applet wrapper. There are options to quit the game which will not do anything in the applet version.
*NOTE2* I have added what would have been the instructions screen to the pictures for the entry. Hopefully that can help people figure out what is going on.
You are lost in the woods.  You aren't sure how you got here or where anyone else is, but you have to find your way home soon.
Sort of in the vain of old point and click adventures, but without the clicking (doesn't use the mouse).  Find, combine, and use items to solve simple puzzles.
I don't think it was explained very well (meant to put in a tutorial) but you enter areas by walking off the screen or by pressing the <ACTION> key at an entrance (path leading up or a door).  The <ACTION> key is also used to pickup/use items, but only if the item can be used. I didn't make things obvious because it is supposed to be a puzzle, but I feel I may have made what to do/how to do it a little too obscure.
The idea behind this is that the player is completely alone. No enemies, no allies, no one except the player and the environment.
I was more than half way through making the game when I realized I have no way to recovering if I die.  I was unable to come up with a system that didn't completely re-define my action system. Sorry, but if you die you have to start all over, but if you know what you are doing it only takes a couple minutes.

description:
Not too many years ago, our mother earth got destroyed by people throwing their junk into the nature.
When human kind realized this they started launching their garbage into space.
They soon realized this was a even worse misstake because when they had to leave earth, there were nowhere to go.
So they put up a reward for bringing back all their garbage to the planet.
That's where you come in, control the Garbage Drone(TM)* and collect as much junk as you can.
When the spaceday reaches it's end (even though there are none) you can sell the junk you've collected and purchase upgrades for your ship with the money.
Although be aware, people who are shooting at you are not friendly and should be eliminated ASAP.
Tools used:
Visual Studio C++ 2008
SFML 1.6
Photoshop
GameMaker's sprite editor
Controls:
WASD - Move your ship around
Space - Shoot, activate menu item
Arrow Keys / WASD - Select menu item
Other stuff:
This is my first C++ game and my fourth Ludum dare entry.
If you get stuck somewhere just drop a comment and I'll get back to you about it.
Also, I'm sorry about full CPU usage, I ran into a last minute problem with the accuracy of sf::Sleep() causing half FPS and had to uncap it.
I hope you enjoy the game!
Please leave me a comment with some feedback!
Thanks for an awesome LD,
/HighQuality

description:

Entered into the Ludum Dare 22 competition and created in less than seven hours. The theme was 'Alone'.

title: Expecting a Call
comments: Well, that game is quite addictive
Nice job! And the quickness too!
Very clever, better than my idea by a long way and actually finished :) Nice work.
what does it have to do with alone though
Is there a way to win or lose this game?

I applaud the ambition, but it is only sort of related to the theme and it is more addictive then it is fun. Kind of like a boiled down and more fair version of farmville, which isn't exactly high praise.

I'm very surprised that anybody is unsure about its connection to the theme. Each of the tenants is alone, despite how close they live to one another, and the telephone, despite each of their excitement to answer it, does not remedy their loneliness.

I feel like explaining it may do it a disservice. :( I want more games to be open to interpretation, and giving my own view of what the game means is unfortunately closes that kind of thing off, to some degree.
To help lonely people answer their phones. :)
By the way, I never acknowledged all of the positive feedback in this thread, which is actually very encouraging. I very much appreciate it.

I try to make games that are fairly conceptual (and proceduralistic, to (mis?)use Ian Bogost's term), and I recognize that sometimes this is at the expense of fun. Those are the pitfalls of exploring games as an expressive medium, though! I'm not afraid to fail a little here and there if I can simply provide an alternative to games that don't really try to say anything about anything.
Why am I shooting that Arab-type gentleman in the face? Because it's fun? Eh, it was kind of fun when I was in high school and playing Counter-Strike, now I'm just not interested.
Why am I jumping on these platforms and/or solving these puzzles? Because they're there? Eh...
[end arguably pretentious and defensive games-as-art mini-blog :P]

Clever, especially for such a short amount of time. I totally get the connection to the theme; I actually had an idea where you'd be surrounded by people on a busy city street, but how you can still feel alone in that situation :)
Thanks for the feedback, everybody else! Very much appreciated.

However, i think it's a little weird to say things like it's a "Nice little idea which needs to be expanded upon"! I'm not going to add features unless they also feed into the theme(s) I wanted to communicate.

I definitely see this being an interesting game to put on smartphones, though! The touchscreen would make a nice (albeit easier) interface, and a game about answering phones on a phone would be a pretty cool thing!

description:
Controls: Move with Arrow keys, 'Z' key for action.
This is a short game which tries to be some sort of "art game". To see all sides of it, you need to play it 2-3 times.
I think this theme wasn't the easiest one, but for me it was something which pushed to make something different than I usually do. Less gameplay, more thinking about what being alone can mean, and trying to put that into a few different stages of something. What if you want to be alone? Are you alone, or somebody else? Are you alone because there's nobody around, or because there are too much people? Are you alone because of feeling disconnected to people close to you?
So in my game there really isn't very much to do actually.. I don't want to spoil it all, but it does vary between each play if you do a bit different things.
The game has a 8 minute soundtrack, with start position synced to real clock, so it continues playing if you start game again right after exiting it.
There is also a video link. But remember that the play experience changes a bit if you play it better, and the video naturally doesn't spoil that for you, so the video really isn't a substitute for playing it yourself!
PS. LD #3 was my first one, but starting from 4th Ludum Dare I named all my entries like "Smthng Warrior"... but now I broke the pattern!!

title: Find your stuff
comments: Nice jumping platformer. The title image is very good, although the rest is a bit... repetitive :-P. The biggest problem is with the jumping curve itself which is more of a triangle than a curve, making some difficult jumps harder. On the other hand, i like the idea of "your shit" giving you powers :-P

This was funny, impressive how much of a Metroidvania you implemented in an LD timeframe. For some reason I liked that getting shorts meant you could do walljumps, there was a sort of weird logic to that. I liked how there seemed to be variety and character to the areas despite the minimal graphics (the "basement" felt very different from the "upstairs"). I also liked how the game subtly walks you past a series of areas you can't get to yet at first-- on my first trip through the level I thought I was just picking arbitrary paths, and didn't realize I was being guided in a way that was also showing me where my goals were. Well structured.

I found the game very hard to control and this made it hard to enjoy. The triangle jump was a bit odd but was manageable, what I had more of a problem with was that there didn't seem to be a way to fall "down", you could fall left and at an angle or down and at an angle but not straight down and this made it very hard to position oneself onto small platforms. Also maybe it is just my machine (Flash often runs slow for me) but I often had jerky frameskips/responsiveness issues when there was vertical scrolling going on. And the camera didn't help things, it often would point fairly high up vertically and I wouldn't be able to see what was in a sometimes very short pit except by jumping into it. Having to go ALL the way back to the beginning on death is very harsh for a game with simultaneously so much precision jumping and also a jump that impedes precision jumping and also a beginning which is a long featureless hallway. I got a ways in, then lost all three lives on a section (near the headband) over a pit that the camera wouldn't let me see which sections down were safe or not, and where there was a lot of frameskip-inducing vertical scrolling. Mleh. I may go back and try to finish later.
I really, really liked the game over screen.

author: PerilousPete
title: Copy Killer
comments: Hm. I'm interested, but I'm also having trouble completing the first level.
As the description says, you need to pay very close attention to the instructions. But here's a crash course:

The objective is to find the messages, you can see one in one of the screenshots above (small piece of paper). These appear randomly in levels, so even if you go to every level you might not get them all. Just go back and they will appear.

To open the doors, you need to kill all other clones in the level, then kill yourself. If you read the messages it explains why, but basically the doors open when there's only one clone left, it can't be the one you're controlling. Once the doors open, you need to get the remaining clone out the door, so before you die be sure to set it up so that this will happen. Once the clone gets out the door, he arrives in the room next door to the right or left (depending on whether you left from the right or left of the room). You then take control of this clone. Rinse and repeat.
It's a crazy idea to explain, and I had just as much trouble/fun making it, but hopefully this clears it up for you (or at least helps you past the first level :P).
Oh, you may need to do some levels more than once to find all the messages. This is normal. Once you've found all 10, when you finish the level you're on it will take you to the boss level :D
